description:
The Chinatown centered on Grant Avenue and Stockton Street in San Francisco, California, is the oldest Chinatown in North America and the largest Chinese enclave outside Asia.

Chinatown is an enclave that continues to retain its own customs, languages, places of worship, social clubs, and identity. There are two hospitals, numerous parks and squares, a post office, and other infrastructure. 

The place is also a major tourist attraction, drawing more visitors annually than the Golden Gate Bridge. If you're looking for little gadgets and gifts to take home this is a must stop. You can also find a pretty good imitation Northface bubble jacket!
author: Tracey M.

description:
A historical and the oldest Chinatown in US, I think most of the buildings are still original, no way to find buildings that old anywhere else! We walked around after our dinner at the famous Chinese restaurant Z & Y, it was good exercise after a big dinner though. 

Many little stores sell vintage like stuffs that can't be find anywhere else, sister and I got a few QiPao which are traditional Chinese dresses that are very tight and body hugging. The murals around were amazing too, we particularly loved the Bruce Lee and monkey king murals that were amazing arts. I also saw some nicer Chinese restaurants and a few Chinese bars around, too bad we couldn't try some of those cause we had to take parents back after a long sightseeing day. 

Absolutely tour this historical Chinatown, eat at one of the restaurants, have some drinks at one of the bars, get one of those traditional Chinese dresses. This is such a fun place to hang around!
author: Mimi L.

description:
Growing up, Chinatown always seemed like an aggressive place to be. People shoved and pushed for the best produce. Street vendors would scream and people would make snide comments as they flowed down the river of people. Add in the tourist and it was definitely mayhem.

However, now that I'm grown and I've seen other versions of Chinatowns across North America, SF Chinatown is truly unique! 

The pushing/shoving, street vendors, and deals under the table to get rid of produce after peak hour adds a flavor and a richness that most others can't replicate. I've literally seen the fish monger chase a runaway fish out his door, a produce maven sell tomatoes at $1 a bag so they don't go bad, and watched mom buy honey loquats from a street vendor whose quality looked better than the store. Compare this to many other Chinatowns and you'll easily see the experiences are second to none!

My favorite shop definitely belongs to Mong Kok Bakery which makes sky high green onion bread! Second is probably the fortune cookie shop just from childhood memories. And last, Golden Gate Bakery is good too...you know, if they ever open.
author: Elaine Y.

description:
Ni hao ma!!

Chinatown in San Francisco is iconic. Known most as the end destination for Sun Wukong (the Monkey King) in the epic Journey to the West. The sequel: Journey to the West: Morning After Dim Sum was TERRIBLE!! Zhang Ziyi was totally miscast as Niu Mo Wang!! (Before you rush on to IMDB, I'm making this up. I do that. I'm bored.)

I've always been a fan of everything Chinese. Chinese cuisine, traditional Chinese music, plus I'm probably the only European-American around who wears nothing but Chinese shirts. What can I say: it's my bag, man! Even had a Chinese "girlfriend." She was a Major in the Chinese army, stationed in Xi'an. Not a soldier, doofus! A doctor/scientist. Too bad she was married.

Anyhoo-- Chinatown in San Francisco is a must do at least once. But, it's really just one big tourist trap with numerous shops selling cheap souvenirs, and myriad Chinese restaurants. Some are good, some aren't. I would assume they have some really cool events during the year; such as the lunar festival, mid-autumn festival, and Joy Luck Club festival. But, I've only been there during non-exciting weekends, so I find it not much different than Chinatown LA. But, it does have a different vibe than that of LA: probably because it's so iconic and it just breathes cultural history. Fun place to stroll around, browse through the lovely cheongsam (though they always make my butt look fat) and to stop in for some dim sum. And don't forget the obligatory photo op in front of the Dragon Gate. 

Xie xie!
author: Michael H.

description:
I haven't been here since I was a kid! Seems modernized then I remembered! But it was a fun experience to come visit again.


A lot of shopping stores, restaurants, bigger than most China Town's I've been too.

The murals on the wall was amazing! I captured a few! The had fireworks happening and dragon dancing as well. 

Saturday's are overwhelming but entertaining at the same time. Wear comfortable shoes!
author: Anna S.

description:
SF china town!!!! Got to come here finally as I haven't gone since I was a kid. A lot of walking and a variety of stores. I feel like it has definitely modernized because I expected it to be more ghetto.

There's a lot of different restaurants to choose from and you can also buy a lot of different things here from clothes to houseware.
author: Christine K.

description: Where to start, I have Worked and played in the city for 35 years and I am always impressed with the culture and energy of China town. I have several clients in the neighborhood and I am always treated with so much kindness and respect even when I am butchering the language trying to order at a hole in the wall restaurant. Most of the time I just get a laugh or a smile with a point of the finger at the item I want. This weekend we just happened to find a prime parking spot 1 block away from the start of the Autumn Moon festival. I was in awe with the crowds that came out to celebrate. All the vendors were very nice and willing to explain in English the products they were selling. Some of the stands were definitely local only as it was a controlled chaos, dont think for a moment I didnt get in to the mix, My wife just shook her head at me like I was a kid in a candy store. The short is this is a Great place to immerse oneself into the culture and enjoy everything it has to offer. Eat what scares you and greet people like you were long time friends.
author: Manny G.

description:
San Francisco is a city that has a diverse population along with unique locations to visit. There's something about this city that attracts people from around the world who are looking for a one of a kind experience. Chinatown in San Francisco is different from other Chinese communities around the United States. As soon as you set foot into this community, you'll be tempted to further explore what it has to offer.

San Francisco has a large Chinese population who stay true to their culture. Rich traditions are handed down from one generation to another. A lot of the elderly population within this community speak little English so it's difficult to communicate with them from time to time. 

Of course you'll find the trinket shops selling toys and noisemaker fireworks. Several jewelry and home decor shops sell products that are unique to the area. However, what I found to be absolutely fascinating was the herbal shops that carried oils and herbs to cure/heal common ailments. All that you need to do is to describe your issue and they've got the perfect remedy for you! We purchased some of the Chinese oils for joint pain and migraines. We use it as needed and it has proven to be highly effective! 

Another draw to San Francisco Chinatown is the authentic food! McDonalds and Burger King cannot he found here! The restaurants are often very small and do not have a lot of the modern flairs that you'd see in the larger chain restaurants. A lot of the menus are bilingual, written in Chinese and English with photos to accompany each selection. My husband was ecstatic to find a couple of restaurants that had dim sum and chicken buns. Although you can find these dishes anywhere, you can't beat the taste of authentic Chinese street foods. It's different from what you would be served at a full-service restaurant. 

What I love about San Francisco Chinatown is that it's super cute! The colorful Chinese lanterns are prominently displayed from one block to another, high above the streets. The entrance to Chinatown has two dragon statues to welcome you here. People are friendly and filled with many stories that they love to share! San Francisco Chinatown is not to be missed as it's such a fun place to visit. It leaves you with an appreciation of Chinese customs and culture.
author: Michelle T.

description:
"Notice that the stiffest tree is most easily cracked, while the bamboo or willow survives by bending with the wind." - Bruce Lee

Ahhh Chinatown of San Francisco. The oldest Chinatown in North America, pre-dating the Gold Rush, circa 1849. Yet, before I talk Chinatown, why am I quoting Bruce Lee when he was raised in Hong Kong? Because many don't know Bruce Lee was born in San Francisco Chinatown. Did you know? If you're a Bruce Lee fanatic or just watched one of a dozen Hollywood movies of his life you probably already knew, but hey, Bruce Lee was American! 

So I can talk about Dim Sum, the fruit markets, the murals, the baos... like the other hundreds of reviews. But I'm not into repetition and boring you on how the best place for Egg Tarts (Dan Tat) is at Golden Gate Bakery on Grant (you should know). Instead let's talk about... The myth... The legend... 

The legend of Bruce Lee. Some might wonder shouldn't he be talked about in Hong Kong where his movie success began... or perhaps talked about in Seattle where he began teaching Martial Arts, and where he is buried at Lake View Cemetery, R.I.P. Nah, I choose to talk about Bruce Lee's association in San Francisco Chinatown because as the urban legend goes this is where it all began...

Back in the day, when Bruce Lee moved from Hong Kong back to San Francisco for a better education, he lived with his older brother in Chinatown. He eventually moved up to Seattle to attend college (where he met his wife) and shortly after began to teach martial arts. Lee was already a master of many techniques of the arts. The difference was he was willing to teach the ancient arts to anyone. Not only Chinese. He opened his doors to all, including "Gweilo" (non-Chinese). His fame grew and so did his successes... eventually word got out within the secretive martial arts community and somehow this had to be stopped. Bruce Lee must be stopped!

Enter Wong Jack Man (correct spelling, trust). Wong was a master in several fighting disciplines including, T'ai chi ch'uan, Xingyiquan, and the Shaolin technique. Wong had a fierce following of traditionalists and overall the majority within the community. Who is this Bruce Lee punk teaching "our" martial arts to "outsiders"? Of course, there's the Hollywood version of the fight, then there's the urban legend of the fight, but make no mistake, be it in the underground of Oakland or San Francisco, it did happen. If Wong Jack Man won... Bruce Lee must stop teaching outsiders. If Lee won he was free to choose to teach the ancient arts to anyone. Long story short... the match lasted only 3 minutes, Lee pummeling his opponent, and as the story goes... Wong Jake Man was literally running away in the end! The legend of Bruce Lee is born... 

In the end, San Francisco Chinatown is a great place for all, yes including you "Outsiders" lol. It is no longer ruled by the dark underworld of the 19th century Tongs, or more recently the Triads. Today, it's all about capitalism and great places to eat! You can find some of the best Chinese cuisine & baos anywhere! It's predominantly Cantonese, so it retains that vibrant Hong Kong vibe. And visit during Chinese Lunar New Year... it's happening! 

So next time when in San Francisco Chinatown remember this is where the legend of Bruce Lee was born. A legacy intact 'til the end of time. It's really a wonderful story when you think about it... a young man breaking away from the prejudices of his own society to become an icon for all the people. It's definitely a story that should be told. We can dismiss Big Trouble in Little China, starring Kurt Russel, har har oh please. Enter The Dragon...

"Love is like a friendship caught on fire. In the beginning a flame, very pretty, often hot & fierce, but still only light & flickering. As love grows older, our hearts mature & our love becomes as coals, deep-burning and unquenchable." - Bruce Lee
author: Eric R.

description:
Date: 10/21/2017  Time: 3:35 PM  62°  Partly sunny

Because I did a check in of this community, I got one of those yelp reminders to write a review, which popped up on my yelp page. Where do I start in preparing a review of San Francisco Chinatown? I have been there numerous times as a child all the way to a senior citizen now. What is there for me to say when some of my fellow yelpers (Victor G, William L, Tiffany D) have already mentioned it with stellar reviews? 

I grew up in a Chinatown that is across the Bay - Oakland Chinatown. I don't want to do any comparing as to which city has the better Chinatown. However, I have a preference as to which one is more convenient to go to by public transportation and which one has the flat surface walking on the pavement. Besides I was born, raised and grew up on the east side of the bay.  

San Francisco Chinatown brings back childhood memories of some of the weekend outings to the Chinese movie houses (World Theater, Great Star Theater and a third theater on Grant) with my mom, brothers and sisters while my dad go and visit his association on Clay Street for social activities among his compadres. (I'm not going to elaborate as to what went on in the back room.)  After the movies, some of the time my family and I dined at the old Sam Wo Restaurant. It was a hole in the wall joint that was opened late. They had to shut down back in 2012 due to food safety concerns and rodent problems in the kitchen. About two years ago, Sam Wo reopened. I have yet to dine at the new one.

The memories also include the wedding banquets, red egg ginger parties and the Chinese New Year parades that I have attended. Two years ago, I attended the Autumn Moon Festival on Grant Avenue. The festival was okay. I'm not much of a fan for mooncakes, except for a small piece of doong yoong don wong yuet beng. I have to watch my sugar and carbs intake these days.

Walking to SF Chinatown from Macy's in Union Square via Grant Avenue is not that bad. However, the  street becomes narrow at the entrance facing Bush Street. It is crowded with the local people and tourists. Occasionally I will see a few street vendors and street musicians along the way. Sometimes there are women handing out handbills to tourist to try a dim sum restaurant in the area.

With so many eateries, bakeries, souvenir shops and clothing stores around, I do have my favorite places to dine, shop and pick up dim sum, egg tarts and sesame balls.

New Woey Loy Guey for some home-style Cantonese dishes - pan fried pork hash with salted fish, stir fried chicken with shiitake mushrooms and veggies, snails. (Chinese soul food...lol)

Golden Gate Bakery for the best egg tarts around. There's always a long line of people to savor these sweet delights.

Good Mong Kok for dim sum and sesame balls. Three har gow for $2.10; three sesame balls for $1.80.

Wycen Foods on Stockton Street for an assortment of Chinese sausages aka lop cheung. They also carry other grocery items, such as mung bean vermicelli, snacks, hot sauce, canned goods, etc.

Eastern Bakery for coffee crunch cake, assorted sliced cake rolls, sesame balls, cow ear cookies aka ngow yee beng, moon cakes.

Peking Bazaar for souvenir gifts, houseware items, clothes, jewelry and accessories.

Mow Lee Shing Kee Company for lop yuk aka preserved pork belly. I don't eat it, but my mom does and occasionally she has it with some steamed rice.

Oriental Pearl Restaurant on Clay Street is nice as far as ambiance is concerned for tourists, but the size of some of their dim sum leave a lot to be desired. 

Street parking is about as impossible as it gets. Thus, the available parking is the Portsmouth Square Garage. The entrance is on Kearny Street between Clay and Washington Streets.
author: Carol C.

description: Don't buy it at the first store.... whatever you think is unique, just wait and check out a few other stores first! Fun place, don't forget to haggle! I love how they push buttons on a calculator to make you think  they are giving you a deal
author: Jimmy G.

description:
Great little shops, foods, and culture.  Food!  I love the food.  So many hidden shops and new things to discover.  I found the best custard buns and eggrolls I have ever tasted.  I wish I could've flew them all back home with me.

Chinatown seems endless.  So many things to see.  I walked for blocks and blocks and still managed to find new things at every turn.  Definitely a must when visiting San Fran.
author: Abby L.

description:
Loved walking around San Fran Chinatown.

So many restaurants, bakeries, tea shops, souvenir stores, open markets, brightly colored buildings, etc. Some of the souvenir shops are overpriced but there are some that are very reasonably priced. We came here mostly for dim sum and left incredibly satisfied, so good! Their baked goods are also fresh and well priced. Don't forget to visit Golden Gate Fortune Cookies and see how they are made. Good Mong Kok Bakery also has delicious dim sum and it won't hurt your wallet.
author: Kimberly J.

description: I enjoyed SF chinatown area that was full of restaurants, stores and some cool building structures and art murals. I felt welcomed and safe as I walked around the streets alone.  The day I was visiting there was a "flower festival" going on and some of the main streets were cut off to cars making it easier to walk around.  I wasnt able to check out a few popular restaurants in the area but I did enjoy the overall vibe of the community. I visit a lot of Chinatown communities in my travel and this was one of my favorites.
author: Teresa S.

description:
With this being the largest Chinatown outside of Asia, it is no surprise that there's an abundance of tourists going in and out of here. I was one of those tourists. Having not visited San Francisco in years, I was quite excited to explore the city and Chinatown was on the top of my places to visit.

Chinatown was within walking distance of where I was staying and it wasn't to hard to see the Chinatown gate right at Grant Ave. As soon as I walked passed the gate, I was hit with the sights and sounds of Chinatown. There were storefronts selling all kinds of knick knacks from Chinese slippers to panda bears in silk clothing to magnets. The shopping stores were the first to line up along the Grant Ave, the restaurants and boba shop come a little later upon further walking.

For restaurants, there are several tourist drawn spots. San Francisco Chinatown is home to the oldest dim sum tea house in America (Hang Ah Tea Room), bakeries and restaurants that former presidents have visited (Great Eastern Restaurant where Obama made a surprise visit, Eastern Bakery visited by Clinton), and popular egg tart bakeries where people line up for hours (Golden Gate Bakery, Good Mong Kok Bakery). The restaurants and bakeries are a bit spread out so you'll definitely get your workout walking. (The hills here will give you your stair climber work out hehe).

San Francisco's Chinatown is a lot of fun! There is a lot to see as well as eat and drink. The one thing I did notice however it is pricier than other Chinatowns I've visited. I found that their souvenirs were pricier than the airport or at Pier 39 (For example same Hello Kitty plush was $14.99 here while $8.99 at Pier 39 and $10.99 at the airport! I also found a imitation Hello Kitty wallet for $8.99! It was imitation and for that price, I can get a real one at the Sanrio store. Just saying ;) lol) Dim sum wise, it was also way pricier than other spots (The cheapest dim sum dish where I visited was $4.50). All in all though this place is quite an experience and well worth a visit.
author: Jenn G.

description: I just love this neighborhood. There are so many new businesses, dishes, and alleys to explore each time, today I kicked my morning off with s fifteen minute stroll through the neighborhood and especially love seeing Chinatown around 7am when the businesses are closed and folks are just starting to rise. The peaceful setting is quite different from how it feels during the hustle of the day. You'll find egg tart bakeries, anime gift shops, dim sum for days, seafood markets and more. The neighborhood takes over several blocks and can easily be accessed within a ten minute walk of the financial district and market street. The colors, sounds and energy alone are reason enough to visit. Chinatown really gets me thinking about our Asian immigrant neighborhoods and the impact they've made on our country. Cherry on top? I just finished reading The Joy Luck Club last week...impeccable timing.
author: Brittany S.

description:
We've been here many times, but each time is fun. There's something nostalgic for them since they've been going since they were small. 
It's got a ton of standard shops with typical Chinese and Asian goods, restaurants, tea shops and landmarks.
author: Danielle G.

description:
San Francisco Chinatown is the largest Chinatown in North America and is bordered on the north by Broadway St, the west by Powell St, the east by Kearny St and the south by Bush St.

This place is a definite must if you are visiting from out of town, but if you live within a 2 hour drive like me, I prefer to go only every couple years. My favorite part about Chinatown is walking around the area more so than any particular spot. When I was a vegetarian, I used to love Chinese bakeries, but now assume that pretty much everything I ate before is off limits because of butter and eggs. If I were to eat in this neighborhood nowadays, I would check out Lucky Creation Vegetarian Restaurant or Enjoy Vegetarian Restaurant in order to have more vegan options.

The gate with the dragons at the front of the neighborhood is fun, but a lot of the stores have cheap souvenirs for tourists that will get old real fast. Still worth checking out.
author: Regina W.

description:
Wonderful place! Crowded, but not obnoxious. Lots of great cheap souvenir places and even some good quality places as well. 

Just walk up and down Grant street and you won't be disappointed.
author: Sarah H.

description:
SF Chinatown is still the best C-Town in the country.  This place NEVER changes unlike LA Chinatown.  SO, if you want to eat and shop anything Chinese that has not changed in 50 years, then come here.  

The Dim Sum is one of thee best (the other is Oakland Chinatown).  You can always get a Guy Bao/Chicken the size of a saucer plate (HUGE!).  The Dim Sum is reasonably priced along with the other foods available at  any of the restaurants.  2 ppl can eat for around $10-$13 plus tip.

Chinatown is very big, stretching from Little Italy to the Stockton Tunnel which leads to DTSF.  It IS walkable, but if you are not use to long walks, bring a walking stick.  The hills are doable/walkable around Powell, Stockton, Broadway, Washington, Jackson, etc.

I love this place and always visit when I'm up here.  HIGHLY recommend visiting when you are in SF
author: Randy L.

description:
Ne hao? Wo hen hao.... 

Awesome! To a small town country girl from the east coast, this place is legit. Even my friends who live in China thought I was actually in China when I sent them my pictures. Haaahaaa 

Cheap prices a stereotype?? Nope, that's a fact. 

This area has the bus line that comes through. It has places for massages and reflexology, authentic cuisine, lots of t-shirts, coats and souvenirs, jewelry shop, phone case shop, a great park where I heard the locals getting together to play music. Friendly people and a great place to visit. A must stop. It's worth it.
author: Carrie K.

description:
Chinatown in San Francisco will always have a soft spot in my heart. I have a lot of memories of my childhood spending time here with my family. And while new restaurants and shops continue to appear, it still feels exactly the same from when I was a child.

This Chinatown is fairly large, well kept and overall clean. There are tons of shops (both inexpensive as well as expensive). Also, tons of restaurants, hole in the walls and delicious bakeries. All different price points for what you are looking for.

Over the years, they started putting up murals and more urban art - which I love.

As for food and such, just because it's in Chinatown, it doesn't mean it is the best, more authentic or a good choice. Do select your establishment carefully either by researching it in advance or asking around locals. I've gotten food poisoning on numerous occasions from Chinatown and have definitely had some really bad Chinese food here.

Great place to visit for tourists and at least once in your life!
author: Natasha S.

description: Bustling with life in every corner! This Chinatown is huge and be prepared to bring your walking shoes! I love coming here to get food and go around the local shops to see what they have!
author: Nancy D.

description: San Francisco's Chinatown is incredible. I've been to Chinatown in NYC, Boston and DC, but have never seen anything quite like this one. It is really cool and another must see when visiting San Francisco. There are several Chinese restaurants within Chinatown. I would highly recommend checking Yelp (or similar) for reviews because it is difficult to tell which ones are amazing versus not so great. There are plenty of shops that sell various items including souvenirs. It may make sense to hold off on souvenir shopping until you've already checked out Chinatown.
author: Kari C.

description:
This is one of the prettiest, largest, and busiest Chinatowns that I have ever visited!  (not counting Hong Kong, Taiwan, Macau, and China - haha!)

Yuri and I lucked out with the parking!  We happened to find a metered stall, but the meter was broken!  The meter maid reassured us that we could park for as long as we liked... for free!  SCORE!!!

Shopping was fun, but getting "don tat" (egg custard tarts) was even more fun!  (see my review of Golden Gate Bakery - LOL!)  https://www.yelp.com/biz/golden-gate-bakery-san-francisco

In the past, I've bought beef jerkey from Jackson Street and various types of lup cheong (Chinese sausage) from a factory whose name escapes me at the moment.  I also got a knitted cap and a green four-leaf clover purse hook - I still use these souvenirs!

One year, we had dim sum at an underground level of some restaurant when my friend's daughter was in the Miss Chinatown USA pageant.  During that trip, I got some cute Dragon & Phoenix towels from a street vendor and some fancy Chinese pinwheel that I've never seen before.  I put it on my dad's grave.  I'm sure he was amused!

I really like this Chinatown because it seems cleaner than Honolulu's; it has more action than Los Angeles'; and it's bigger than Las Vegas'.  

Writing this is making me want to return again soon!
author: Nadine C.

description:
你好! (Translated: Hello!)

This is it! The first, original and oldest neighborhood in San Francisco's history! Chinatown brings customers (residents and tourists alike) of all ages to experience the Chinese's shopping and dining culture every year. Located at Grant Street near Bush Street, you'll enter at the Gateway Arch to welcome visitors in awe. Once you'll enter, you can see many attractions and local businesses especially classic architectures by giving Chinatown a tradition of prosperity and kindness.

For local shops across Chinatown, there are tons of goods to own like nick-knacks, mini statues and sculptures, original Chinese artworks (i.e. paintings and hand-written Chinese letters), delicious Chinese restaurants and baked goods and many more! Back in the 1990s, my parents and I are always coming to SF Chinatown the most because we wanted to shop their affordable goods. Chinese herbs is their top priority choice to shop which it's so rare to find in any Asian markets in Sacramento (i.e. dried Lingzhi and red ginseng roots). Speaking of baked goods, we always coming to Golden Gate Bakery the most which we enjoyed tasting and eating egg tarts especially for delicious fortune cookies from Golden Gate Fortune Cookies. For restaurant dining, I really enjoyed dining incredible Chinese foods. No matter how good it is, it always appetizing for everyone! Yummy!

Furthermore, Chinatown has a wide arrange of attractions! Every day of every year, you can hear the sounds of every Chinatown residents by having conversations back and forth. Also, there's Tai Chi in Portsmouth Square, so you can relax your mood in ease without being too anxious. There's tons of street artworks across Chinatown too, so you can see every paintings represents the culture of China's everyday lives in a contemporary ways. Every year, Chinatown has a parade every February, so you can see many floats, acrobats and lion dancers throughout the whole day and night! It's fun for the whole family and friends!

Parking can be a challenge to park. If you're driving with an automobile, you can park at the surface metered parking nor the Portsmouth Square Parking garage if it's available for space. Alternatively, you can also ride a bike, walk, carpool, ride sharing or public transportation easier without the hassles and gimmicks.

To sum up, San Francisco's Chinatown is the most original and poignant neighborhood spot that I've always enjoyed and experience the Chinese culture and attractions all seasons long! A must visit for your San Francisco trip needs! A well received visit indeed! 恭喜發財! (Translated: Gung Hay Fat Choy!) My rating: 5 solid stars.
author: William L.

description: Now this is a real Chinatown! I have been to Chinatown's in numerous places including NYC and DC but SF's Chinatown is literally its own town within SF. There are countless shops, restaurants, electronic stores located here. There is blocks and blocks to explore in SF Chinatown!
author: Sam T.

description: Fun times in Chinatown! Lots of shops with small odds and ins and all things Chinese! Great experience.
author: Joiya A.

description:
very Nice place to hang out and check out the sights, my girl friend really like it a lot.
we really enjoyed the shops and art work, at the stores.
if i come back in the future, I'll be sure to have dinner, at one of the many places to eat at.
author: Paul P.

description: Chinatown is quite a historical area.  It's San Francisco's most densely populated area. There are many shops and restaurants where immigrants start out.  The cultural beauty of the place is overtaken by high rents as many stores change hands.  Also, it's not the cleanest area.  Stockton St is the real Chinatown.  The produce off the sidewalk is overcrowded with food stands and shoppers. Thus, the sidewalks are filthy. Grant Ave. Is just a tourist mecca that doesn't represent the true Chinatown.  However patrons want to shop, there's plenty to see, shop and eat.
author: Angela W.

description:
Man, this area was huge. You can literally spend a whole day here shopping and eating. 

You know you're in Chinatown when the streets are littered with Asian faces and sidewalks filled with fruits/veggies and souvenir merchandises. I'd say price compare since I def saw similar items at diff shops at diff prices. 

Parking will be a pain in the behind. Our group parked at the Portsmouth Square Garage. The total was $21 for half a day's adventure -- translating to about 6 to 7 hours. I will also have a review of this parking deck and a pic of the prices. We also used this parking opportunity to walk over to Union Square for further shopping. :)
author: Andrea M.

description: San Francisco's Chinatown is the best Chinatown I've ever been to.  It spans more than a dozen streets and has plenty of shops, restaurants, cafes, etc.  I was really impressed with the decor and the beautiful, world-famous Chinatown Gate.  They have plenty of lovely gift shops and delicious pastry shops.  They also have some lovely supermarkets with fresh, inexpensive produce.  I would visit often if I lived in the SF Bay Area!
author: Pegah Y.

description:
The sis and I had to visit the oldest chinatown in the US. It was just too good to miss. We found a parking garage and it wasn't too expensive. We had to walk a little ways, but this place is the epitome of the chinatown I've always wanted to visit. The smell is pungent with all sorts of food and a mixture of sewer, it's overcrowded with tourists and those that are browsing to get some groceries or buying something to eat, different voices shouting out numerous things, and good food for really cheap.

Don't expect clean establishments or exceptional service. Come with an open mind and don't judge a store or restaurant by its front. Some of the best food are from here. Come with an empty belly and be prepared to get blown away with culture and flavor.
author: Anh L.

description:
Been down here a bit these past few decades, and I'm glad I experienced this place when I did.  It can be universally agreed upon that parking stinks here.  

I wish I'd been taken somewhere else, but in fact this place left me still in San Francisco in some sort of crazy tourist trap.  Fortunately, those roasted ducks hanging in the window can be found in other places (TONS elsewhere in SF) where I can find parking spaces right next to the pigs.  (the roasted ones)

Fun to return- glad that the 'flavor' of this area has seeped out in to other areas.  If you've never been, I'd suggest trying it once and then see how often or even if you want to go again.  This has become a once, maybe twice a year thing in my book, even though I'll pass it dozens of times in a year.
author: David B.

description: Numerous shops, restaurants, and banks. Gets crowded and busy especially during weekends. Be wary about lack of parking. Parking too expensive. Good place for tourists to hang out! 2nd largest Chinatown in the US after New York City's Chinatown (Manhattan). There is a 2nd SF Chinatown on Clement St in Inner Richmond District.
author: A L.

description:
San Francisco's Chinatown is so beautiful and cute. My mother and I walked down there from the scarlet Huntington this evening to take a stroll and go to dinner. We went to the Hunan home kitchen for dinner, and it was delicious!

We just arrived in San Francisco today and we are having a great time. There are so many cute stores and restaurants and boba places!

Seriously enjoying the food we are eating right now. We got wor Wonton soup, Combo chow mein, a Side of assorted veggies, and xiao long bao dumplings at Hunan Home Kitchen. DELISH! The food is so rich and the service was great. I have traveled to China several times, and the food at this restaurant is just as good if not better than the food in actual China.

I recommend the dumplings that we started off with because they are especially delicious. They even have a little bit of peanut butter in them! Wow! We then got boba down the street... Great walking!
author: Amanda W.

description:
This a great place to get AMAZING deals on just about anything you want from souvenirs, clothing, furniture and food. The exact same items found at the major tourist spots can be found here for much less. The SF hoodies cost between $30 - $40. Here we picked up the hoodies for $20. We saved a ton of money. The area is crowded, yet the people were nice and helpful including the merchants.

TIPS
-Negotiate. The least you can get is about 10% off the already low prices.
-Save Chinatown for your last day in SF. You get to see what the prices are during your trip. Then you can compare when you visit.
-The California Cable Car Line runs directly in front of this street. Just ask the cable car conductor.
author: Sam N.

description:
What can I say? Every guest that has visited us in the Bay Area wants to visit China Town. Every guest that has visited China Town enjoys their experience. 

Tips: 

1.) Plan your parking: There are some places located adjacent to China Town with ample parking -- and some of it is free! Nearly every space is free on Sundays.
2.) Plan to walk: This is a city built on hills. Be prepared to walk up and down hill and over curbs.
3.) Bring cash: Some stores just don't like it when you buy a $1 item and charge it with your credit card. Take some cash (in small bills) if you plan on shopping for inexpensive items (and there are A LOT of inexpensive items).
4.) Dress for the weather: Weather in San Francisco can be chilly -- even in the summer. If you're going to be walking for a few hours, please remember to dress accordingly.
5.) The famous "Dragon's Gate" entrance is located at the corner of Bush and Grant. This is just four blocks from Market Street -- not far from some of the taxi, trolley and bus stops as well as the underground Muni station.
6.) The Chinese food in China Town can range from Americanized "Chinese" cuisine to authentic. Find what you like and try it!
7.) The Dragon's Gate entrance isn't far from Union Square (Post St. & Stockton) or Market Street. Both are great spots to experience modern San Francisco too.
author: Chris M.

description:
This is probably the largest Chinatown in all of North America! 

It encompasses supermarkets, bakeries, dim sum shops that are over the counter fast food styled, bubble tea shops, herbal medicine shops, fish markets, souvenir shops, an open square for the elders to sit and play chess or talk, etc. 

I think this place makes me reminisce a lot of how Hong Kong used to be back in the day - I mean, in some ways it still is, but with the modernization of the place, it's rare to not see beauty shops with bright lights or bright lit pharmacies all over the place. I think San Francisco's Chinatown keeps the heritage and culture there is for Chinese people.

I also think that the Chinese New Year celebration is very authentic and super exciting to visit - where people purchase firecrackers - big or small and throw them everywhere on the ground. This is banned in other parts of the world such as Hong Kong because it's dangerous, but yet it's a tradition that is still kept in the States - I find this pretty interesting. 

Although it's Chinatown, the graffiti walls still adds a touch of the San Francisco culture, and like many like to say - where the East meets the West. If you're in San Francisco area, I highly recommend coming to Chinatown for a visit!
author: Kristy N.

description:
San Francisco Chinatown... one of a kind!

What is one of the major popular tourist attraction in San Francisco aside from the Golden Gate Bridge (if not the most)... yes, Chinatown! This Is reminiscent of when I lived in Taiwan for two years when I was very young.  It is probably the largest Chinese community outside Asia... and what's great about it is they seem to be always open! When looking for something to do on holidays when the whole country is closed for business where do we go... Chinatown, where everything is hustling and bustling like just a normal day. There's so much history and culture in the community and, yes, it's a tourist trap. 

Located in downtown San Francisco, I've seen Chinatown during the day and evening. No matter how many times I visit Chinatown I always feel like a tourist. There's plenty to discover here most notably are the plentiful authentic restaurants, its produce and fish markets and stores. It's a place like no other.

Dined here a few times and ate at Chinatown Restaurant on Washington Street (yes, that's the name, as plain and simple can be) https://www.yelp.com/biz/chinatown-restaurant-san-francisco-2?hrid=ebbrMvwZmVZs7iTFkTJiKg&utm_campaign=www_review_share_popup&utm_medium=copy_link&utm_source=(direct), New Woey Loy Goey Restaurant on Jackson Street https://www.yelp.com/biz/new-woey-loy-goey-restaurant-san-francisco-2?hrid=v9qh7bGjMRZJOlR0foy7rQ&utm_campaign=www_review_share_popup&utm_medium=copy_link&utm_source=(direct), purchased baked good at the Golden Gate Fortune Cookies on Ross Alley https://www.yelp.com/biz/golden-gate-fortune-cookies-san-francisco?hrid=0exnMQJp-Y8bA-bUIzK3yQ&utm_campaign=www_review_share_popup&utm_medium=copy_link&utm_source=(direct) and the Golden Gate Bakery on Grant Ave https://www.yelp.com/biz/golden-gate-bakery-san-francisco?hrid=v_aCF0MS1iUIfQRBUE90sQ&utm_campaign=www_review_share_popup&utm_medium=copy_link&utm_source=(direct)... and checked out many of the shops around. I remember also purchasing an 18k hoop earrings in one of the jewelry stores many years ago. 

Parking! That's another story... it's always a challenge! If not able to find one within the area you may have to park on the outskirts and walk. Bring comfy shoes because steep hills may tire you easily. I'm also interested in doing the Chinatown 90-minute walking tour... there is a story about the Golden Dragon Massacre at the Imperial Palace and until this day the Imperial Palace is still open for business.

Review #0633 (and 444th review for the business)
author: May A.

description:
Yeah.  I'm a fan of Chinatown in San Francisco.  It's probably the tourist trap I go to the most when I am in the city.  It's not for the knick-knack shops but for the food.  There are some really good authentic places to food here.  There are some garbage dumps too, but Yelp is pretty good in steering you in the right direction.

I love how it really does feel like a city within a city.  What I don't love is that some of the places don't accept the good old credit card, but really it's still totally worth it to get the amazing food.

The other good part of this little gem is that it's up a hill.  It seems everything here is up hill from everything else.  And what better way to work off all that Dim Sum than to walk up hill both ways?!

For a traditional 'merican tourist, this might be a little "too authentic" and grungy.   But really, if you are coming to SF, you probably should be prepared for the dirtiest city you have ever been in, and Chinatown might be the dirtiest of the tourist parts.

One thing I want to stress. WALK if you are able.
author: Robert S.

description: A walk thru Chinatown is worth it, we went from Market street all the way up and down to the other end of Chinatown, nice sightseeing of a different culture. Stopped by a couple of bakeries and tried different items, a lot of places to eat. Take your time as you explore it. Would go everytime in San Francisco.
author: Rafael B.

description:
Always a must stop when I am in San Francisco. One of the few Chinatown's that is comparable to the one in Los Angeles.

Street parking is rough. Metered, they take credit cards. Always crowded with people and cars so you have to be careful when walking and driving.

Cash is king here if you want to buy and bargain.

Fresh fruit, cheap items, egg tarts, fortune cookies, and dim sum!
author: Kevin W.

description: It Is SF China town, great walk and crowded and kinda dirty on the streets, but going through the end of it is where all of the food is located at.
author: DrBarbara S.

description:
We didn't have a bunch of time and my kids didn't want Chinese food (Boo Kids!) But hey when in SF gotta get some Chinese on ya.  http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/san-franciscos-chinatown-san-francisco?select=RkSkKJDGimTRDXGJky8voQ  Fun Shops full of silly shit.   So we bumped around a bunch of the kooky tourist shops. http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/san-franciscos-chinatown-san-francisco?select=1Mw0SMA3bJJ3EhxolPCttQ

Gotta looke likey a local so you don't get ripped offs.
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/san-franciscos-chinatown-san-francisco?select=EmVjr_ztlt37ek74KNvPhQ

Training my kids right.  http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/san-franciscos-chinatown-san-francisco?select=cszgnO_msycA3M6D2bwa5w  the onlyest place in CA you an score these without a Prop. 215 card.

You never know??? http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/san-franciscos-chinatown-san-francisco?select=hy1u1WGUo3IAbLluw8fkiA

Scored on some new slippas http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/san-franciscos-chinatown-san-francisco?select=0rBeh5c82JuRWFUb0mBBkA

Too many peeps here http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/san-franciscos-chinatown-san-francisco?select=_RqMq1LVockQeddoxrAsHw

I'll be back when I need some new kicks or some illegal fireworks.
author: Roy B.

description:
All of China's best packed into a long 4-6 city block radius of San Francisco's financial district. 

*Oriental fans (my mother flips over these! I call them her "hot flash controller)
*Bakeries (moon cakes)
*Sash & kimono ensembles 
*Graffiti
*Restaurants
*Salons 
*Masseuse
*Live sheet music
*Street cars 
*Photo ops 
*Tons of restaurants, culture rich shops, tea retailers and a bunch of condensed awesomeness.

Take a half day and explore Chinatown; you won't regret it.

~Christy Love
author: Christy A.

description: The oldest Chinatown in North America. If you're a Chinese person living in NorCal, you must visit here at least once in your lifetime. I remember visiting when I was a kid. The main reason for my last visit was Golden Gate Bakery. If it's open, make sure you get in line for the fresh egg tarts. And if you're looking for cheap souvenirs, then you came to the right place. Avoid the headache and don't bother trying to find parking on the streets and park in the garage instead. I do want to come one day during Lunar New Year and watch the parade.
author: Helen H.

description: First trip to Chinatown. Lots to see and crazy amounts of food and Fresh markets too. Would recommend.. it's a must see!
author: Lisa G.

description:
Compared to the Chinatowns in other big cities such as the one in LA, San Francisco's Chinatown is decent and worth a trek there once or twice. 

Note that especially for SF Chinatown, it is definitely a BIG tourist trap. If you are looking for good dim sum and cheap bargains, try to avoid the area north of the Chinatown gate. Going past the gate will only lead you to tourist stores with collectibles that you probably won't want to pay for. The outskirts of Chinatown such as along Stocktown is where you want to go. This is where all the beautiful smelly markets are and where the good food is.

Even if you are a longtime native of SF, it's always good to venture to Chinatown. You don't know what you'll find and so it's worth the visit!
author: Bryan W.

description:
My family and I have been to China a few times, and SF's Chinatown comes pretty close. If you don't look up and only look at street level shops, you could easily be fooled. When you look up, or pay attention to the steep incline of some streets, that's when you realize you're across the ocean on another continent.

IMO, that's one of the coolest features of this place; it's a perfect 50/50 mix between San Francisco and China. We didn't have the greatest experience dining here, but the shops sell everything from large golden Buddha statues and ornate bracelets to cheap touristy nicknacks.
author: Nic Z.

description: One of the best Chinatowns in all of the US. lots of fun touristy shops on the Main Street, lots of fun food markets, and restaurants. one of my favorite things to do in Chinatown is to buy a box of poppers and scare the tourists while walking down the street. Stop by one of the high quality tea shops and enjoy some dim sum while in the area.
author: Amber V.

description:
I have to say this is one of the biggest Chinatown I have ever seen out of Asia. Actually wait, Asia doesn't really have Chinatown. Ok....

I like the fact that you can get lost in here. Its huge. I would say at least over 10 blocks. I didn't count.

I somewhat think this is a tourist area as well. Its so crazy busy. As well the sidewalk could be a bit too narrow, I find. There are good Chinese restaurant in the area.

I had to come here because my parents told me to buy dried shrimp. Yes dried shrimp. They insisted I can only get it in San Fran. Yes.... I am not joking. I managed to find high quality dried food. I bought them home and they were delicious. thumbs up.

Only fall back is the parking. Free parking is hard to find on Sunday. Not to mention the paid parking and meter parking is just as hard. You could be cycling around and around in circle. 

Comparing this one to the Seattle one and Vancouver BC one. This one is way better.
author: Denise W.

description: The last time I went to Chinatown to a herb shop I use my credit card and after using it I began having problems on my credit card so I suggest never use a credit card in Chinatown use cash only  be where
author: Marty W.

description:
Interesting fact about Chinatown, we all know it's a tourist attraction, but did you know it draws in more visitors annually than the Golden Gate Bridge? Crazy right? 

Your trip into Chinatown can be what you make it of it.  You can look for some interesting gifts, buy some exotics teas, try some of the best dim sum you will have!

I have been to Chinatown many times and basically anything goes, if you are looking for something, I'm sure you will find it, you just have to know where to look.

I can spend all day in Chinatown, there is so much to see and to shop for. They even have walking tours for those who want to learn the history of Chinatown. 

You never know where your adventure might lead you while in Chinatown, so go live a little and have fun!
author: Monica O.

description:
Enter the dragon gate!!!!

BITS & PIECES:
(1) Here's there's a lot of people - many tourist stoping and taking photos, why not? It's such a great little place! Sometimes can cause pedestrian traffic... cause I gotta go to my favorite places in Chinatown - ya know? Stock up my fridge for the whole week... cause I'm homesick!
(2) Tons of cheap little dumpling places! If there's a line... go to the next one! 
(3) Boba places too!
(4) Little gift shops - selling statues, lipstick pursues, scarfs, random little toys... and oh... lots of random little stuff! 
(5) Sometimes there's a funeral going and if you're driving a car... be prepare to stop and drive in slowly. Traditionally, they will walk and drive around the block of Chinatown.
(6) No parking! So get here by Bart
(7) Restrooms are difficult to find - just go to a restaurant and order something ... they will have a restroom

**OVERALL: my favorite place to go during the weekend... I do all my grocery stuff... stuff all the Chinese dumplings in me .. for a week... and repeat!
author: Mindy Y.

description:
THE BEST IN THE WEST!!!

I'm amazed every time I come here - nostalgic.  Honestly, Grant Street is super touristy, but do what you want tourists, use those maps.  The best thing is word of mouth (aka YELP) and ask locals what to see and do.  

Culture - SF Chinatown is filled with vibrant culture, foods, and trinkets.  All this is visible in the atmosphere.  What's great about Chinatown is the uniqueness of all the culture combined in one place.  You will get immersed in a variety of dialects, broadening your knowledge of all the Asian cultures.  The moment you enter, you're in a different world. 

Foods - When you go around any corner, you smell authentic Chinese cuisines.  Let's not forget those hanging roast ducks and pigs.  I love seeing people's facial expressions and picture taking moments when they come across these exotic dishes. The food is always cheap if you go to the right places.

Trinkets - Bargaining 101 starts here.  Just remember when they say the price is 'FINAL', it never is.  Not having cash in Chinatown is not an option.  Banks and ATM's available.

For non-locals, don't forget to pick up some keepsakes and non-perishable items for your friends and family.  

For cheap salons and high quality, you can't beat the prices in Chinatown.  Although parking is horrendous, anything is possible with patience.  I suggest parking at Portsmouth Square Plaza to save your sanity.  

If you haven't been to Chinatown, it's about time you go :D
author: Christine R.

description:
The streets are too crowded for any festival, but all festivities are always top of the line that you don't want to miss it. 

San Francisco's Chinatown is a great place to find prestigious cultures, enjoy fabulous Chinese food, meeting people from all over the world and just be here for the Largest Chinatown in United States. 

Yup, I don't need to elaborate. Let it be my shortest review. You've heard from 400+ other reviewers talking about San Francisco's Chinatown.
author: Lou C.

description:
No visit to San Francisco is complete without a visit to Chinatown.  Entering on Grant Ave and Bush Street you will be greeted by Dragon's Gate.  Along Grant, it can get crowded but there are a number of shops to look for cheap souvenirs.  There's also Golden Gate Bakery but they are closed for now as they are on vacation :( 

I would definitely recommended walking west to Powell and Stockton where the locals tend to shop for BBQ meats, baked goods, and produce.  There are also the alleyways that offer some smaller shops and where you can hear the mah jongers playing.  Down Ross alley is the famous Golden Gate Fortune Cookie Factory.

To the east of Grant in between Washington and Clay is the Portsmouth Square Plaza where you can find washrooms, a playground, and many older Chinese people playing card games for money.

Lots of great restaurants for dim sum, noodles, or get a take out container with hot food for cheap.  The SF City Guides also offers a free walking tour if you are interested in the Associations and Tong of Chinatown.
author: Violet P.

description:
Rain or shine, there is a LiveLiness surrounding SF's Chinatown. Streets are fiLLed with the sound of cars swishing by and horns being honked. SidewaLks are uneven and fiLLed with jam packed crowds of tourist who snap photos as they waLk by.

An abundance of fruits and vegetabLes and freshLy butchered meats are readiLy avaiLabLe. 
WhiLe the kids go crazy for aLL the knickknacks that they can get their hands on.
Bakeries and eateries line aLong each street with goodies to satisfy even the biggest appetite.

I enjoy the rusticity of the buiLdings and their traditions are very intriguing: undergarments hang to dry outside of widows and just a few inches away are homemade sausages curing. Who wouLd have thought?
I've been here a miLLion times and it never seems to get oLd. This is a must whenever we are in the city.
author: Ter L.

description: Awesome! Lots to see! Gave me idea for my wedding decorations! My teddy bear husband went crazy buying souvenirs all over especially the dim sum !
author: Aracely V.

description:
the best china town in california (yeah, california has only 2 chinatown indeed). Keep walking and walking until you exhausting. So many stores that entertain you while you walk. Dont forget to buy san fransisco mark souvenirs, decorations, shirts et cetera. Never worry starving there, so many restaurants are waiting for customers.
If you using public bus, yes they are several buses bring us here ( you need to gather more information about number and what street the bus stop).
If you drive a car, I suggest you to park at portsmouth garage square. Why? $3/ hr. Plenty parking space, up to 4 levels and located right on the chinatown's park.
author: Loena Loeloeh L.

description:
San Francisco's Chinatown, U.S.A. Such a novel feeling being here, a member of the majority, hahahaha!! Just kidding! This review is my perspective as a visitor.

There's the fish, meat, and the many, very fresh, produce vendors. Granted the meat is not freshly killed just hours ago like in the villages inside China, but it'll do. However, some of the fish being sold are still swimming in aerated tubs. Prices for products  vary from vendor to vendor, but generally are better than what you would find at chain supermarkets. 

I won't go into the plethora of shops, bakeries and dining options available. Yelp reviewers have generously made their marks, by business names, for these categories. Local, wonderful Yelp friends have also shared their thoughts about this Chinatown. Edwin R., this IS a "magical" place. Ann S., I am "transported" to a foreign land without leaving U.S. soil.

It was amazingly enjoyable being able to understand the locals' conversations as I walked throughout the neighborhood. I was reminded of a month long visit to my family's ancestral villages near Guangzhou, China, where I was told I spoke like a native. (I think they were being kind to their American-born cousin.) Many staff in shops and restaurants in Chinatown here speak at least a little english but will readily slip into Toisanese or Cantonese Chinese speech dialects if you initiate the conversation. 

Chinese have been historically adaptive and flexible in the US, as are most immigrant groups. The proliferation of Chinatowns in the U.S., at the turn of the century, can attest to that. I am so proud of, and grateful for, the Chinese immigrants before me, who braved incredible hardships to establish this haven of southern Chinese culture. 

NOTE: Additional photos of this incredible Chinatown, including videos and snapshots taken during the March 7, 2015 Chinese New Year Parade, are imbedded in the Yelp business photos section.

PS: Be sure to see the authentic Chinatown gate at Grant Ave. and Bush Street, significant because it was built according to the dictates of traditional entry gate construction in China.

Chinese Historical Society of America:
http://chsa.org/ 

http://www.pbs.org/kqed/chinatown/resourceguide/story.html
author: Shal W.

description: Gotta see the largest China Town outside of Asia.  Typical trinket stores all carry the same stuff, but a fun place to wander around. Lots of restaurants to choose from. It's a fun cultural experience.
author: Douglas F.

description: Authentic, great shops and restaurants, and an awesome location. I love visiting different China towns and San Francisco's version did not disappoint!
author: Juan M.

description:
We have relatives in east bay and do a road trip few times a year, and almost always stay near the financial district due to closeness to the bridge and it's roomy hotels.  This means that we're always within walking distance from Chinatown, and that's alright by me.

Yes, it's crawling with annoying tourists like me, but it's charm never seem to diminish, regardless of the number of times we've walked through.   It's rich with history, colors and smells, distinct to SF Chinatown.  

Missing a star due to underwhelming dim sum.  The rest of SF has fantastic eateries, but if you happen to be hungry when walking through grab a bite at the Hang ah tea room off Pagoda Pl.   

A must walk-through if you're visiting SF.
author: Pat C.

description:
Ah, such love for all the Chinatowns of the US, the "home away from China" for my people. I grew up with my parents taking us to various Chinatown all over the US-but it has probably been 7 years since I have last visited this particular one in SF. I honestly do think it is one of the best in the US, top 3 in my opinion. It's larger than most, and although modernization has occurred over the years and generations have become more Americanized, this little American slice of China remains roughly unchanged. While in town for the weekend I managed to make 3 trips to Chinatown, one to eat lunch (Kam Po), one to browse the shops, and one to stand in a very long line Sunday morning for Chinese bakery goods (Good Mong Kok). Although some may cringe at the smell of dirty streets and sewers and raw fish from the markets, this is an environment I am very comfortable in, and love to visit when I am in town.

On an emotional note, my grandmothers have recently passed. Walking the streets of SF Chinatown takes me to a place of my childhood and adolescence when I would do the weekend grocery shopping with my popo in Honolulu's Chinatown, and I have been to the SF one with her as well. This bit of nostalgia takes me right back to when they were here with me, and for that, I am entirely thankful. I hope it never changes and modernizes here, and many other families can create fond memories here.
author: Lianna N.

description:
This place is wonderful. 

There are so many places where to go and buy cheap clothes. 

I went early in the morning and it was a bummer because not many places were open at that time. 

There were not many places that offered food, just a lot of clothing stores and crafts to buy.
author: Jannie M.

description:
I believe anyone who visits San Francisco (particularly the first time) absolutely must make a trip to the famous Chinatown. At least make your way to the entrance gates and snap a pic for your digital photo album. 

If you've ever been to Chinatown in other major U.S. cities (e.g., New York, Chicago) it's about the same, so you kind of know what to expect. SF's Chinatown reportedly houses the largest Chinese population outside of China so it is much larger, the streets are crowded with tourists and locals, and there are tons and tons of shops that pretty much all carry the same items; however, prices do vary vastly. Whether you're looking for higher end sculptures or simple little imported trinkets such as Jade rings or fans, I suggest visiting the Bargain Bazaar located at 667 Grant Ave between Sacramento St & California St (corner store). They offer way better prices than stores right next door or across the street and have 3 full levels of goods to choose from. 

As would be expected, SF's Chinatown also has many authentic Chinese dining options from somewhat upscale and $$$ (e.g., try the famous Fried Crab at R&G) to some quick, and inexpensive Dim Sum at $ (e.g., Yummy Dim Sum). If you want the most authentic Chinese food at the best price, walk a street or two above the main drag...just be forewarned that the people in these establishments may not speak English well, but most do have English menus.  

Lastly, take advantage of the many foot message places scattered throughout Chinatown. After walking the soles of your shoes in SF, a good reflexology session will do you wonders and most of the places are super affordable (e.g., for both quality service and fair price I like Lucky Foot Massage / Health Center Massage).  

If you are a tourist and are staying several days, you will probably find yourself visiting Chinatown more than once. If not for the food, than to purchase something for that one person you seemed to have forgotten on you first trip. Wán dé kāixīn!
author: Dawn H.

description:
I've never eaten in Chinatown (too touristy, in my opinion), but I really enjoy walking through here.

Depending where I am going, I use Chinatown streets to avoid some of the major N-S hills. 

And I always feel safe here. From walking through to watch the sun rise from Coit Tower to strolling in the evening, I always feel safe. 

Good for people watching. Good if you want to buy knick knacks. Good if you want a $5 haircut (can't say I have experienced one).
author: Kristin Leigh M.

description: You can't find this kind of culture still stocked with tradition in any small towns.  I am so glad I got to participate in this area.  I want to come back another time to really get a better sense of what it has to offer.  The food and people make you feel like you are in a different country.  Yes, they sell a lot of trinkets/junk but I think I would find the same in China.  I love how hard they must work to keep this from getting Americanized.  And they really have made it stay that way for a long time.  I hope they always will.
author: Ryan H.

description:
This is the largest Chinatown outside of Asia. If you're walking from Union Square, don't miss the Chinatown gateway entrance with the lion statues. If you're a literature buff, Joy Luck Club was set here, so you can see many of the sights mentioned in the book.

Be sure to wander deep into Chinatown and off of Grant Avenue for the more authentic Chinatown experience, away from the majority of tourists, the knick knack shops, and pushy menu-pushers. 

Here you'll find beautiful street art and murals, delicious Chinese bakeries (be sure to take a dim sum crawl, stopping in various bakeries for a cheap lunch), ample restaurants, loose leaf tea shops, boba shops, and a plethora of produce and meat/fish stands. Here's an area where locals come to shop, tourists come to gawk, and everyone comes for the hustle and bustle and lively atmosphere. 

Don't miss the Portsmouth Square Park to see the local elders playing various games like mahjong very seriously. Also, be sure to poke into the Golden Gate Fortune Cookie Factory to see fortune cookies being made. 

Chinatown is easily one of my favorite places to walk around in the city. Sure, it can be a bit dirty and smelly (but not unlike plenty of other areas of the city -- albeit just different smells), and you might have to abruptly step into traffic if you're pushed and shoved on the busy sidewalk, but there's always things to look at, tempting food to buy, and a fun and lively atmosphere.
author: Rebecca G.

description:
Good 'ol SF's Chinatown, how it reminds me of home...   

Okay, you got me. Not really, but San Francisco's Chinatown is the home of one of the greatest stories ever told, "Big Trouble in Little China". 

Since I was in town, you know what good 'ol Jack Burton says at a time like this? "What the hell?".  It was time to start walking the streets of Chinatown like I was trying to get the Pork Chop Express back and find David Lo Pan.

Talk about shops, stores, wares, food, hills, hanging lanterns and people for miles. This place is packed and busy on weekends. Tons of stuff that you'd be hard pressed to find anywhere else, especially packed all into one area.  It's pretty cool. It's not glamorous by any means but still worth a stroll through.

Even the some of the buildings are reminiscent of what you'd see in China as far as the overall architecture goes.  I wouldn't go as far as saying it resembles buildings from the long gone "Walled City" but you'll see some structural similarities to some of the living quarters you'd probably find in urban China.

There are shops that sell everything from produce and food, antiques, swords, cutlery, several Asian cultural items, clothing, incense, etc., etc.   Basically everything.

Golden Gate Bakery is here and is a main attraction but pretty much no matter what time you go, it's packed with about a 30+ minute wait.  On a Sunday, I walked past it around noon and it had a long line. After touring town and coming back around 3:00PM, the line was even longer.  If I hadn't been hard-pressed for time I would have waited but I had to skip it.  I hear it's great but I'm not sure I have the patience to wait 30+ minutes for some egg tarts.

I never found David Lo Pan, The Pork Chop Express or my Asian Girl with Green Eyes but Chinatown is not a place to be missed when you're in SF.  It's just one of those experiences that you just have to indulge in.
author: Jeff S.

description:
Such a cool area in San Francisco!
Very fun place to visit, great photo ops, you instantly feel like you are in a different county.
Tons of people, this is the busiest area in town and finding parking can be tough though they do have a few lots that charge about $10 a day.
Very unique shops, tons of places to get souveniers, prices are great and you can haggle to get the best deal.
One of my favorite places during our visit, a must see while in the area!
author: Nijole T.

description: Chinatown is a wonderful and immersive experience that makes you feel like you're really in China. It's beautiful and the stores seem to be reasonably priced.
author: Katie H.

description:
So much fun here! There's a ton of shops: the usual tourist stuff, antiques, groceries, bakeries, and very **very** good restaurants. I had delicious lotus root stir fry, baked banh bao, salted plums, and some kind of mooncake. Hello, Chinatown! Goodbye, waistline!  

The only downside to Chinatown is that it's easy to get lost, so make sure you have Mapquest on your phone. Also, it was difficult to order at a lot of places because the menus were entirely in Chinese. Man, I basically took a crapshoot every time I ordered lol But everything was so good, and very reasonabley priced.  

So if you have a couple of hours to shop and get lunch I recommend checking out Chinatown.
author: Iron Man H.

description:
You gotta love china town sf I feel like the start of china town is at the dragon gate on bush street.

you walk past the dragon gate and keep straight up on grant avenue. There are tons of gift shops where you can get all types of souvenirs like snow globes, fridge magnets, keychains, picture frames, San Francisco t-shirts and caps, not to mention you can also find oriental gifts like fancy chop sticks, tea pots, baoding balls, my favorite place for souvenirs is at a shop called heart of Shanghai The shop is pretty big and you can find pretty much everything that your looking for as far as gifts.

There are plenty of spots to eat you can get some good duck over at new golden daisy cheap but primo good or get some  sushi Over at sushi boat restaurant gotta love the floating boats that carries the different types of sushi , Or you can get some good Chinese food over at snow garden which is my favorite place to stop in and eat they have some awesome tasting egg rolls & killer egg drop soup.

You can also get a nice full body massage or foot massage pretty much anywhere around Chinatown.  If your riding the historic cars up or down California ave. you can stop on grant to walk up and down Chinatown but I recommend buying a 1 day muni pass  that you can use for the whole day to hop on and hop off the cable cars because they are 6$ for every time you get on.

Chinatown is one of my favorite places in San Francisco, it doesn't matter how many times I've visit this city I always walk threw China town for some good eats and gifts.

Note: If you plan to take photos in front of the dragon gate be careful because there is threw traffic that passes up the gate, if traffic is clear of site then your free to take photos.
author: Edwin R.

description:
It's truly a sensory immersion in SF's Chinatown. Throughout the journey, hear the abacus beads clicking, catch a whiff of incense burning (I dare you to dismiss the allure of savory foods cooking). You can't miss the buildings' flaring pagodas and waving flags. You may even come across the two stone lions at Chinatown Gate.

Make sure to make your way towards Grant Avenue. This strip is full of souvenir and antique shops, herbalists, masseuses, acupuncturists and folks, young and old, who gawk right back at you. You will surely find treasures on Grant! You can sample a moon cake at Golden Gate Bakery. Only reason to pass on the moon cake is if you've had too many snacks along the way already. ;P

If you want to hang like the locals, visit Stockton Street. Try an exotic fruit, witness the wide array of dried mushrooms, peruse through the exotic spices and gaze at the assortment of sea creatures ready to be cooked and devoured. 

Tip: Saturdays are the most crowded when locals swarm the hood with tourists.
author: M E.

description: SF's Chinatown is definitely worth a visit. The murals I think are the highlight. People always say it's better than NYC's Chinatown because it's cleaner and bigger (It's really not bigger anymore - NYC's Chinatown is growing every day!). And it's true, it is cleaner, but I feel like it doesn't have the grittiness and authenticity of NYC's Chinatown - which may be blasphemous to say given that SF's Chinatown is the oldest. And there's always the Columbus Park vibe in NYC's Chinatown. I also find that the food is a lot better in NYC as well.
author: Judy S.

description: Chinatown is a fun place to spend a day or two exploring - especially as a tourist. I like to stop here for a bit on trips to San Francisco and check out what is inside the shops and maybe grab a bite to eat at a restaurant. The shops aren't the best stuff - but definitely still pretty cool to shop in. Also not bad for getting some cheap bubble tea.
author: Carlos H.

description: So I really just passed through.... I was going to stop and eat at one of the shops, but I couldn't find anywhere to park... and it was SUPER busy! But it was a very pretty site. I hope that when I go back I'll find somewhere to park ( I know I should have Uber'd) so that I can walk around and take some pictures.
author: Stephanie K.

description:
I was a sucker for places like Chinatown when I was a kid, so it was very educational to prowl around the place with my then-eleven-year-old niece, who was at a similar sucker-for-places-like-Chinatown age.  We were looking for a Buddha for her bedroom, and we finally found one that wasn't too big or expensive, after going into a bunch of those ridiculous high-end-crystal stores.  I quite enjoyed the experience, actually, because each saleswoman truly believed that I would purchase for my niece some tacky $2500 end table and have it shipped down to Southern California.

The hills are killer, but what I really want to explore are the tunnels.  I'm afraid, though, that I would just get sad about all the stuff I would see.  Chinatown's kinda like that:  You want to see it even though you really don't.  The alleys are all really neat, although there are way too many non-homeless middle-aged men peeing in public for no good reason.

Italian food is always good in Chinatown.  Chinese food is usually good in Chinatown.  Chinese restaurants never disappoint in Chinatown--even when they're disappointing, you can always tell they will be, plus someone is always rude to you for no good reason.  After those two hours last year and a previous two hours in 2003, I'm tired of looking for trinkets, although maybe this is maybe the only place in San Francisco you can't complain about cheap plastic crap from China.

I can't believe my friend Esther still wears those sandals.
author: John S.

description: Super busy, fun to walk around, changing with the city may not be a good thing, memories of firecrackers and parading dragons in the street, early morning fish markets. Tons of food options and many many more trinket shops. Bargaining here is custom. Have to park and walk around to enjoy.
author: Lindsay B.

description:
China town is great.  I know its been said before by others but it is true! No trip to San Francisco is complete for me without a visit to....in this case China Town (in SF there are so many places on this list that it is hard to see them all in a visit,  China town is one of the best though).  

I usually enter from the Ornate gate.  Then I come down Grant enjoying all the paper lanterns over head, the shops in buildings designed for tourists. After a few blocks I have had enoph so I jog over to Waverly and see all the temples and Chinese associations,  When that ends I go on to Ross Alley with its darker narrower street.  There I look in on the Golden Gate Cookie Company and sometimes buy something.  

From there I may take a detour into North beach maybe even to Fishermans warf or even beyond taking the trail to the Marina.   My "official walk" though cuts over to Stockton and comes back up through the shoping street the residents use, lined with grocery stores and bakeries, banks all the stuff of everyday life,  then at the top I go into the tunnel and come back to the Union Square area.  

Note, there are few if any benches on my walk,  the return is all uphill.  It can also put a slight strain on your wallet if you arnt careful.

The best time to come is around Chinese New Year,  Yes the parade is great but the time leading up to it is busy in the area with lots to see and do as well.

It is a great walk with a different feel and culture then back home.  I usually come back with some buys.  It is a great area with a facinating history (at least to me, I love history) but that is some research for another time...
author: Mark B.

description:
China town is China town as always...many many shops to bargain. It just interesting to walk around and observe the area. 

The Chinatown Gate is where you enter the Chinese market place and wonder around. If you have to buy lot of touristy souvenir... than this is you place! The architect of some of the buildings is quite nice. If you are looking to eat Chinese, there's alot of authentic places to eat here.

If you go from the main gate its a slight walk upwards, so have comfortable shoes.
author: Bilal S.

description:
Chinatown has a real nostalgic feeling for me. I remember being a little girl tightly holding my Po-Po's hand as she did her food shopping because I was scared to get lost in the huge crowd of tiny old Asian people walking through the streets. I remember plugging my nose whenever we went inside Chinese medicine markets and the smell of ginseng was so overwhelming. Whether you're a tourist, or a local, a lot can be loved about this place.

NOTES:
~ I would actually separate Chinatown in half - there is the tourist-friendly street, Grant, that is a lot more well-kept and more catered to tourists than locals. Here, you'll find souvenir and antique shops, old men playing the er-hu, and more tea-tasting stores than I can count. Stockton street though is where you'll find a much more "raw" Chinatown experience that is catered more towards the locals to the point where you may even struggle to find English speakers here. You'll find a lot more grocers and Chinese medicine shops on this street.

Both these streets of Chinatown definitely have their place and I highly encourage visiting both if you get the chance. If you're not from a Chinese background though, get ready to come out of your comfort zone if you visit Stockton.

---

Since Chinatown is the biggest Chinatown outside of Asia, you'll be hard-pressed to find anything like it in the Western world. It's not only a place great to visit, but it's also rich in history and culture. If the timing is right, try to visit during Chinese New Year and get a taste of what being Chinese is all about!
author: Clarissa Y.

description:
Chinatown is exactly what you think of it. There is Chinese stuff and it's kinda like a small town.
Anyways first thing is first, parking is ABSOLUTELY horrendous but this is the city so it is expected. Your best bet to park is a parking garage and since there is a abundant of garages to choose from, you should park in the cheapest one you can find! I say this because most of the streets is posted with no parking 7AM-6PM or parking only at 8AM-3PM. They WILL tow your car if you are not parked in the correct spots! 
Anyways back to Chinatown! Best place to start is Dragon's gate which is the start of Chinatown!
You have many shops, restaurants and gift shops on this street
Make sure you stop on by some bakeries and grab some Chinese style goods!
Now for the gift shops, they are abundant but some of the items are really cheap as in low quality but that's to be expected. There's one shop where they sell deformed knock off Pokemon so save your money in that store or you'll end up with a giant squirtle head with a mini squirtle body.
Between the numerous shops are murals hidden in alleyways so make sure you look both sides because you will miss some awesome ones! There is a multi colored steps art, tiger art, and dragon art which is the most popular ones. There are several other ones scattered throughout Chinatown.
