It's a really nice place to come and best of all it is walking distance from little Italy so if you want to explored two neighborhoods, it's a plus!
author: Jason H.

description:
Chinatown... feel like HOME!!!

It reminds me so much of places in Asia, love the  open air market, architecture and of course the authentic Chinese food.

Many souvenir shops, bakery, restaurants, etc. So much to see, you can definitely spend hours in Chinatown. 

Don't forget to wear comfortable shoes because you are going to do lots of "cardio" (walking)!
author: Cassandra Y.

description: San Francisco Chinatown is the largest Chinatown outside of Asia as well as the oldest Chinatown in North America. It is one of the top tourist attractions in San Francisco. Set aside a couple of hours and enjoy a unique cultural adventure that you will never forget. It's a great place for little bargain shopping as well as trying out some great noodle dishes. I truly enjoyed it and i would go back!
author: WarmCoffeeHub ..

description: I was in San Francisco Chinatown this past Saturday(1/20/18). I think before going to Chinatown plan your trip right. Bring a jacket if planning to stay for the evening (winter time), bring comfortable walking shoes (some uphill and downhill walking), bring a carrying bags for food or merchandise purchases. think about parking, some parking garages or street parking. I parked in a garage on 170 Columbus Ave, San Francisco, CA 94133 after 3:00 pm $10.00 all day (Saturday) Just off Jackson st.. Nice starting point. easy to find after a long walk. Get a map. Always remember where you parked(important) it can be a maze of streets once you get into the market and business streets.Had a great time in the Dim Sum markets, merchandise stores and bakeries and restaurants and taking in the sites of cultural Chinatown (Plan on at least 3 hours or more). They are getting ready for Chinese new years. I took a cool picture with wall mural painting of Bruce Lee (see pics) on Jack Kerouac Alley and grant ave (Applemeister 1142 Grant Ave,). I am a huge Bruce Lee fan. I like the Dragon's gate Grant Ave and bush St. for the landmark picture. Some streets are well decorated with hanging lamps and buildings with Terra Cotta Soldier statues (see pics). Really had a great day. Start later in the day and stay for the evening night walk. Lots of the street vendors for vegetables and fruits are usually open in the morning and daylight hours. Restrooms in some dim sum markets and restaurants. If you buy something use the restroom. Your day activities depends on what you want to do. Hope this review helps and enjoy!! I Did.
author: Albert J.

description:
There's so much going on here! We enjoyed looking at the different stores and a big plus was that you can get the same souvenirs from Fisherman's Wharf at about half the cost! :-) there are many dim sum places and shops to check out!  

The only thing I didn't like about Chinatown is that every time we'd visit a shop we felt as though we were being watch led like hawks...almost as thought they thought we were going to steal something. But yea it's a great place to check out and take some great photos! 

Gotta love the lanterns strong across the streets.
author: Nasha W.

description:
It's a sketchy hike in this hood my friend, but everything is worth it in the end once you find the fantastic deals on a lot sweet nifty Asian products.

As compared to other Chinatowns I've been through, this one is extremely narrow with some steep ass hills, so you better work those walking shoes if you have any! Parking can be a B-I-T-C-H. Either you park up the hill or find one of those parking places were you pay HELLA money when you can park in one of the lonesome neighborhood streets for FREE.

Be aware that this Chinatown isn't as clean or friendly as the Oakland one. I found a lot of pushy owners trying to direct Brian and I to their business, and once I Yelped them up, it was time to say, "BYE FELICIA!" On the other hand, have your travel sized hand sanitizer, toilet paper and maybe some baby wipes ready in your purse or bag. Usually a lot of the bathrooms don't provide some toilet paper or sometimes run out of soap to cleanse your dirty hands in.

Also, be prepared to bring CASH. A good 99 percent of these stores don't take debit or credit, so be prepared unless you want to pay a two- four dollar fee for using one of the ATMs. 

Nevertheless, this is what I definitely call a tourist trap. It's nice to stroll around here during the day time, but any time after 6 PM, run for the hills and have that pepper spray ready.
author: Aubrey D.

description: Visited San Francisco last month (my former home town) and went for a short walking tour after lunch. Great place to see weird food in the store windows -- along with the usual chicken and ducks.
author: Tim L.

description: Bewitched, bothered and bewildered am I by the sights sounds and smells of the lovely tourist trap and cultural center that is known as San Francisco's Chinatown. I am really too close to it to review it properly so all I can do is salute it, and walk in the street to get anywhere like the rest of the locals.
author: Viv R.

description: Fun place to roam around! This China Town is way bigger than LA's. There is so much to see and shop for. Food is overly abundant! If you come to visit San Fran, it's a must!
author: Camellia P.

description:
Being it my first time in the city, I'm surprised to see such a little town as livid as Chinatown of San Francisco.  It's not the people who walk or work along the streets that I'm talking about-- it's the buildings!  The different structures and designs, along with the kiddy color schemes, are what makes this side of the city captivating (definitely a must-see) for tourists like myself; witnessing a part of China without having to go to the actual country to do so.  

Due to the limited time I had left in Frisco, I only managed to see the face of Chinatown without fully immersing myself to what it had to offer, but I'm intrigued already and there's always next time (it's what I'm saving my 5th star for).  ;D
author: KanDieu ..

description: Mongo like China Town. Mongo go to park and listen to China music. And see many people playing cards and Mahjong on cardboard boxes. Mongo like China food. Mongo eat much. Then Mongo shop much. And Mongo buy many sew-va-neers for family back home.
author: Mongo I.

description: I never get tired of SF Chinatown. I been coming here for years. The one thing I like is buying cheap rubber Nunchucks for the my kids and a few boys that live next to us they get a big kick out of them, I watch them all play ninjago. Most of the shops here sell cheap stuff made in China , but there are stores the got some expensive stuff. As for the food I really have only ate at the empress of China, which has close wish I would have known so I could has seen it one last time, the place was like going in a old school Chinese restaurant. One other thing that is a must is stoping but the golden gate go to bakery for their yummy egg tarts, you  can't miss the place you will see along line. I can't forget about li po cocktail lounge for one of the famous Chinese Mai tai. I've been to China town on LA and that place ain't got nothing on the Chinatown in SF.
author: Dennis T.

description: My first visit to Chinatown! It's cute, busy, and fun-filled, but I didn't realize it was built on a slope. Yikes! I hope to find some time to come back and try the food!
author: Tony A.

description:
My first and lasting impression is that it's noisy and dirty. It's not like the people who live here don't care because they sure do, and there are even noisier parts of the city. 

My main comparison is Chinatown in Oakland, which is very different indeed. Oakland is flat and has wide streets, but San Francisco's feel narrow and of course it's hilly. 

Overall I just have mixed impressions. They are much worse places in the city, and many better (and of course more expensive). And I can't really recommend living next to the cable cars either.
author: Peter N.

description:
There's something magical about San Francisco Chinatown.  No matter how many times I come here, there is always something new to discover.  

SF Chinatown has got to be one of the best "CHINA" town in the world and I've been to many!  Maybe it's because the businesses are tightly packed and the street are not as wide as they are in NY and Los Angeles.  Maybe the little alleys with the local MOM & POPS businesses make it feel more "homey" like that cute little FORTUNE COOKIE FACTORY that's probably been there since the turn of the Century (feels like it anyhow)!   I love that place.  I've been buying my fortune cookies there since I was eight.

The best part about CHINATOWN today is that it has gotten a cool FACE LIFT over the years especially the upgrade of the parking garage off on Kearny Street with the park upstairs for kids to play too -- and the retired residents who vacates this place for Chinese Chess, they are so fun to watch!  How cool is that?  I get a kick coming here early in the morning to buy my congee (Chinese Rice Soup) during a weekend escapade from the Peninsula and I would sip my soup and watch the old ladies exercise their Tai Chi.

Oh BTW - my favorite time of the year to come to CHINATOWN is during their MOON CAKE FESTIVAL.  They block off the surrounding infamous "GRANT STREET" and everyone gets to have a little fun and learn a thing or two about LOVE!
author: Edwin R.

description:
NOT REALIZING WHAT'S IN MY OWN BACKYARD

When I travel around the world I like to go to local spots to interact with the locals. Traveling also gives me an appreciation that there a lot of sites to see that most people in the US don't have the capability to see. As my former boss said there are beautiful things to see in the US especially your own backyard. This week at work a colleague of mine who works at the Seattle office came to San Francisco to help implement new software program. As an appreciation I took her to Chinatown. I've been to Chinatown many times but that was only to grab a quick bite to eat for lunch. I never really explore it.

On Wednesday night after work we walked to Chinatown, which is about five blocks away from my work and is across the street from the hotel my colleague was staying. We walked though the main entrance on Grant Avenue. We explored certain craft stores. My colleague joked when we went inside these arts and crafts store that you want to buy things that are actually made in China. These "Made in China" items do attract tourists but also adds personality as they reflect a cultural identity. This cultural identity is why tourists and locals explore Chinatown. Besides walking on Grant Avenue we walked through small streets such as Spofford Street and Waverly Place. Even though there are restaurants all around Chinatown most of the restaurants that tourists go to are located on Jackson Street. (I had dinner that night in Chinatown at the oldest dim sum restaurant in the country Hang Ah Tea Room).

Since we walked through Chinatown on a Wednesday night the area wasn't packed full of tourists. That was a benefit to us because we could take our time to relax and explore without feeling claustrophobic. As we explored Chinatown I began to have an appreciation that I took granted for. I have been traveling around the world to explore sites that people don't have the opportunity to see that I neglected to realize the sites that are in my own backyard that tourists come to visit. Chinatown is one of those sites. As I walked through Chinatown I began to realize why it's considered the biggest Chinese community outside of Asia. It is one thing to read history, but it's another thing experience history. Exploring Chinatown you get to walk and see the oldest Chinatown in North America. Certain streets such as Spofford Street and Waverly Place have charm because they feel old as if you were walking in the 1850s or 1880s. 

Since I work in San Francisco I have an appreciation how tourists come to visit to see and explore sites. However I never took the opportunity to explore certain sites such as Chinatown. It took an outsider to come to San Francisco for me to go to Chinatown. Thank you Lauren for not only coming to San Francisco implement the new software at work but also making me appreciate that there are great places to see in my own backyard.
author: Gerald R.

description: Many disrespect rude people Asian and white people loves to be rude, disrespectful, harass, hassle you on purpose need to mind their own business permanently.
author: Lorrie T.

description: San Fransisco's Famous Chinatown. Enough said, a must see. Explore all the Streets, try different restaurants as there are so many types of food from different provinces, take in the history of all it has to give.
author: Melody K.

description:
People often make San Franciscos Chinatown sound super great, but it was actually pretty basic to me. Every store sells the same thing - Jade, postcards and tacky t-shirts. Oh, and every store is having a "Retirement Sale - Closing after 30 years of business." Did everyone decide at the same time they were going to retire? Ha...

I didn't think it was all that great.
author: Madison G.

description:
I love Chinatown! It's crazy how you can feel like you're in a completely different place just from taking one step into this area. Right away, you're hit with the Chinese culture - old Chinese men playing mahjong, small "made in China" stores, a billion bakeries, and lanterns strewn across the street. I come here all the time, and the sight never ceases to amaze me. 

It can be difficult to find parking, so I would suggest finding a space in the surrounding streets. It's a short walk to Chinatown, give or take a hill or two.
author: Lauren V.

description: Fore warning, parking is MISERABLE in Chinatown. They honestly should rename it Little Shanghai. But the experience was awesome, definitely check it out!
author: Maxwell M.

description:
I've been to few Chinatowns across the country, mostly spending time in Philadelphia's Chinatown.

This is only different in the vertical orientation--that is, all the climbing to get to where you're going.

You have the gate and the touristy gift shops behind the gate.  When you stray from the tourists' path, you find the hair salons, housewares, and markets that make typical life work.

If you're lucky, you find that side street where the local people eat.  I find it amusing that I don't have to struggle with Chinese language in Chinatown, but in Fremont.
author: Nobuyuki S.

description: Interesting, cool and fun. Chinatown lives up to its name with door to door markets and restaurants. What I loved about it was the authenticity and vibe the town gives off. If you're visiting the San Fran area it's definitely worth stopping and exploring. The markets are extremely affordable selling anything and everything from toys, home goods, clothes, fresh produce and of course Chinese food. Loved visiting and definitely recommend.
author: Alicia S.

description: I had always wanted to go see Chinatown and I am so happy that I had the opportunity. The shops are amazing- there are many places to pick up different items and the overall experience is memorable. Walking through Chinatown allows you to escape from other busy streets and into magic.
author: Robyn Y.

description:
Bottom Line:  Chinatown is a must see for visitors to San Francisco but the best way to experience Chinatown is through a walking tour.  If you think Chinatown is just junk for sale, then I think you've missed the boat.

Consider this:

If you stroll through Chinatown you can snap a selfie in front of the Chinatown gate, admire the ornate Chinese lanterns overhead and marvel at many touristy shops selling stuff from China.  That can be an entertaining experience, but, consider this . . .

If you take a guided walking tour of Chinatown you will travel back to the 1850s and learn how Chinatown came to be what it is today.  You'll gain an appreciation for the discrimination Chinese immigrants encountered in San Francisco and how they transcended racism to thrive in this unique neighborhood.  Your tour will take you off the beaten path where you will be mesmerized by pagoda-style architecture and perhaps dazzled by a tea or dim sum tasting.  But Chinatown is not all about colorful produce and vibrant art, so you will also learn about the opium related crime that plagued this neighborhood in the 1970s. Although all tours vary, you will probably stroll down Ross Alley for a fun photo op at the Fortune Cookie Factory.  

If you take a guided walking tour of Chinatown, instead of just departing Chinatown with some cheap souvenirs, you will leave with a deeper understanding and appreciation of this sub-culture.  I've been to Chinatown many times and it's most certainly the walking tour that made this a five star experience for me.  

Here is some additional information about Chinatown that I hope you will find helpful:

- My favorite souvenir shop in this neighborhood is Canton Bazaar.  They have two floors of goodies.  Be sure to check in on Yelp for a discount or to just negotiate prices anyway.  I spend so much time in this store that I usually have to take a bathroom break -ask for the key, the restroom is downstairs.  In addition to souvenirs, they have some great gifts and practical items too.  I am loving my new authentic chopsticks for Asian dinners at my house. 
 
- I also love the Fortune Cookie Factory on Ross Alley.  They do ask for a small donation ($0.25 I think) for photos and in exchange the gentlemen will smile in the background of your photo and give you a fortune cookie.   It can be a little tricky to find but definitely worth it.

- If you love to cook or are a foodie, you will be fascinated by the produce stores.  Yes, they sell things other than bok choy!

- Vegetarians might be horrified by naked ducks hanging in the storefront windows and live turtles swimming in tanks.  If you know which back door to knock on and speak Cantonese, you may be able to find some abalone or other interesting cuisine.  Wink.

- My Chinese-American friend that lives in SF says the best Chinese food is actually near Golden Gate Park, not in Chinatown.  But, if you're not wanting to venture to that part of town, I can attest that I've had some yummy food in very authentic restaurants in Chinatown.

-If you are lucky, a musician or two may be out on the street playing traditional Chinese instruments.  

- Several companies offer walking tours.  Some might focus more on food or architecture but many hit all subjects at a high level.  Check Google or Yelp to find the perfect tour for you.
author: Courtney K.

description:
San Francisco's Chinatown is the oldest Chinatown in North America.  It's located near the city's downtown Financial District and covers over 20 hilly blocks.  Along with the Financial District, other surrounding neighborhoods include North Beach, Telegraph Hill, and Russian Hill.

Chinatown is mostly a tourist destination.  So, expect tourist traps in the form of restaurants and gift shops you'll come across.  Sure, you can find some decent Chinese food, markets, bakeries, and the like here, but you can find better versions elsewhere in the city and in the Bay Area in general.  If you're looking specifically for a neighborhood with good, authentic Chinese food, I recommend Clement Street in the Richmond District.  That's where you'll find the locals and not the tourists.

Chinatown is fun to walk around and explore.  The main gate is located at the intersection of Grant Ave. and Bush St. (the address for this business listing).  Grant Ave. is one of two major thoroughfares in Chinatown.  Stockton St. is the other.  Grant is more touristy than Stockton.  All over the neighborhood, you'll see old buildings with traditional Chinese architecture.  It's what gives Chinatown most of its character.

If you plan to drive to Chinatown, you can park in the garage located at Portsmouth Square.  Portsmouth Square is a small public park and often contains Chinese folks practicing tai chi and old men playing Chinese chess.  The square is also connected to the Hilton, which houses the Chinese Culture Center of San Francisco.
author: Daniel B.

description:
I'm a big nerd actually when it comes to vacations and will read up ad nauseam on the place I'm going to before hand so I'm appropriately prepared to drive my traveling companion *&//ing nuts with my comments on where we go. 
Chinatown held some sort of mystique for me and it is pretty interesting. The largest chinatown outside of asia, oldest in the country. However, once you get there its a lot of stores selling costume jewelry, lucky white cats, pillows and knockoff bags/scarves etc. It all sorta blends together after awhile. I meant to buy some of their big strands of pearls but kind of got sick of seeing them in every store
The food was reliably good and cheap. The people were friendly. I liked staying close to this part of town.
author: Lisa A.

description: Totally in love with this place. I would definitely love to come here more often and try all of the eateries and knock off shops that seemed to be squeezed on every corner. And the alleys....Like a place out of a book. Gentlemen smoking long opium pipes and the sound of people "washing dishes" filled the night air as if it was telling an ancient secret of tradition. Amazing place.
author: Saeed R.

description:
San Francisco has the largest Chinatown outside of Asia. It feels exponentially bigger because it is on a lot of hills. The famous gate is at the intersection of Grant Ave & Bush St. When it comes to Chinatown, my thought is that you need to know locals who can tell you where the great holes in the walls are located. Yelp ratings fail me for Chinese food. Unfortunately, I did not know any locals who could give me recommendations. I did try a 4 star rated hole in the wall on Yelp, Delicious Dim Sum (752 Jackson St). It was decent and really cheap. If you go to Chinatown, I would recommend walking into hole in the walls and bakeries where you can see the food before ordering. They are also usually cheaper than sit down restaurants. You will find a lot of them as you walk around Chinatown.

If you are visiting San Francisco and looking for recommendations, feel free to message me through Yelp and I can share my itinerary, which includes my Yelp reviews. The information for an electronic copy can also be found via my Yelp profile.
author: Patrick W.

description: So glad we walked through Chinatown! Had dinner at R&G Lounge (I will make a separate review for them!). Walked to the Dragon's Gate at Grant & Bush Streets. I wanted to time it perfectly while I was shopping for my usual kitschy knickknacks. Walking north on Grant is here you'll see the latterns lit at night! Great Photo Opp! Our last stop on our walking tour was to Buddha Bar! There's even Zoltar at the sidewalk of one of the shops! Get your fortune!
author: Joanne P.

description:
It's fun, and worth visiting once as a tourist, however the whole place could use a serious  pressure wash. 
I'm guessing the lighting at night is very nice, however we were there during the day so we missed that. 
Spent $60 on lunch for the four of us, which included one beer (only). The food was .. "meh." Somewhat flavorless.  Can't remember what the place was called. Sorry.
author: T T.

description:
Very overrated. You'll literally find store after store that hold the EXACT same trinkets and goods (makes me wonder if they all restock from the same supplier). After half a block, I was so bored. At a glance this place looks very interesting and colorful, but in reality its crowded, dirty and smelly (see photo). 

I expected this place to be a lot more authentic...not a beat up street that desperately caters to tourists. I can tell at one point there was an attempt to memorialize the Chinese history in SF, but the parks/statues/signs are now all littered and graffitied.
author: Clare S.

description: San Francisco's Chinatown has to be the best Chinatown I've ever been to. It's like you transported to China lol! So many stores with cheap prices for souvenirs and other Chinese products. A plethora of restaurants (although I didn't get the chance to dine in any.) As well as a street dedicated to selling produce and meat (can be pretty busy and packed)! Highly recommend on going here to get cheap prices for souvenirs if you're visiting San Francisco. Got a hoodie for 10$!! A must-go on your list on what-to-do in San Fran. (:
author: Jordan L.

description: Don't get me wrong, Chinatown is a fun place to walk around. Just take a jewelry store along with a Chinese restaurant and multiply them by 100 and you have Chinatown mostly. Cheap clothes and bring cash!
author: Alain T.

description:
ehhh. It was okay. Just okay...

I was really looking forward to check out the infamous San Francisco Chinatown. This was actually one of the first tourist locations we headed off to shortly after arriving in SF.

It is freaking HUGE! Tons of stores, shops, restaurants, etc everywhere. It was fun to walk around and just check things out for a while. 

Until you realize its all about quantity here, not quality. The stores and souveneers available down here are nothing more than cheaply made trinkets...crap, really. Sorry, but its just the truth.

They have so many restaurants, yet not one of them sounded overly enticing. Than there was the fleecing we endured at the Chinatown Restaurant(see review). We did happen to find a cafeteria style place that wasn't too bad at all(I just wish I remembered the name of the place). 

Point is, we just kept running into disappointments...and it doesn't end there..

As we were walking down the street, a car appears out of nowhere flying like a bat out of hell, hit 2 people and slid into 3 parked vehicles before the driver jumps out of the car and runs like he's being chased by someone...very effing surreal...check out the pics.....no joke...we were just like...W...T....F??

It was something I always wanted to checckout, and now that that is done...I will not be back...I want to live!


2 stars
author: Mike F.

description:
Mexicans to LA are like Chinese to the bay in terms of the majority ethnic group.  You are probably in agreement if you are familiar with both cities.  They are the largest ethnic group in San Francisco.  San Francisco's Chinatown is the largest Chinatown outside of Asia and the oldest in North America.  The Chinese have been living in San Francisco since the 1800s.

San Francisco Chinatown covers 24 blocks and 5 zip codes.  In distance it is 1 mile long and 1.34 miles wide.  Like other Chinatowns throughout the world, it is full of herbal shops, tea shops, restaurants, souvenir stores and that is just scratching the surface.

You could find me in San Francisco Chinatown on a dim sum run or just to order some good traditional Chinese food.  After all, I am a quarter Chinese and there's no better way to honor that than in San Francisco.
author: Cheryl S.

description:
Pros: big, great variety of shops, very good bakeries/food, lively with people 

Cons: lack of plazas and/or courtyards, hilly or steep

My favorite Chinatown by far. There are a lot of shops and the area is highly decorated with traditional Chinese lanterns, decorations, etc. The buildings are traditional looking and beautiful. It seems to have a real community thriving here versus the ones in LA and Chicago. Subsequently, it's common to see a lot of people and tourists walking around which gives it a lively feel. I would recommend seeing this Chinatown, but try to go in the morning or early day since this area tends to get very chilly and cold after 5 p.m. due to the ocean breeze. For parking, you will probably have to park a few blocks away in an actual parking garage in  downtown then walk to it but it's not too far so it's not bad.  Definitely worth checking out!
author: Hu L.

description: Great place to check out. It was too crowded for people to walk through but over all its a great place to look around. Although it is pretty pricey if you are thinking about buying stuff.
author: ChrisLeni D.

description:
When it come to Chinatowns in America, San Francisco's is the oldest. Whether its the largest (or even the best) seems up for a coastal debate, but it still gets a thumbs up from yours truly for pioneering and persevering an ethnic enclave known to all around the world.

It's not as widespread as LA, as pathetic as Portland's, or as gritty as any of NYC's Chinatowns, but it definitely has its own charm. There is a mix of young and old, with colorful murals that illustrate the old days of railroad hardship and colonial ties. A majority of the many Chinese locals here are Cantonese speaking, and there are plenty of elderly folks walking the streets, hitting up the markets and manning the divey shops.

It must be me, but in terms of eats I've yet to find anything outside of Golden Gate Bakery to entice me to come here more often. The Canto contingent has been more concentrated in the Richmond area and regional Chinese spots seem scarce. Something tells me Ar-Yi and Ar-Po are busy cooking their market veggies and meats at home, unless they're just settling for mediocre Dim Sum and noodle joints.

Like all large Chinatowns there is no shortage of touristy businesses aimed at providing an gimmicky experience, as opposed to cultivating and maintaing authenticity. It is by all accounts, a ghetto space that turns into a ghost town after 8pm.

In spite of all of this, I still make an effort to explore Chinatown whenever I'm back. Most of my friends in the area tell me I'm wasting my time, but I can't help but wonder if i'm missing something good that I can't get back in NYC. Hence, for now, the nation's most famous C-Town gets 3 big stars.
author: Jando S.

description:
I loved Chinatown. Not only is the entrance beautiful, but it honestly doesn't feel like you're in San Fran once you walk through the gates. There are tons of people milling around, going to work, shopping, going to school... and of course us tourists. 
Like San Fran, the place is very hilly. I was worn out and out of breath by the time I made it to the top of the hills, but the views are amazing if you can make it. There are lots of shops, restaurants, and alleys with more shops and restaurants. I was by myself and didn't have a guide, so the next time I think I'll take a guided tour of the place. 
Most placed take cash only, so be prepared. There are lots of banks around, so if you're like me and hate paying ATM fees, walk a few blocks until you see your bank.
author: Melinda R.

description: Slightly, only slightly better than New York's Chinatown (and I'm saying that as a New Yorker).  We had a great time exploring this neighborhood rich in Chinese culture.  Roam the hilly streets for some cool souvenirs or seek out a great authentic Chinese restaurant.  I say it's better (slightly) then NYC because the restaurants don't seem to cater to just tourists so you'll get some pretty great Chinese food here.
author: Anthony G.

description: Good place to tour.  It's swarm of people walking on the sidewalks. The park is also crowded with Chinese folks. They were doing some kind of dance and singing. A lot of pigeons on the streets. Mostly find them everywhere.  Beneath the park is an parking area which I thought is unique. There's all sorts of shops to look and restaurants around.
author: Anonymous U.

description: I came here to try some dim sum (thanks to Yelp.)  It was fun walking around... although it was super crowded.  It was interesting to see how lively it was, especially on Stockton.. it was kinda weird seeing fish everywhere.  Is that really clean?  Some places looked iffy.  But the places I tried were decent.  There are many different stores to check out.  Lots of Chinese food to eat and things to see in Chinatown! Worth a visit if you're close by.  I enjoyed San Francisco's Chinatown for what it is.
author: Betty H.

description:
My visit to Chinatown was surprisingly quiet, but it was nice to visit.

The area is 1 mile by 1 mile, with more Chinese culture packed in than anywhere else in the world outside of China.  Thus, I was expecting a full-on culture attack.  However, I don't know if it was because we were visiting in December during a rainy week or what, but not much at all was going on. It was really quiet.

The dragon gate was beautiful, along with a lot of the other architecture.  We visited one restaurant which was just OK and not the heavenly food we were expecting, but it was cheap with kind service so no complaints.
author: Sheri C.

description: They say that this is the largest Chinatown outside of China.  I've been in the one in Toronto and Yokohama Japan.  I think they are bigger.  But, this one is huge.  Go beyond the Chinatown Gate and you will find yourself outside of the U.S.  It feels like you're in China.  All Chinese signs.  Many merchants cannot speak English or at least proper English.  At times, you feel like you're in the movie, Groundhog Day, because each blocks looks the same with the same type of stores and same type of restaurants.  But you ain't.  There is so much to explore here.  It is crowded due to its popularity.  Even with that, you'll be glad you came and explored.
author: Darrell K.

description: Man this was a true experience! So awesome! We ate the most delicious dim sum on a dirty street corner, shopped at stores where no one spoke English and found some truly wonderful treasures that you cannot find anywhere else. It was such a pleasure exploring China town. Have fun! It's totally worth the experience!
author: Eva B.

description:
Ni hao, Chinatown!

I've always dreamt of traveling outside these US borders, to a place where I can find exotic food, culture, people, and unique items.

Little did I know, it was right underneath my nose. Who woulda thunk it!

San Francisco's Chinatown is the oldest and largest Chinatown outside of China, in North America.

Well, I'll be darned! 

While Chinese immigrants are drawn to this location because of the familiarity with culture and affordable housing, even more so are the foreign tourists and outside visitors that come to this fast paced community, visiting here at this Chinatown more than San Francisco's very own Golden Gate Bridge! A true phenomenon, indeed!

The air permeates of Chinese BBQ'd meats, the decoration of brightly colored lanterns, the collective sound of Cantonese chatter, the wide open markets filled with unfamiliar roots, herbs, and vegetables, not to mention the old Chinese men who gather in one spot who spectate a rival of some sort of chess game; this here already qualifies it as a place all on its own.

I, for one, have found great richness in the culture of Chinatown here in San Francisco. The people are functioning as it were in their homeland and it's truly a marvel to see. 

Oh, and I can't discount the fact that everything is uber cheap here. As a fellow Asian, I love a deal whenever I can get one!

A wonderful place to visit if you decide to tour! An absolute, true historical landmark here in this city!
author: Ann S.

description:
Came here to try the famous egg tart from Golden Gate bakery but found out they were closed for Easter. Decided to walk around with no agenda to see what else was out there, not too impressed by the appearance of the town as it seemed a bit dirty. 

Saw the exact same souvenirs in at least 4 different stores- talk about lack of originality. Ten minutes into my exploration I decided to stop by Brandy Ho's and get some dumplings - yum! (Definitely the highlight of my visit.) Not too sure if I'll be revisiting this area again but who knows, maybe in the future I'll give it another try.
author: Sarita P.

description:
Chinatown Restaurant 
744 Washington St
San Francisco, CA 94108 

What a nightmare! Dirty water, dirty dishes, food position small (not family style), bad serves, etc. Beware the coupon lady, run the other direction. Please eat somewhere else. 

My family still talk about how awful the place to eat!! They add all these surcharges and God know what on the check. They can't accommodate a big group.
author: Ann Marie A.

description: WOW! What a culture shock walking through Chinatown! It is true that this is a huge, and I mean huuuuge Chinatown. Everything is authentic Chinese and most of the people that own the shops don't even speak English. I really want to visit the country of China one day because of its rich history and culture. Walking through Chinatown in San Francisco really validated that interest. The food is amazing in San Francisco in general, but when you want some good Chinese food, you have to come to the source. You can also get pretty much anything you want in one of the shops, and you can even bargain with the owners. Being from San Diego, I have visited LA's Chinatown a few times and it has absolutely no comparison to San Fran's... another plus added to the grade of the great city of San Francisco in my book.
author: Melvin M.

description: well, where to start. Walking through Dragon Gate is nice or under Stockton bridge, which is supposed to be on of "the things". Anyway Chinatown is pretty especially in the evening, when shops and lamps on streets are glowing and pace is slowing down. It reminds me a bit of Chinatowns in Kuala Lumpur, but not exactly there. Definitely worth talking a walk to, especially that it is next to Fisherman"s Wharf and Coit Tower (I mean American "next to", not European ;) ).
author: Filip C.

description:
Nothing but joy and fun and original artworks all over the place. Don't get jipped by their fast talking sales guy and always bargain for the higher priced items. They'd rather sell them have em sit and collect dust.

Lots of bakery and tea shops to grab a milk tea (no bobas, please) and a piece of cake. DO: buy interesting souvenirs. Something useful, like the scalp massager. Or a preserved bat.

It's just really fun walking and snacking around here. Best part is that it's so close to union square where we stayed.
author: Helen D.

description:
This is the place to go when there's nothing open on Christmas day! An interesting place you should never miss especially if you are a tourist. As expected there are tons of Asian restaurants, tea shops, souvenier stores, with quality and prices varying significantly. Most are open late, so you're destined to find somewhere to grub. 

Look out for the graffiti art by British artist Bansky (see picture). I recognized it right away while walking around China town.

For more information about Bansky. Click here: http://www.banksy.co.uk/
author: Michael F.

description: this place was a cluster f**k! parking and traffic was a joke! people were rude and don't know what personal space means! very disappointing! i would not visit this nightmare of a town ever again! i would give it a negative star if i could!
author: Chris K.

description:
Being a San Francisco Native, I have practically gotten very used to the ritual of going out to Chinatown every week. This is something I've been doing for the past 24 years. Chinatown is a local flavor for which it is a spot attracting tourists from all around the world to come here. It seems to be more appropriate for the use of public transportation for convenience. There is something to be advised ahead of time, Chinatown can certainly be very crowded and parking is not always easy to find either!

There are plenty of restaurants, bakeries, grocery stores, and banks around here. A line-up of multiple businesses here representing San Francisco's Cultural Diversity. The banks here are listed as follows:

--Wells Fargo Bank (2)
--Bank of America (3)
--JP Morgan Chase (2)
--East West Bank (5)
--Hong Kong & Shanghai Banking Corporation (1)
--Bank of the Orient (1)

MUNI routes 1, 8x, 10, 12, 30, & 45 provide service to and from Chinatown. Routes 10 & 12 now go through Chinatown together, they are also a much better option since they're not as crowded. On the other hand, routes 1, 8x, 30, & 45 are always crowded. These routes are so crowded that is making the operators and passengers very frustrated! This is not even a joke, take 1 of these 4 routes and you'll know exactly what I mean!
author: Bennett W.

description:
Ahhh SF's Chinatown is really fun! I've been to NYC's Chinatown countless times, and this one seems larger and cleaner. Well, cleaner in that I didn't see (or smell) any fresh fish on the sidewalks, so at least it has that going for it.

There are lots of kitschy Asian stores & dim sum restaurants as far as the eye can see. I loved all the hanging lanterns swinging above the street, but I wish they lit up at night! It would have been beautiful. The Chinatown Gate is beautiful, and the facades of the buildings are also kept pretty nicely. It was really cool to see the years they were built, and the old school ornate designs that have been well-preserved.

We stopped in several stores to wander around, and I may or may not have been on a search for pork siopao (which I found!). Also, I highly recommend you waste a couple bucks on the Confucius machine on the sidewalk, because it gives you a fortune and it talks very loudly about you hahah.

Great place to shop, eat, be a tourist, practice photography, and marvel at some of the history of San Francisco. Just wear comfortable shoes, because THOSE HILLS lol.
author: JoAnna D.

description:
I love Chinatown! It seems like the top complaints that other Yelpers seem to have an issue with is: Chinatown is dirty, Chinatown has too many tourists, and the people in Chinatown don't know how to use crosswalks.

First off, Chinatown is dirty. Yes, it freaking stinks, and I'm pretty sure the street cleaners don't come here often because it often smells like dank, garbage, and ass (not mine) With everyone hawking loogies, blowing snot rockets, and dumping unknown substances into the street, then I mean, what do you expect it to smell like? Flowers?! Secondly, yes there are tourists because it IS a tourist spot. If you don't like tourists, then come during the morning time. Thirdly, yes, it's true that people don't know how to use crosswalks. That, my friend, is the reason why you don't drive to Chinatown! There are plenty of other modes of transportation such as BART, MUNI etc and if you MUST drive, there's a nearby parking garage where you can park and conveniently walk to Chinatown.

Other than that, Chinatown is a great place to get lost in for half a day (if you can bare the smell) There are plenty of things to see and great places to eat! You must visit Golden Gate Bakery and get some Dan Tat, visit the Fortune Cookie Company and purchase some yummy fortune cookies, and wander amongst the streets and alleys of good ol' Chinatown. 5 stars for me!
author: Joyce E.

description:
I like anything Asian. Food, lucky cats, everything. This was a fun walk. 

People weren't too friendly, filled with majority tourists. 

However I do believe this is a must see in San Fran. 

I just don't know about any of those divey restaurants....
author: Diesel H.

description:
Oh Chinatown, you & me have a love-hate relationship, but mostly hate, i gotta say...

I never really liked all the times that I had to come to Chinatown. I rarely ever come on my own unless I'm required to. The only times you'll find me in Chinatown is if my parents are visiting me; then they would be the ones who would drag me there. 

Chinatown is full Chinese people, duh. Let you on a little secret...I used to be scared of Asian people. Hahaha.. I'm serious! Growing up in a place where there's no other Asian people other than my family, I'm def not used to seeing Asians. So I used to be scared of Asian people whenever I visited SF back in the days. But now I def do not have the fear anymore since I've been living in the bay area for more than 5yrs now. 

So what can you find in Chinatown... you can find lots of fruits & veggies, bbq items, pastries, clothing, dimsum places, and other random stores. 

Asian Pearl is the main dim sum place that we always frequent whenever we're there. It's alright. Service is so-so to sucky. Then usually we would hit up ABC for dinner. But our last experience there was not that great so I don't really care to go there anymore honestly.

I do however like the decor especially of Grant Street. Very touristy, I know, but that's what makes it beautifully Oriental. I've once done a night photosession here & the pictures came out great since the decor was brightly colored. 

There's like 3 different parking garages: Portsmouth, North Beach, & the other one right across from it. It's rare that you'll find a parking spot on the street plus i wouldn't trust parking on the streets of Chinatown anyways. Who knows what will happen to it or who does what to it? I've seen someone peed near a car once & that's just gross. So yeah, don't be stingy; just pay a few bucks to park in a garage. Much safer for you & your car!

Oh and watch out for silly pedestrians that think they always have the right of way even when the light clearly states that they are NOT meant to get on the walkway to get in front of cars! So definitely pay attention & drive carefully!

So yes, Chinatown and I are definitely not bff or just friends.. I would have to say we're like frenemies. Hahaha!
author: Amy C.

description:
I really love Chinatown.  Yeah, it's touristy!  So WHAT?!  Enjoy it and don't get so caught up in being too cool for touristy stuff.  There is a lot of fun to be had here.  I will give you some tips from a local...me, hello: 

1. Go early...like BE there by 10 am.  

2. Park in a garage...there are several RIGHT there.  We parked in the Sutter Stockton Garage and it's literally right across the street from the entrance.  There's one even closer but I couldn't find it this time around.

3. Stop at one of the bakery-type places and get a sesame ball.  DO it.

4. After burning off your sesame ball, get dim sum.  My personal favorite is the Hang Ah Tea Room.  The service leaves something to be desired, but it's WORTH it.  See my review here: http://www.yelp.com/biz/hang-ah-tea-room-san-francisco#hrid:_sdgWUjkAwWTAhKUILOBXw

5. Buy some souvenirs.  Buy some for friends and family, but buy some for yourself.  You'll appreciate them when you get home!
author: Tara S.

description: On Christmas Day...this is the place to go in San Francisco...most of the stores and restaurants are O P E N...yay!! and lots and lots of people.  It is totally happening place for a holiday (remember Christmas Story the movie? )..so when everything is CLOSED in SF...consider this place =)
author: Jing F.

description: I am not a fan of SF Chinatown. It's a very small town, all they have to eat is mostly just dim sum and not only that, they barely have anything here. There's old people playing cards for money near the elevators from the parking garage and they all smoke. Not only that, they have staring problems. I think I'd prefer japantown. It's more of a mall than walking up and down streets.
author: Nielly M.

description: I've heard this was one of the best Chinatown's in the USA, but I wasn't impressed. It was huge, but there weren't many shops to buy gifts (like the NYC Chinatown), and the sidewalks are crowded and loud. It's also not very safe to be there really late at night. Many of the store's names are written in Chinese, so there is some authenticity.
author: Margaret P.

description: China town is a great place to walk around, especially if you're a tourist. Definitely buy your souvenirs here!! Everything is so cheap. Post cards are like $0.35, magnets and key chains have deals like 4 for $3 or something. So it's something to think about instead of buying it at the airport at ridiculous prices. There are also a lot of beautiful murals you'll walk by. It tends to get crowded but its manageable.
author: Melissa C.

description:
Chinese New Years is around the corner! 

You know what that means?!  Chinatown will be shuffling with many people getting their last minute haircuts, fresh groceries, new money, red envelopes and all the traditions to prepare for the New Lunar Year!

From the firecrackers and the beating of drums, it will be a loud festival going on here!  It will be super crowded as well!

This district is a mixture of tourist catered shops, local restaurant eateries, grocery shops and fully equipped basic essentials' shops for the Chinese community.

Go here if you want to experience a bit of Chinese culture!
author: Tiffany D.

description:
I used to work in the North Beach area and I used to spend a lot of  leisure time in the Marina area and the MUNI bus I rode always passed this area and when the "locals" from chinatown  came inside the bus, manners flew out the window.

They would talk to each other so loud and you're in the middle and their saliva goes straight to your face.
author: Leslie M.

description: A must stop for anyone in San Francisco! So neat! The culture, the shops, restaurants, etc are to be taken all in!
author: Jason T.

description:
What's not to like.

I've been going to China Town SF since the 70's when was smaller. It's grown over the decades. 

There is a tourist area of china town which is shopping and restaurants and there is an area that is business and for locals. Both are neat in their own way.

I can honestly say every time I go to China Town it's populated with greater than 80% Asian people. Lot's of Japanese people in SF these days.

Everyone is always very nice. There are great deals to be had in the shopping.

Let's face it, it's a tourist destination, but it gets 5 stars from me, as there really aren't any China Town's that compete with San Fran's China Town. Yes, there are other nice one's, but this one is still the most unique given it's location, size, and the fact that it still caters to the local and tourist Asian population.
author: Brad K.

description:
All I know of Chinatowns are Houston's and the very periphery of New York's.  So do bear that in mind.  I must say though, San Francisco's Chinatown is out of control.  Like in a good way . . .?

Anyway, it's perfectly navigable on feet, perhaps preferable because the parking situation could end up nightmarish (limited street side parking and overzealous meter maids).  We explored on a weekday, during the early afternoon and it was fairly well-populated with tourists and locals alike.  

So the architecture has a bit of Asian-inspired frills here and there.  Some of the buildings possess that certain element of years of charming wear and tear - don't seem very well-maintained.  They have um "character?"  All the different shops  are surely densely packed with cheap Chinese trinkets and the like, appealing to tourists.  

Of course there is a large concentration of Asian food fare - probably all far more authentic than P.F. Chang's.  If you know Chinese, Vietnamese, etc., it's probably best to bust out with your skills when ordering to avoid possible "surprise dishes."  

We only visited a few of the stores and one restaurant (vegan options are kind of sparse?  Or my Chinese is just teh suck?) because I was more concerned with snapping my touristy shots.  But I would highly suggest at least one visit here if you've never been.
author: Ellen C.

description:
This is an incredible place to check out the Chinese sights in SF. 
The Chinatown Gate lets you know that you are entering a foreign district of San Francisco, and along the streets there are Chinese style lanterns for street lights. It's such a beautiful side of town! 
There are all kinds of interesting shops to check out along Grant Street. They sell cheap tourist stuff to take home with you. However, many of the shops are now owned by Middle Easterners selling incredibly expensive and gaudy stuff for the home. Think things like Dale Chiuly style chandeliers, carved marble Romanesque statues of gods, fountains made of jade, and huge metal frogs to put in your garden. 
Be sure to wear comfortable walking shoes, as this place is on the side of several hills, and there's lots to explore! 
A key part of being in Chinatown is the food! There's lots of authentic places to eat. No, not like the fast food stuff like Pei Wei or Golden Panda or anything, but the real stuff.
author: Curt C.

description:
I MISS COMING here as a Kid!!!!!!!!!!!
GOOD OL' Times!!!!

THIS IS DEFINITELY the tourist part of "chi town" (Pronounced CHEE town) for sure, all the cheapy asian toys, seemed overpriced now. a small SF toy train is $5.00, I did buy 3 for my niece, but I still think it's WAY OVERPRICED!
You know they get it for .50cents

Their "farmers market" OR as we asians call it, the market. haha

have very fresh veggies, and meat.

HOWEVER, My niece, sister and I purchased about 5 sweaters (CALIFORNIA, The City) for about $18 each.
and IF YOU SEE a sweater you like don't shop around, it's the same price at each store, IF ANYTHING only a dollar cheaper.

BUT there is this one store that sells unique styles in the CALIFORNIA hoodie sweater, it had CALIFORNIA FLAG but instead of a regular square border, it had a city background!!
CUTE!!!!!

a regular thin, bruce lee sweater was originally $18.00 and she did me a favor and gave me $1 off.. they charge tax everywhere you go. -_-

I don't remember the OLD china town charging tax or .10cents per bag!!! and without telling you. 

this is the MODERN DAY CHI TOWN for ya'!!!!!!


Parking structure located by Stockton st. Parking prices has definitely increased, it used to be $6 an entire day, now its $12 a day. $3 for an hour I believe. 

OVERALL, It's a good experience, and you need to get out of your comfort zone once in a while and experience Frisco's China town. There's nothing more original!
author: S-Goddess V.

description:
Chinatown is as much as for tourist and locals alike. 

One of the oldest neighborhoods in the city; you may discover something new every time you come here. To some people who've never been to China, this could be the next best thing. It's as close as to traveling to China as you can get. 

There's plenty of good, legit and delicious Chinese Restaurants here as well as Hole-In-The-Walls. And if you want some delicious and delectable pastries, there's plenty of that here too. DVDs from Hong Kong are aplenty; but buyers beware if you know what I mean. Take the walking tour to uncover the many layers of Chinatown. 

When I say layers, I mean it's the kind of layers that goes way back to the beginning. Some of those layers are nice and pleasant while other layers are best to be left alone and not to be touched even by a ten foot pole. There's parts of Chinatown that you stumble upon and in order to be safe, you best believe you have to turn the other cheek. 

Yes, they serve a purpose and they hide in plain site. But that's the way it's always been here in Chinatown for many a generations. It's intriguing, beguiling, romantic, exotic, mysterious and even dangerous at times. But that is what's alluring about Chinatown.
author: John G.

description: Best most magical China town in the world. Just let yourself get lost. Walk into the little rundown shops. The most unexpected places are the most magical. The energy is electric.
author: G M.

description: No visit to San Francisco is ever complete without thoroughly checking out Chinatown.  My only problem with it is that it clearly panders to tourists.  It seems every business here is either a restaurant or some kind of bazaar selling souvenirs and junk.  In comparison to NYC's Chinatown in Manhattan (NYC has more than one "Chinatown"), I realize there's a lot of tourist pandering, too, especially along Canal Street, but I would say that overall the businesses there cater more to locals than tourists.  I also see tourists struggle to communicate with shopkeepers in NYC's Chinatown, however, in San Francisco, all the shopkeepers seem to speak English fluently.
author: Jaszon S.

description:
I've been told that this is the oldest Chinatown in the US, and the largest as well. I believe the first, but I think NY might be close in size too. SF Chinatown also beats LA Chinatown, hand downs. LA's Chinatown seemed completely dead and actually seemed to cater more toward Malaysia, Vietnamese, Thailand...etc, when I visited. 

There are lots of very old architecture here too; like one of the shops we went into was actually a very old, run down theatre, and you couldn't tell unless you looked up at the ceiling and saw the loge balcony. Another was The Empress of China building; it screamed history all over it. I kept on being reminded of the Joy Luck Club wherever I turned.

Because SF Chinatown was probably one of the first to have existed in the states due to imported labor from the first city in China to open up (Hong Kong), it makes perfect sense that it's less Chinatown than it is Cantotown.  

Most of the people here can speak Mandarin, but you will almost exclusively hear Cantonese. It freaked me out at first because I've never been to a concentrated area in America with so many Asians since New York or China, but I heard all different types of dialects. Here, it is almost exclusively Cantonese, and there were even a few situations where people didn't understand Mandarin!

I can see myself buying groceries here if I lived in SF. Prices are cheap, produce is high qual, and it's always nice to grab a cheap snack or some dimsum before running more errands in the city. 

So obviously go for the Cantonese restaurants, esp. the divey ones. They're the ones serving the best food. 

I've heard Grant is the more touristy of the streets, so Stockton might be more authentic (or at least slightly cheaper, because touristy places have a tendency of lower qual at higher prices). 

Hmm....don't go to the Chinese Cultural Center. It's located in the Hilton (or was it something else?) Hotel on the 3rd floor or something like that. Complete waste of time- literally 4-6 pieces of work in a dead floor. 

Most of the shops here have comparable items and prices. One that stood out for me was China Bazaar; goods were very similar, but cheaper, and takes credit cards. 

I would estimate most of the places here are cash only as well. DON'T ever, EVER drive here. You will not find a parking spot, and you will not be able to move. Take the Bart to Union Square and go up from Macy's to inside the tunnel. Once you hit the light you're in.
author: Cindy W.

description: Worst place in China Town ever!!! Food is not fresh at all, and the server is very rude. They don't even provide you clean ice water. At the end, they automatically added 20% tips on your bill without your permission. Avoid the restaurant for your own good.
author: Anna Z.

description: I love this Chinatown I'll definitely be back next time I'm in town. There's lots to do be sure you bring cash a lot of locations charge or don't except ATM or debit cards. Most of the area does open towards the afternoon around 11. Lots of hills and walking be sure to wear comfortable shoes
author: Alexandra Linette S.

description:
Chinatown...definitely an interesting place. I used to live in Chinatown in Honolulu and there really is no comparison. I love walking through the stores and checking out the wares of each store. Last time we went I found a great new Zen Garden for my new office. My daughter has a fun time picking out cool knick knacks too. 

Another favorite place for her is to go to the fortune cookie factory. The husband and I like to go for dim sum as well. All in all a fun experience. 

The Hang ups: Get used to the crowds, lines for the well known dim sum restaurants, homelessness, some interesting characters.
author: Nicole C.

description: We loved Chinatown.  There are so many fun shops for decent priced souvenirs to take home.  The food is amazing.  We stopped into a restaurant called "Chinatown", but am unable to find it on Yelp.  We thought it was so good, that we went back another day!  The area itself is filled with excitement with shops, grocery stores, restaurants and people watching!!!  Don't leave San Francisco without stopping by Chinatown!!!
author: Roseann K.

description: I love China town! It was my first time here and everything looks nice. The walking your is kind of fun since it's an obstacle to go up and down roads, the people and environment is lovely. I just don't like the shops because they are all the same in the products wise. The architect and the authentic Chinese food brings joy!
author: Angel P.

description:
Aw yiss, good food and interesting culture. It is crazy busy at all times though. The food ranges from very Americanized but still slightly more authentic than a Pei Wei to the very traditional stuff that I am not allowed to order because I like Pei Wei.

It's a nice stroll with plenty of interesting and exciting things going on. Definitely worth seeing in person if this is your first time to the city. Or second.
author: Daniel L.

description: We drove though, we couldn't find any parking so we kept driving. It was a ton of people, and seemed as if it was a good idea to keep driving. The streets looked dirty with trash and the sidewalks were packed with people.
author: Tom T.

description: Fun environment a must visit. Also venture in to authentic restaurants and shops for a great experience. Always something new to discover.
author: Frank C.

description: This is the first Chinatown I've ever been to about 15 years ago and I compare every Chinatown I go to to this one. Chinatown SF has a good size, crowded, messy, and dirty. It definitely reminds you of China. Best things here are the stores were you can buy cheap souvenirs, dim sum places, teas, that fortune cookie factory, and those medicinal shops.
author: Juan F.

description: It's a beautiful Sunny & Windy day today in SF Chinatown right now. SF Chinatown it's way better the Chicago & NYC Chinatown.
author: Mychael H.

description:
Do not eat in Chinatown. I was told by locals that the restaurants are notorious for ripping off tourists and it's true. My family and I ordered 3 plates and two bowls of white rice and the check came up to $71! I've never felt so scammed in my life over Chinese food which I know it isn't that expensive at all!!! I learned after from my conversation with my friend that chinatown is a tourist trap. Do not stop at one souvenir shop to buy your souvenirs. Keep walking deeper into Grant St as prices go lower. 

The town itself is interesting and worth a single visit.
author: Lina D.

description: Ultimate tourist trap in the City. As a kid, I used to hate coming to Chinatown because I always thought it was dirty and crowded, and to a certain extent it still is, but I don't come here as much as I used to so it doesn't bother me as much. Nowadays, I come here to buy things I truly need that can only be found in Chinatown, and then I leave immediately after. Parking is horrendous and people will suddenly forget how to drive right as they enter into Chinatown. But if you've never been here before, this is definitely a place to check out while in SF though.
author: Jackie T.

description: Crazy busy, crowded, but excitement in the air on the verge of the Chinese New Year parade in SF.
author: Jason G.

description:
Grant Ave. and Bush St is where it all starts. The famous Dragon Gate, the one Jack Burton drove his rig through in the classic flick Big Trouble in Little China, in 86'. This is the best Chinatown in the US, supposedly you have to go to China to get more authentic. I believe it. It really is an amazing place, it holds the oldest Dim Sum Tea house in America, the Hang Ah Tea Room, the fortune cookie factory. Every time you order Chinese take out and crack open that sweet little cookie to read your fortune, this is where it comes from. Chinese Culture center is an educational and cool place to roam around, it resides in the background of Portsmouth Square, also an amazing place which will have its own review up shortly, it's gonna be a good one, wait for it...!

I don't think I could ever get tired of going to this wonderful place. The mom and pop stores/markets very comparable to those in China, people drying their clothing outside their windows. Every sign posted in English and Chinese. Asian family YMCA, schools, businesses, banks, etc... I will definitely update this review, I'm just having a cluster of thoughts race through my mind right now, faster than Andretti.
author: Steve L.

description: This is one of the best Chinatowns in the entirety of America, and it's always fun to roam around the shops and restaurants, even if you're not looking to buy or eat anything. The shops are authentic, and it's fun to browse the amenities. Be sure to check out the markets for interesting products at cheap prices. And don't be afraid to try out a random restaurant - chances are it'll be delicious!
author: Ally M.

description:
This place is the real deal. A definite Asian cultural enclave with all the coolness that goes with it.

"Dense" is the word with San Francisco Chinatown. SF in general is a dense city, but this place is the epitome of it. The streets are one car wide and there are houses built upon houses. It's kinda like the Asian equivalent of the French Quarter in New Orleans.

There's the general cheapo stores that are so prevalent in LA's Chinatown, but there also so much more, including a lot of legit restaurants and shops. Basically any restaurant there is gonna be run by people who seriously know how to cook. We saw a group of older men playing these odd-looking instruments on the sidewalk, which sounded really neat. There was at least one place where they had people who could write your name on a grain of rice and put it in a water-filled tube on a chain for you to wear. Other places could write your name in beautifully flowing calligraphy on parchment.

Chinatown's also a good place just to walk around and soak it in. I was a little distracted, though, because I kept having scenes from "Chinatown" and "Big Trouble in Little China" playing in my head.

I'll find some way to cleverly incorporate the famous lines from those movies into my review update.
author: Alek Z.

description:
Local Insider Tip: Don't drive. Period. Walk. You can walk all over Chinatown and won't need to worry about remembering where you parked. 

Local Insider Tip: Come at night - many of the businesses that service the residents are closed and the restaurants are open (which means less hustle and bustle on the streets from people doing their daily shopping.) 

Local Insider Tip: Get off of Grant street and go down an alley. Listen for the clink, clink, clink sound coming from the basements. It's the sound of people playing (and gambling) on mahjong. You can hear it all over the place.

Local Insider Tip: Look for mirrors above doors of homes and businesses. They are there to "confuse the spirits."

Local Insider Tip: Go on the Chinatown Ghostwalk Tour to find more about this interesting section of the city.

Local Insider Tip: Don't be afraid to haggle. Be patient. Listen when people talk because most shop keepers speak barely any English.

Fun fact: The term "hooker" was coined here in San Francisco's Chinatown. Cheap (read: busted) "ladies of the night" were in rooms on the 2nd and 3rd stories of brothels and needed a way to get men's attention. They would lower a hook down to grab men's hats off of their heads to get them to come up to their rooms to get their hats back... and for some slut time.
author: Rachel S.

description:
i love coming here a lot. its like I'm home and know where to go and where everything is at just don't ask me how to get to one location to another because i visually memorize it so just follow me and i am glad to take u there hehe. its always a workout in china town i must say. i love coming here to grocery shop because its cheaper than sac and the produce and fruits and everything else is so fresh. if ur a chef or a cook like me this is the place to come here and shop. 

i also like coming here for the pastries, there are so much pastry shops to get your cravings. including egg tarts and curry turnovers, to bbq pork boas. its all amazing how this china town has it all. one of my family favorite bakery shop is golden gate bakery and yes they are amazing with their egg tarts and their curry turn overs. anything else is alright. to my thoughts any place that serve hot fresh food is the best to eat it on the spot. 

i also like coming here to get my boba fix after a exhausting day. some of my favorite affordable boba place i like is quickly which is cheap and good and just satisfy my thirst. i also have discovered cool tea bar too which is very close to quickly maybe only 3 blocks away and their boba is always amazing. speaking of boba its tapioca which is a chewy texture in your drink and as you sip the big fat straw the boba goes in along with your sip of deliciousness drink. the drink could vary to milk tea, tea, or smoothies to milk shakes. 

i also love how china town has a bunch of characters i mean so many elders wandering around and just doing their thing. whether they are walking around, shopping for grocery, or gambling by the park, or just smoking a cigarette, or maybe even visiting with friends at a coffee shop. i think when i am older i would love to move to china town and just wake up in the city and downstairs is filled with fresh ingredients to cook or having some dim sum with my old time friends. i can see myself living in sf chinatown and i really won't mind. 

Parking might be a problem in china town but i always solve it by just not being cheap and park at Portsmouth square garage which is in the hear of china town their parking system is affordable where we only pay 6 dollars for like 2 to 3 hours of parking which wasn't bad at all. i am a fan of this parking lot and saves a bunch of time from wandering around trying to be cheap and look for free or meter parking. i am on the go kind of person so i aint got time for that. 

overall a tip is that if your a foreigner speaking english isn't a problem. i think sometimes speaking in english you get better service than Chinese. when they know you speak Chinese they are so rude in the tones and sound of the voice. but i have experienced where speaking in english they try to charge extra  on the bill when i went to dine at a rest and i was like hold up I'm an accountant so i check my bill every time and asked what the heck is that so they went ahead and fixed it and didn't even say sorry so yea sometimes good and bad. communicating in english shouldn't be a problem because they deal with lots of tourists so ya should be fine.

also i love the location of chine town where it connects to the pier side or union square downtown shopping area. or even little italy which is next to it and serves pizza to pasta which is noms i say. overall china town is my home and how may i help you. thanks for reading and now vote and have a nice day and stay positive and smile and happy yelping. thanks for your time.
author: Alex T.

description: I enjoyed walking up and down the streets of Chinatown. I have a baby so going up and down the streets was a bit of a challenge with a stroller. So we brought our carrier and that was much easier. We had difficult again finding a place to eat since we had kids but did end up finding a few in the beginning of Chinatown near the gate off grant!  Food was good, shopping was fun and we Will go back again but maybe when our kids our older.
author: Jena D.

description: This Chinatown is so cool and hip. 2nd biggest in the US (NY the 1st). Great dollar stores, restaurants and people watching. I often buy cooking ingredients, jewelry making supplies and school supplies here. It connects to Little Italy and North beach. Loves it.
author: Court S.

description:
Since the roots of San Francisco's Chinatown in the 1800s, it has grown to about 24 square blocks and is considered North America's oldest Chinatown with the largest Chinese community outside of Asia.  Settled and established by the early immigrants from the Canton (Guangzhou) region of China, Chinatown now encompasses the new immigrants including those from Hong Kong and Mainland China.  Though still mainly Cantonese and its various dialects are spoken in Chinatown, there are now the various dialects of Mandarin that have become common to the community as well.

The two major Chinatown streets running south to north are Grant Ave and Stockton St, each with a different vibe and feel.  Grant Ave. starts at Bush St. at the "Chinatown Gate." Grant Ave caters more to the tourists with its shops mainly selling arts and craft and souvenirs.  Stockton St. is where the Chinese community comes to shop and eat.  Stores selling daily staples, dry and can goods, fresh vegetables, meat and poultry, live seafood and deli.  There are new Chinatowns out in the western side of the City, on Clement St in the Richmond District and Irving St. in the Sunset District serving the residents that have moved into those Districts.  Yet many residents still venture back into Chinatown to do their shopping.  Late in the afternoon, they are carrying their shopping bags onto to the 30 Stockton bus on their way back home. 

For those looking for dining establishments, there are restaurants, bakeries and take-out dim sum establishments located throughout Chinatown.  The Cable Car Museum is located here as well as the Chinese Historical Society of America Museum.  Parking lots are located in Portsmouth Square and two structures on Vallejo St.

For many, they will have either a love/hate relationship with Chinatown with its touristy side on Grant Ave. and the dynamic, busy atmosphere on Stockton St. where the residents come to eat and shop for the groceries.
author: Al L.

description:
A couple of days ago chinatown was filthy, like a cess pool. 
l met up with friends doing some documentary work on bay area chinese history.
We walked around,  some friends visited old shop keepers for photo shoots.
The alleys were particularly littered to the point that they are a health hazard.
The City solutions could be to allow the shop keepers extra water priviledges to hose
down the sidewalks, the community could install some sand buckets for the cig butts which are all over the place and some signs of keep our neighborhood beautiful could be installed.
I am a fan of our Chinatown but I am really sad. I don't look forward to returning
author: Sandy D.

description:
Visited this section of San Francisco and hope to try the more ethnic portion of it since I understand I walked along the touristy section (block) of it.

Great shops and eateries to choose from.

Hope to visit again.
author: Sal M.

description: Chinatown is like stepping right into China for a short visit. As soon as you step off of the bus you step out of America. We got off the bus on a street that was mostly all markets. Just walking around on an afternoon where almost everyone seemed to be doing their weekly marketing was such a culturally enriching experience. The markets all extended out onto the sidewalk and were selling anything from veggies to huge whole fish. I simply loved walking around just looking. We then walked two blocks down and entered into a true Chinatown neighborhood with laundry being dried on clotheslines off of balconies and Chinese lanterns strung across the street. We walked down the street with many other sightseers, taking in the views and enjoying the experience. We went Chinese tea tasting as well, which you can read about in the next review!
author: Alyssa L.

description:
I love San Francisco's Chinatown.

-  It's the biggest Chinatown outside Asia.  I had a great workout walking up and down the streets of this Chinatown.  Make sure you wear comfy shoes and get ready to rub elbows with the locals and tourists.  
- One of the streets is covered with red lanterns...very pretty.  Get your camera ready.
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/san-franciscos-chinatown-san-francisco?userid=W7DHyQlY_kXls2iXt-_2Ag#Z3aemBXXvsIsBanAFydiJQ
-  You don't need to worry about not having enough cash for cash only businesses.  They have Bank of America, Citibank and of course..Bank of China.
- There is a crepe store with HK egg waffle..not sure if it's good there.
- The stores are bigger with better quality souvenir gifts.  Well not sure about the quality but they do look nicer than the stuff I see in LA Chinatown.
- Everyone greets me when I enter the store; it seems to be very tourist friendly.
- Not too far from Little Italy.  You can cross the intersections and you are smelling spaghetti instead of peking duck.
- SF Chinatown has more take-out dim sum places (even @ bakeries) compared to LA Chinatown.  
- Parking is expensive in San Francisco.  I parked @ North Beach Garage for 1 hour and 27 minutes for $6.00.

Get egg custard tart or pineapple bread, buy cheap souvenir gifts, take pictures and last but not least....dine @ Chinatown.

Have fun!!
author: Maggie C.

description: Chinatown is a must visit if you're a tourist, and a routine visit if you're a local.  Lots of stores with your cheap souvenirs and most importantly, a lot of good food.  It will range from sit down restaurants to quick to-go places.  For quick snacks, every block most likely has a to-go dim sum spot.  Grab your favorite dish for about $3 and chow.  A popular restaurant is House of Nanking but plan accordingly because it gets packed.  There are a handful of parking lots/structures but I recommend the portsmouth garage.  It's central and the easiest to get to, and is the most likely to always have spots.  It's probably the costliest though so if you're looking for a saving, try 343 sansome street.  $6 for 6 hours of parking, but it's a really small garage and super tight fits!  Kind of scary.
author: Matthew T.

description:
...sigh. I never heard of the term, nor witnessed the act fearfully called "snot-rocket".

Until...I ventured into the nether-regions of SF Chinatown...which essentially is anywhere in this corridor.  Today, this old-cantonese-dude...holding one nostril down with his index finger, and essentially exhaling his inner-nostril contents into the street.

Oh god that is soooo gross. Luckily no down-wind...about the only positive comment I can add to this ongoing discussion that is San Francisco's Chinatown.
author: Derek N.

description:
Chinatown is a must-see for tourists, and one of my regular stops when I'm in SF. 
If you need a San Francisco souvenir of any shape or size, Chinatown has got you covered. Use what I call the Mexico tourist rule and DO NOT buy that souvenir you like without first checking the other shops... chances are you will find no less than a dozen stores selling the exact same thing and possibly for less money.
If you're looking for a toy or novelty, Chinatown has thousands. Some stores have started appealing to the nerd crowd (*raises hand* Hello!) by stocking merchandise from popular shows, movies, comics and games- I recommend checking out Sekaido, Far East Flea Market and Bargain Bazaar if that's up your alley.
If you're hungry, there's plenty of restaurants that will fill you up on the cheap. If you don't know which one to try, look for someone handing out flyers on a Grant St intersection and go to whatever restaurant they're promoting. Have a little food adventure.
For a beautiful cacophony of sound, sight and color, the annual Chinese New Year Parade will give you the most bang (literally) for your buck (figuratively, since it's free).
