I'm just listing a few of my favorite things but there are so many more things Chinatown has to offer. Visit and discover for yourself!
author: Summer M.

description: Fun place to shop! We found some fun things to buy and the food was really good. Great little shops and places to eat along the way. Yup a few touristy places but what can you do!
author: Allen O.

description:
San Francisco's Chinatown is said to be the largest Chinatown in North America and has been around since 1840's.  It is also know to be home to the largest Chinese community outside of Asia.

Although it has changed over the years, Chinatown serves as a popular tourist attraction as well as a place where the local Chinese community goes to eat, shop and do business.  There is a nice blend of Chinatown natives as well as visitors which is nice.

There are so many Chinese restaurant and lovely bakeries selling my favorite Coconut Bread or BBQ Pork Steamed Bun but I always have a blast asking a local where their favorite place is.  Feel free to do the same, the community is usually very accommodating and friendly.
author: Shiho F.

description:
Over the years, I have had many different and enjoyable Chinatown experiences. The first one was as a teenager when my Iowa family visited San Francisco on vacation. I specifically remember a treasured puzzle box that I bought at some unnamed shop on Grant. Here are some others:

- Visiting a girlfriend before I moved to the Bay Area and naively enjoying my "genuine" cultural experience at Brandy Ho's (No MSG!) on Columbus.

- Strolling my favourite tourist route. I get off at Powell BART, walk through Union Square to Chinatown, move onwards through North Beach and on to the Fisherman's Wharf/Ghirardelli Square Area, enjoy an Irish Coffee or ice cream, and then take the Hyde Street Cable Car back (with at stop at  Lombard Street).

- Riding the 30 Stockton Bus!

- Walking through the Dragon Gate (on Grant), but first stopping at St. Mary's, the adjacent square that includes a memorial to Chinese war veterans, and the Church's gift shop.

- Breathing in the smells and energy of the Stockton street market scene.

- Being taken to Lunch in Chinatown for Lunch by my Landlord. I could never find this place again on my own, and I was certainly in the minority. And I took his advice and avoided the thousand year-old soup dish.

- Watching the Chinese New Year Parade (in the rain of course).

- Attending Kung Pao Kosher Comedy at the New Asia Restaurant. And did you know that observant Jews have a separate set of dishes for Chinese?

- Going to Dinner years ago with an Orthodox friend of mine. At that time, 2 of the very few Kosher restaurants in SF were in Chinatown.

- Hanging out in Portsmouth Square (Chinatown's Livingroom) and watching many of the SRO occupants playing chess and practicing their Tai Chi.

- Taking a guided walking tour and exploring the history of Chinatown via the alleyways.

I'm sure that more pleasurable experiences will be forthcoming. And all I need to do is show up, look around, and pay attention.
author: Eric B.

description: We walked up Stockton to what we heard was the street the local Chinese frequent as opposed to tourists. The sidewalk was tight. Lots of people, mostly Chinese people shopping for fruits veggies and hanging birds. I wouldn't miss this when visiting San Fran!
author: Gina J.

description:
A must when in SF!

Within an uphill walking distance from Union Square. Photo op at the gates is a given. 

Keep in mind that as you continue up the main drag, the cheaper items get. 

Also, eateries are always better farther into Chinatown. 

Visited a couple shops for my future sis-in-law, souvenirs for fams, and I picked up some cas scarves. Tried 2 bakeries and THE best Chinese food place in SF. (Refer to those reviews.)
author: Maria C.

description: Finally I gotto visit Chinatown in SF. Funny how all the Chinatown are alike. I've been to the ones in NYC, LA, and SF. Vendors, crowded, dirty, messy, parking is a beech....  Love the dimsum and food offerings here. Dimsum is a steal with great quality. You have to go to Good Mong Kok Bakery!!! It totally made the whole experience here for me.
author: Katie T.

description:
Chinatown is always crazy, busy, and oozing people. My wife and I enjoy a nice stroll down the streets of Chinatown. Be careful because the sidewalks are not wide enough for the amount of tourist and locals in the area. If you have kids, leave them at home. If you must bring them, like myself, make sure they can walk.   

My favorite part is finding all the knock off purses, shoes and clothes. I didn't know you could get a Coach bag for under $40. I think it was called Cooch not Coach. It must have been a misspelling.
author: Alberto E.

description:
This was my lovey's first trip to Chinatown, which is baffling to me. We trudged uphill en route to an herb shop like soldiers in combat, which is an apropos analogy as it was Chinese New Year and there were 600 (SMALL) people crammed per square foot. 

We did prevail in our pursuit of cheap herbal supplements; "Gunpowder" green tea and ginger gummies for me, and for Adam, a small cardboard box labeled in Mandarin that the shopkeeper insisted was a miraculous elixir for allergies. We'll see!

My favorite Chinatown moments are those spent in gift shops bartering with salespeople in broken English. I'm so easily sold on items of no use to me (three packs of Pokemon cards? "Three for ten dolla!") but that's all part of the fun!
author: Julianna O.

description:
Oh Chinatown, how I love / hate you, due to the congested parking and endless people standing around sidewalks. 


I rarely come here due to several things: 


01) Yes it stinks, what else would they do? Plus you'll find trash here and there.


02) Walked in a bakery to use the facilities (pregnant at the time), owner told me to buy something first before using the bathroom, told her I will after I go. Men's bathroom was open, and women's side was locked with a bolt (Uh... okay? And why is that?) Asked her, and she told me only bathroom I could use was the men's, alright.. walked in, oh geez can someone call the health inspector please! Poop & pee stains everywhere, including toilet paper, in spite of that, I'm picky of where I take a piss. 

Came out, and told the owner, I'm not buying anything due to the bathroom the way it was, and just left and went to another place.


03) Watch out for purse snatchers. Yes, don't carry something that you might regret losing afterwards, I've learned the hard way.


Other than that, would come here only to browse some stores or to eat.
author: Carol T.

description: Not as great as I thought it'd be. The streets are dirty and all the shops are selling cheap souvenirs. Not really worth my time.
author: Amber S.

description:
Killer hills!  

Who needs a Stairmaster when you can walk around Chinatown all day?  Then plan to gain all those calories back by eating at the local bakeries and dim sum shops!

PS.  Can we say "moon cake"?
author: Sophia W.

description:
If your looking for the tourist t-shirts and overpriced cameras you can buy anywhere head to Grant st and look at all the cheap crap you may want.

If your looking for the authentic experience of immersing yourself in the Chinatown local scene take the city bus at Market and Stockton (30 - Stockton line) and get off after the tunnel and walk to North Beach. Take your time and don't miss all the hidden alleys. 

DO NOT drive here. There is no parking and millions of people everywhere. If you have to drive, park in the Sutter-Stockton Garage and take the 30-Stockton.
author: Justin S.

description:
I really feel like I'm in China or something when I'm here. So many Asian faces everywhere!! The language here is Chinese not English. I would come here once in a while to visit relatives who live in Chinatown. They'd take us to eat and the food was amazing. Still is amazing! Where else can you get dim sum on every block? They have dim sum places here like we have McDs everywhere. 

The streets are very crowded here. Don't even think of driving, walking is the only way to go! 

Don't leave this place without buying some fruits/veggies from the markets.
author: Cindy K.

description: Some many trips to S.F., but have never been through Chinatown.... this time as out hotel was located right next to it (0.1 mile away)... decided to walk the route and look for a fun place to eat. Was surprised that there was not any "STREET VENDORS" selling interesting food from carts, but was still able to fine a sit down restaurant for lunch.... just wanted a little more local flavor.... lot and lots of cheap shops to by crap if your into that, and best of all, it felt very safe walking up and down the streets (not always the feel in S.F.)...... was fun to see this landmark!
author: Mark K.

description:
I love Chinatown! I can easily stay here for a week and not get bored. But I also venture to North Beach and walk down to the waterfront when staying for more than a couple of days. Talk about walking the world in a week while being in the city.

Chinatown has everything you can imagine. Good food, tea tasting, bars, banks, shops that sell good stuff and shops that sell the cheap stuff. Good art and tasteless art. Good food and okay food. It's tough to figure out where to eat... after 15 years, I'm still trying to find that gem. Doesn't help when they close or move shop.

I love the markets on Stockton! This last time we finally got a duck to take home and it was SO good!!!! Bought garlic for so cheap, scallions, bok choy, ginger, everything you need to make your Asia cuisine for very little money compared to our traditional American markets. We also got Durian to try...  I only wish I knew how to cook with the dried smelly foods as I know they are used in a wide variety of dishes... just don't know the techniques of cooking authentic Chinese foods.

Chinese New Year is fun! Tons of people walking the street, festivals, lotteries, shows and of course the parade. 

The stores close up fairly early; but the restaurants and bars stay open late.
If you've never been and can handle crowds of people - you must go!
author: Sandra R.

description:
It's fun just walking around here and observe the things going on around Chinatown! Lots of cheap shops with useless/junky items. Asian slippers, dishware, toys, fake jade, bootleg designer stuff, etc. Lots of fun looking at all the bakeries and food shops!! Overall, cheap dim sum here if you know where you're going!

Must see/do:
- Fortune Cookie Factory (in Ross Alley)
- go into a giant bazaar/store that sells all those useless and yet funny items (Far East Flea Market)
- have dim sum at a crowded place (that way you know it's good)!!
author: CeCe C.

description: It's busy here with both locals and tourists every day so be prepared...but that's just all part of the travelers experience
author: Joe B.

description: I'm giving it Five Stars because it impressed the hell out of me!  Walk two blocks straight in, turn right and walk one block, then turn around and look. You'd swear you were in China. There is nothing there to remind you you're in the U.S. Shopping opportunities for Chinese items are vast. I even walked into a Chinese adult bookstore! It was wild seeing whole roast ducks hanging in meat shop windows. A few times I felt a bit anxious because I didn't know if I'd find my way out of there. Experienced Dim Sum Cuisine for the first time and loved it. The neatest thing that came from my visit to Chinatown was months after my trip I was watching the movie "Big Trouble in Little China" and saw the restaurant I ate at in the movie!
author: Mark D.

description: A filthy, ripoff tourist trap with dirty restaurants and junky novelty shops. No parking. I live in San Francisco and haven't gone near Chinatown for over15 years. On my last trip there, obviously tubercular old people were coughing up blood on the sidewalks and that did it for me. I'll never go back there. Shoes that walk on those foul streets should be burned.
author: Pam J.

description:
Aside from a few signs, San Francisco's Chinatown doesn't look much like any place I've been to in modern China. However, the architecture, little shops selling useless trinkets, markets, and the abundance of tourist-traps all work together, contributing to it's charm.

It's a pity the best dim sum places aren't found in Chinatown - I have fond memories of going to the one in Boston on Sunday mornings for dim sum with the family. It would complete the experience - especially for first-time visitors!
author: Asha S.

description: I truly love walking around China town...especially with my nephew, god daughter and their friends in tow. Truly a must see... I love looking at all the touristy stores.. Make sure you have your walking shoes on to really enjoy the sights!
author: Claudine S.

description:
Very nice China Town!  Like most China Towns (except Sacramento China Town, read my comments on Sacramento China Town under CHINA TOWN MALL), this China Town has many restaurants, many Chinese grocery stores, Cantonese language schools, banks, tourist stores!  Sometimes I do buy post cards (I like collect post cards of different towns/states)!  Always very popular during Chinese New Year period each year!

Always nice visit this China Town!  Nickolas at Sheraton regarding Sacramento, he say there no Chinese New Year events there, "You better to go to yours in San Francisco or in Oakland!" 

I remember, mentioning one in Sacramento, Nickolas at Sheraton in Sacra, he mentioned something of, "I Been To Your China Town in San Francisco, Miss C!  I thought I would get lost to find my way out," I said, "Nick, is only sixteen or seventeen blocks one way, sixteen or seventeen blocks another way!"  Yes, this the biggest Asian community outside of China!  How he gets lost not know, then I realize since growing up in Oakland, may be easy for him get lost!

Now is February 19, 2015, start of Year Of ThE Sheep!  Gung Hay Faat Choy to every person!  Obviously, any Chinese New Year, China Town very busy with both the Chinese people and tourists!  Wishing people wisdom, prosperity, longevity, happiness!
author: Karyn C.

description:
You've got to do this at least once. Your calves will be killing you on the walk back (Damn those hills!), and you will be tired, and your feet will be hurting (even with the comfiest shoes), but it's worth it. it's a good time. 

Souvenirs here are much cheaper than on the Wharf. You can pick up tons of T-shirts for super cheap (just don't expect them to last long at all. The graphics of all my tees from there peeled pretty fast, but hey, it's the thought that counts, right?). Another thing I love to buy there are the little purses. One of the best things though to get is the jewelry. They are always on "Going Out of Business Sale", but that's just what they want tourists to think. Still, you can get jade and other precious stones for very cheap. Beautiful bracelets, necklaces, and earrings. I bought fresh water pearls for my mother and she loved them. Feel free to haggle a little, too. If you are buying a lot, the shopkeepers will work with you. 

About the food -- check Yelp before going in somewhere. On my last visit I kept checking on my iPOD as we walked by places because we were so hungry, but everything had really low ratings. We ended up going for sushi in North Beach of all places! it was awesome, though. 

The Verdict: I said it already, but I'll say it again. You've got to do it at least once. Take lots of pictures!
author: Cara S.

description:
What a unique experience! 

Both times I've been to San Francisco I had to go here, it's so unique. It is very crowded but it just seems to add to the experience. The whole area is colorful, literally. I've never been in a neighborhood like this. It's fun and alive.

I really didn't like the pressure to buy more and more things in some of the shops.  But there is a lot of fun inexpensive trinkets and snacks.  If you don't like crowds then this isn't a place for you.
author: AnneMarie N.

description: I love going to Chinatown.  The people and energy is exciting.  Yelp has terrible tactics and needs to come up with a realistic way of filtering.   Filter away
author: Juan N.

description: This is a neat place to visit but as others have said lots of junkie stuff that is sold at every other store-and be very careful to check your change as well as what you are charged at both shops and restaurants.
author: Laura J.

description:
Hard one to rate. Hilly and touristy on one side but cheap groceries and eats on the other.....

The food places are average, golden Gate Bakery is worth checking out if they are ever open for some good old fashioned egg tarts!

The thing that sticks in the mind (not good) was when someone decided to pull down their pants and a take a dump on the street. It became more like China than Chinatown! lol

Worth a trip for visitors and the groceries are cheap. Don't get pushed around or you'll miss all the good stuff when it comes out!
author: Nick L.

description:
Really enjoyed taking my 11 year old niece here, she was visiting from out of town and I wanted to take her somewhere different than the usual. We explored many different places and bought some fun goodies for her to take back home with her. 

It was a total delight. 

Parking can be a little annoying, but this is San Francisco. We got lucky and found street parking right away.
author: Meghan L.

description: o loved San Francisco Chinatown. It actually feel like you're on China. Loss of little shops and restaurant. Literally, almost every shop and bank is advertised in Chinese. I went to the Citibank and it was all in Chinese. Crazy but cool!
author: Zochi F.

description:
If you try and drive through Chinatown and/or expect to find parking, you're insane. I've seen people many times try and drive through these streets while stopping here and there in frustration because tourists are crossing and parades are forming in the middle of the street, like they are surprised that this is happening. So I stand on the sidewalk and point while laughing. 
You will find metered parking along the cross streets, but you'll most likely be trekking uphill. If you are prone to having a loser moment like myself and happen to get lost most of the time, just listen for the sounds of illegal fireworks, music, and live chickens.

Most of the stores are inexpensive. You will find an assortment of souvenirs, mostly, as well as fresh fruit and vegetables. You will also find a lot of people walking around with their kids on leashes, ducks hanging in windows, tourists trying on different hats and clothes while taking pictures of themselves with their camera phone, one can only assume they are uploading to Facebook, and [love] lanterns/decorations hanging from building to building.

The food here is scrumptious; so many places to choose from. 
*Note to self, bring cash*
I have yet to try any of their bakeries, but from what I hear it's AMAZING.

It's always a treat to come here.
author: Linnea H.

description:
So this is going to be a bit of a rant but after reading some of the reviews I gotta tell it how it is.

Yes Chinatown is dirty. But this is not some inherent quality of Chinese people or anything like that, it's because most of the people who live in Chinatown are desperately poor. And when you're poor and living in an overcrowded area things are going to be dirty. So if you're going to complain about the dirt check your privilege and understand that no one lives in a dirty neighborhood like that by choice, it's just what happens when you're new to this country and can't afford to move to the suburbs. And yes it is a little bit like China but that should come as no surprise because China is an overcrowded country with predominantly poor residents.

I am someone who fondly remembers regularly going to Chinatown as a child with my grandmother to buy groceries.  This place, although a tourist attraction for some inexplicable reason, matters for the people that live there and the cultural history of San Francisco as a whole. Many of you may not know that the beginnings of Chinatown wasn't necessarily a place Chinese people created by choice - it was that no one would rent to them and they were forced to settle in the slums. Or that the pagodas,  the "chinese architecture",  were made solely for the benefit of tourists in the wake of the 1906 earthquake to allow Chinatown to stay where it was since the city wanted to move all off them out of what was potentially prime real estate.

Chinatown has a lot of history for my family and many others and has been and will be a port of entry for many poor immigrants. So when you complain about the dirt and give it one star reviews, understand that the laptop you're writing off of in the comfort of your house is a world away from what most residents of Chinatown have ever experienced.

Enjoy the food, buy the knick knacks, and please keep spending your money there but be polite because Chinatown is more than just a tourist attraction, it's a community. Chinatown does not exist for the benefit of tourists but for the benefit of it's residents and the wider community.

End Rant.
author: Misha T.

description:
THE cleanest Chinatown I've ever been to.

It's a great place to go shopping and eating Asian cuisine.  Just be sure that you know how to use chopsticks because some of the mom and pop shops don't have forks.

It can get pretty crowded on the weekends so be prepared to run into people.  Also, don't be there at night. It's all residential, so you can't do much there at that time.
author: Vira P.

description: Still looking for things to do in Cali, okay, do the China Town walking tour or just do the tour in your car. If you are in the mood for lunch or dinner, you will find many options here. Good luck in finding a place to park. Taking the tour by car is a swift way to get in and out of the area. As I see it, if you seen one China Town, you have seen them all.
author: Gloria B.

description:
From the fruit and veggie markets to the dim sum to Golden Gate Bakery you cannot go wrong.. I mean today for example I passed by a shop that had the Garmin for 99 bucks.. the catch? It was in Mandarin... hey... it gives you an excuse to learn another language :-). I usually spend around an hour and a half here... thirty to forty minutes waiting in line at Golden Gate Bakery and the other time is spent going  up and down checking out different stores while my egg tarts cool.... 

From one tourist to another.. it is really annoying when you are walking super slow in a big group and other people can't get around..same goes when you suddenly stop in the middle of the sidewalk and I walk into you... move it or loose it!!
author: Vicky T.

description: I love Chinatown and come often and every chance I get. No trip to the city is complete without it. Great for gift shopping for yourself and others. Bargains are always found and you can negotiate prices on anything, you don't have to pay what it says. Most venders will bargain with you or at the very least not charge you tax or take a buck or two off. If you are buying in quantity you can always get a great deal the more you buy the more they discount it. The bakeries and markets over on the side streets and one block over are always good too. Most of the places off the strip here don't speak english very well, if at all, but they do their best. If it is a massage place or something like that some of the markets and bakeries though don't care or need your business and can sometimes ignore you. But I used to think they were just rude but I think they just don't want to have to deal with you and those good bakeries are busy so if you cannot point or tell them what you want you may get frustrated. It has happened to me but if you stay on the main drag there are a few bakeries there and they have things marked in english pretty good unlike the other ones. Lots of good finds here and food galore, get a reflexology foot massage for $20 for 30 min too they are fabulous! Just look down the side streets they are usually right off the strip 1/4 block or so you can see the signs. Enjoy your trip to the city and come here for sure it is a great place to take a walk down and allow some time if you are looking to eat some good food and shop as well and then get that foot massage on the way out. Or walk to the end cross the street and go into Little Italy area for some dinner.
author: Heidi H.

description:
I love it here.  The SF Chinatown definitely beats LA's Chinatown in terms of little retail shops.  The shops have all the touristy things, but there are shops that sell useful Chinese kitchen appliances, fake paper money/clothes for praying to your ancestors (i.e., usually around Chinese New Year), tea houses, and groceries.  Most things are relatively inexpensive and almost all stores allow you to bargain the prices a little down (except groceries).

The only complaint I have is about the food.  The food in the area is horrible.  Sure, maybe 20 years ago the food is great, but I think most of the Cantonese chefs have left SF and come down to the LA area (like San Gabriel/Arcadia area).  Lucky me, since I live near the LA area!

Right next door is Little Italy...
author: Lily L.

description:
Having lived in the Chinatown area for a long time (since elementary school) I have seen a lot and smelled a lot. There is a reason why the 30 Stockton bus is nicknamed "The Orient Express". Great dim sum restaurants and at a cheap price. I love telling people who live outside of this area how much I spend on dim sum and compare it to what they spend at their suburban restaurant. They have it all, Noodle Festivals, Chinese New Year's Parade, and more. 

And where do all these people come from??? It seems like thousands upon thousands of Chinese grocery shoppers. And then after 6pm, they are all gone. Where did they go??? 

Coming soon to CMC Music Channel...MC Fong's music video, "Chinatown Rap" being filmed entirely in SF Chinatown.
author: William M.

description:
I felt like my own personal roller coaster when I was here, walking up and down some of the steepest hills! Truthfully, traveling up and down these hills by foot is most certainly a vital part of the visit being as grand and amazing as it was!

I loved going into the shops and seeing stuff and more stuff. I mostly enjoyed the Chinese stuff. The tea sets, robes, fans, lanterns.  I purchased my first Chinese fan at one of these shops, next it will be a tea set and I will wait until I return to Chinatown in SF. The supposed Chinese shops here in Los Angeles don't seem to hold the same caliber of quality as those in SF...or maybe its a trick of the mind, and I just rather spend my money on something I know I don't need when I'm on vacation and not at home...hmmm...Who knows,who cares? 
Anyway, they had other stuff, too. Hello Kitty, Angry Birds, Phineas and Ferb, other characters and of course San Fransisco themed products for the visitors.

Browsing through the user uploaded photos on here I've noticed that Chinatown hosts a festival. I WILL be going to one!
author: Jennifer R.

description: I love coming here whenever I'm in town simply because I feel at home here.  The shopkeepers and locals speak my dialect, which is Cantonese, so that makes negotiating (never pay full price) & ordering food much easier.  I don't frequent the tourist traps (bazaars, memorabilia, t-shirt crap) but I do hit up the local restaurants, bakeries, Buddhist temples, various ethnic associations, the Y & the historical places.  After all, I need to recognize my people's past so I can better appreciate the present.  So this Chinatown and the ones in NY are my favs.  The one in LA is total crap, absolute rubbish, you don't even hear Chinese spoken there anymore.  Like What's that about?
author: Michael L.

description:
Some say it smells like hot garbage, I say it smells like home. I make a point of walking thorough this hood on my way to/from work every day. Depending on the alley or street you're on you might see:
*Fortune cookies being made.
*Elderly practicing Tai-chi.
*Whole animals being delivered to butchers.
*Lost tourists. 
*Parades.

What I love:
*Mooncakes
*The food (check out Great Eastern for dim sum!)
*Bartering

Other tips:
The residents speak Cantonese. 
Most things are cash only. 
Please, for the love of god, do not try to drive/park here. Also, standing in the street to take pictures & crossing when its red is not recommended. You will be run over. 
Respect the residents. There's nothing worse than angry Chinese.
Tourists: please take note that sidewalks are for WALKING not standing.
author: Sara P.

description:
A must-see attraction in San Francisco. The shopping is the same kitschy knick knacks you can find anywhere, but there is a lot of beautiful architecture and history here. There are some good restaurants...check Yelp for great recommendations. I highly recommend coming early in the morning to get great pictures with little people in the way. There are beautiful red hanging lanterns that photograph well.

Definitely something not to miss...unless it's the middle of the day and it's elbow-to-elbow.
author: Rosie P.

description:
CON: Rude old little chinese women
PRO: cheap food & finds

REALITY: Learn to live with it!!
author: Tam T.

description:
I used to live at Pacific and Jones, which could be referred to as the China-Nob... Nob Hill but extremely close to the fish shops, cheap trinkets stores, cash-only restaurants, and questionably fresh produce.

We would buy a few things at the Chinatown markets, such as veggies and fruit on occasion... they also have some excellent restaurants, shops for cheap gift ideas and necessities such as a quick $2 umbrella, places to make keys, etc etc.

I'm not a huge fan of Chinatown, but it's something I think everyone should experience. I'm from the Midwest, and Dim Sum isn't exactly something I would choose to eat for breakfast. However, I've done it, and I can't say I wish to do it again.

Anyway, cash is a MUST in Chinatown, and be prepared to be pushed around a bit in the crowd. If you're visiting, take the bus or a taxi- parking is near impossible!
author: Kristin F.

description:
I second, third, fourth, and 50 millionth any past comment that said to avoid driving here if you're meaning to visit. I've lost count of how many lights we've ended up sitting through multiple times over because people kept entering the crosswalk even when the light was red. It was just a constant stream of people. 

On top of that, parking, especially street parking can be hard to find. When we finally got a space, it had one of those $3/hour meters where a quarter buys all of 5 minutes. 

I'm with those past Yelpers recommending either taking the MUNI or walking. Oh god, yes.  

Grant Avenue is the touristy section full of shops and restaurants that more appeal to those seeking the "exotic" or "mysterious" Chinatown experience. It's where you see red lanterns hanging over the street, more people with cameras, more cheap knick-knack shops, and more restaurateurs hustling for you to come and eat. 

Stockton (the next main street west) is often considered the "real" Chinatown, full of markets packed with people and eateries with no English on the menu. You'll see people hanging underwear out to dry from the upstairs windows and balconies and locals bargaining over fruit and fish. 

It's really fascinating seeing the stark contrast between the two. 

For places to visit, I highly recommend a stroll down Waverly Place and seeing the Tin How (also known as Tien Hau) temple on the third floor of 125. No photography allowed, but it's beautiful inside the small space deemed the oldest Chinese temple in the U.S. (or at least San Francisco).
author: Christine A.

description:
What's not to love!

Whether you're on the hunt for cheap chotchkies, shark fins, candied ginger, a whole mess of herbs and teas, exotic fruits or just awesome photo ops, Chinatown is your place.

I love the chaos here. Lots of people walking around, lots of traffic on the streets, people on bikes and skateboards. It's a smorgasbord of people and cultures. Definitely a must-see if you're from out of town. Great photos ops here too!
author: Katy H.

description:
My dad use to drag me & my bro here every Saturday when we were young to buy groceries. It felt like a chore to go. 

As I grew up (high school-ish years and up), I would come here with friends, siblings or cousins, just because, there wasn't a reason. Maybe it was funner because I wasn't dragged along, but I came on my own.

I guess this is the closest thing I have to China without trekking half a world away.

Oh yeah, I wouldn't wear white or nice clothes here...
author: Kylie L.

description:
Chinatown is intense.  It can be super-packed here, but you know what--you'll love it!  I mean, seeing the throngs of people on the sidewalks and crossing streets without fear makes you feel like you COULD be in another country.  

For me personally, I always like to think I'm Jack Burton, and I just parked my rig up the block, and I'm getting ready to battle evil for the greater good when I walk down alleys here.

But if you're looking for an adventure more than fighting, try finding a parking space.  That can drain you of energy and personal solitude (or coin).

And finally, your orders:  you have to eat here.  You will find some of the BEST Chinese cuisine here.  It's against the law to not partake while here.
author: Corey G.

description:
This is a huge chinatown!!! the shops here are whatever and the restaurants are even worse!!!

The only reason I got here is for the fun of looking at things and as well as the redblossom tea store. They have the best tea's!
author: -Johnson- N.

description:
Being the second most Chinese populated place outside of China, one CAN NOT skip a visit to Chinatown when visiting S.F. It would be akin to not going to a casino while you're in Las Vegas, or seeing the Statue of Liberty while you're in NYC. You just have to!! You won't be disappointed either.

There are numerous shops to buy souvenirs, numerous tea shops to drink various teas, numerous eateries to try (a Yelpers dream!), and grocery stores. You literally feel like you're almost in another country because you can let yourself go and get immersed in the surroundings. 

I don't view this as a "tourist trap", but more like a great way to experience another culture, without having to get a passport to get there.
author: Wes S.

description:
Whether I live here or not, I have a love hate relationship with San Francisco's Chinatown. I love it because it has that quaint, nostalgic aura that envelops me whenever I'm walking through it, but at the same time, I get that icky feeling that this is such a stereotypical view of what Chinatown is supposed to be.

This time around, I was in Chinatown for a specific reason and that was to attend a celebration. I looked at it from a different view ... I tried to be a tourist this time, and not a resident who just wants to go there, do my grocery shopping and then get the hell out of there.

I saw the little old ladies and the elderly men doing their shopping and carrying their bags for blocks on end. I remember how people will do their shopping every single day here, not those huge weekly shops we'd do in the suburbs. Mixed in with them were the blatantly obvious tourists with their Hawaiian shirts and shorts (even when it's freezing cold in SF during summer) with their shopping bags filled with souvenirs.

On this visit, I saw some tourists who had just been to the Golden Gate Fortune Cookie Factory -- and I know this because they had 2 big plastic shopping bags full of the flat fortune cookies and this girl of about 12 was chomping on the broken pieces the little ladies at the factory will throw in your bag when you buy something. I immediately wanted to stop by and purchase some to bring home, but alas, I'd already filled my carry on with all my stuff from the Ferry Building so it was a no go.

The hustle and bustle reminded me how much I've missed living in the Bay Area and of my time when I actually worked (and hated it) in Chinatown. I guess the grass is always greener on the other side.
author: Anita L.

description:
San Francisco's Chinatown is my favorite place to explore and walk-around, when I go to San Francisco. I explored most of the shops in Chinatown.  However, each time I go, I seem to find something interesting - an adventure awaits.  I also like seeing all the interesting buildings in Chinatown.

Getting lunch, when we are in Chinatown is an adventure, also.  Just looking at each restaurant's menu on the window is fun.  Usually, we will end-up at a small, and simple, restaurant, like Broadway Dim Sum

When we leave Chinatown, we will usually have bags of produce with us because the prices are low compared to the markets at home.

Overall, I found a great way to spend a day.
author: Bill F.

description: Overall experience was pore.  Many store owners were very rude to us, you would think that china town would thrive on visitors and want to develop a friendly reputation by treating people of a diffrent culture with respect, i guess not.  We did visit one store that was great the rest full of rude people we even got turned away from a hair cut for my son the woman claims they were closed even though there were in fact people getting their hair cut.  Super lame.  We will never visit this place again,  i am sure there are many other places to visit if you want to be treated with some sort of dignity.
author: Adrian G.

description: lots of culture and a lot of food. Bring cash!
author: Connie M.

description:
Feels EXACTLY like china.

Bustling small streets. Stands of random confections and concessions. Its an interesting place. Although, the "China" town in Los Angeles is somewhat quite similar what L.A doesn't have is.. A GIANT HILL. 

This hill is a MISSION. (We took a stick shift car in other words a 'manual') and that was a toughie.

Dim sum is good around the area but you gotta get your food and go. Very few places allow dim sim consumers to sit in their restaurant and order off a menu.

Would I go here again? Of course! The cultural aspect here is VERY lively and the food? Pretty damn good.
author: Monique N.

description:
I've had dim sum, egg tarts, noodles and hot pot in Chinatown.  

Besides the food, I got great customer service at the district's post office and have gotten some beautiful fresh flowers from a random storefront.

To date, I haven't by disappointed by any eatery that I've tried.  Maybe the only suggestion I can make is that the best Chinatown places that I've eaten at can be found at the end of narrow staircases and off the main drag.
author: Darren S.

description: It is always fun to try new things when I go to the city. I haven't been here before and I was impressed although I was told this area is nothing like it used to be with all the great deals and great buys. Now it seems like a local flea market just in stores.
author: BoGordon F.

description:
I am a Chinese student studying in the US. The China town in San Francisco is very nice, but please do not buy expensive jade or Asian antiques there because most of them are fake. I spent 600 dollars on a jade bracelet and found that it was fake afterwards. I called the shop owner and asked if I can return it. He said no. I am very angry but I could do nothing. There are lot more fake bracelets in his shop. I hope other people are not cheated again by him.

 Here is the shop's information: KING DYNASTY Asian Antiques & Arts. Address: 1224 Powell Street San Francisco CA 94133 USA.
author: Jane G.

description: The Grant Street area is a great place for a street fair and the lunar new year 2013 is no exception for this; really an outanding lunar new year this year with concessions, food, ambiance, the dragon - snake and so forth.  Really nice people, too, and am especially impressed with the teas for sale, not to mention any number of other items in the concessions and local merchandise stores.  Really nice!
author: Thomas H S.

description:
To continue on my quest to be the quintessential San Francisco tourist I dragged GBF#1 with me to Chinatown, ok I didn't really he wanted to check it just as much as I did.

Lets see what did I see:
Lots of pink bags
Lots of old people using walkers
Lots of cars stopped in the middle of the road
Lots of Buddha trinkets
Lots of waving cats
Lots of alleys
Lots of Chinese restaurants
Lots of dragons
Lots of people spitting
Lots of gold
Lots of paper lanterns
Lots of rude tourists
Lots of herbs shops
Lots of Churches/Temples
Lots of non-Victorian looking buildings
Lots of banks
Lots of pagoda style roofs
Lots of silk pajamas
Lots of tea sets
Lots of smokers
Lots of trash
Lots of Bruce Lee's memorabilia
Lots of everything

I could have done with out the smoking and spitting but other than that it was everything I expected and than some.  If you want to be the quintessential San Francisco tourist you have to visit Chinatown.
author: Me H.

description:
I love visiting Chinatown, it brings me joy and reminds me how great being Chinese is.  The locals are sometimes loud n rude, they seem unfriendly but don't take it personal its natural!

When arriving to Chinatown,  park at the senior citizjgens park. And go to the shops that are hidden and find unique stuff! My favorite eatery is Hing Lung and a small steam bun shop on the corner of Stockton n Jackson.  There's so much to look at but I never go near the tourist souvenir shops. Check out the DVD & music stores, they have good deals on new released Hong Kong films.
author: La La T.

description:
SF Chinatown. 
-It smells of a mixture of urine, ass and leeks. 
-People here do not watch where they are walking. Be prepared to  dodge tourists and locals who always seem to be looking the opposite  way they are headed. 
-Most restaurants and shops here are CASH ONLY. 
-Good place to go for a cheap lunch. 
-Bad place to drive. No parking, EVER! And always, ALWAYS! double parked cars/delivery trucks congesting the roads. 
-Visiting it at night is much, much more pleasant. Less foot traffic and that means less stress, means more apt to take the time to window shop and maybe even go into a store.
-If you do go into a store, be prepared to pay way too much money for cheap, plastic, crap that just ends up in our landfill. Also, everything you buy from these places have a warning sticker that say they cause cancer/birth defects. FUN!
author: joanna r.

description:
So much culture. so much pizazz. so much color. it's crowded but that's the experience! 
Bakeries, produce, boba shops, souvenirs! interesting people. No restaurant is going to rip you off, pretty much all of them are very moderately priced if not super cheap! $

grab some fortune cookies!!!!!!
author: Veranna N.

description:
What Chinatown isn't complete without a dragon?! :)

Taken at the moon festival:
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/MY7BRqN17bvzD-O_-Mkpuw?select=UJ8x6MHxkQYnJ8eJeVbrbA
author: Jeff T.

description: Didn't to get experience everything because of time constraints, but seemed like a lot of fun stuff here. Although, a lot of the stores seemed to be carrying the exact same things so I felt like it was a bit redundant. Gotta come back to do more exploring...
author: Izz A.

description:
I love Chinatown! Being a San Francisco native, I use to always come up and go drink tea with my parents. Im half Chinese. Theirs two sides of Chinatown, Grant Street which is basically dedicated to tourists and Stockton Street which is where the locals are and all the small cheap dim sum places and bakeries. If your looking for small souvenirs go onto Grant Street. They got cheap T Shirts, Key Chain, and you name it. Way cheaper than Pier 39 and SF Downtown. 

Chinatown really resembles China. Take a walk down the alleys. Make sure your with someone though. And just look around, it looks EXACTLY like China (Yes I been there). 


Some useful tips: 

Dont drive. Take the bus. Especially in Chinatown, your NEVER going to find parking. Your better off walking from Market Street/Grant Street and just walk straight up Grant. Its a 10 minute walk. But it will save you money and time. Ask anyone living in San Francisco, dont drive. Even when your walking around Chinatown the people that live their dont drive. 

Bring Cash, most of the shops on Grant dont take credit cards. Especially since everything they are selling is super cheap. So bring CASH! (Im sure some places do but for the most part, they only take cash..)

Know how to use Chopsticks. Some of these tiny mom and pop shops only got Chopsticks. So learn!
author: Daniel S.

description:
You're better off packing onto the MUNI than driving around here. People overflow the sidewalks, crosswalks, and walkways so it can feel like you're trying to drive through a heard of cattle. Parking is flat out impossible so if you are driving, head to the parking garage on Vallejo. 

Other than that you can find some pretty interesting stuff in Chinatown. I like popping into the most hidden bars I can find and it's always an experience. There's also tons of touristy stuff for a tenth of the price they sell it by Fisherman's Wharf.

Tip: Bring a face mask if you wanna fit in!
author: Murphy O.

description: ITs a crazy environment, very hectic, authentic as if you are a traveler into China.  The things that I don't enjoy is that I cant seem to find anything that I want to purchase here.  You have to be skeptical of what you purchase, you might be buying knockoffs or things that may not be USDA approved, so its challenging.  If I was from the area, than maybe I would know the ins and outs about the stores, but its tough and they do try to hustle out there quite a bit.  Fireworks are about the only thing I see myself purchasing, and maybe a stress ball and green tea.  Thats about it.
author: Rob L.

description:
Some very cool architecture and history.  Stores full of cheap junk made for the tourist market.  Lots of seedy people at night.  don't know that it is unsafe, but you should at least be aware of your surrounding in the evening.  

At night you may glimpse a cross section of real Chinatown life (morbidly curious, voyeuristic, I confess) by lifting your neck and checking out the decrepit apartments over the storefronts.

Honolulu's Chinatown is more interesting I think, not as gritty, with the open air markets and food courts.
author: Jay W.

description:
It seems to be that china Town is pretty much the same, anywhere you go. New York, LA, San Fran. No one is better or worse than the other. 

I will say that parking is a complete joke, but isn't it anywhere! We paid $17 to park in a structure because there was no street parking in sight, that was a total let down!

It was an okay afternoon excursion, but one I probably won't make again.
author: Karma M.

description:
Chinatown in SF is growing everyday. Next thing you know,that it will takeover Old North Beach within a decade. It is the best place to buy your groceries. Don't expect Chinatown to carry organic items or things you would buy at Trader Joe's or Whole Foods. Too lazzy to cook lunch or dinner?, order takeout or buy loose items in the deli.In recent years,Chinatown has expanded throughout the city and bay area including Richmond, Sunset, & Mission plus Oakland,Union City and Fremont. "Chinatown Rocks!!" Don't diss Chinatown!!!

Con:
1.People shopping in Chinatown are rude. (You know who you are!!)
2.Chinatown is dirty,because people spit on the streets. Never wear white clothing in Chinatown.
3. If you are Chinese-local, tourist will ask you,
 "how to get to Chinatown?
 Yeah, I'm Chinese, I know the way. Need a Rickshaw?
author: Matt G.

description:
"Ubiquitous"

That would probably be a good word that comes to my mind when thinking of this vast expanse of the district that has become eponymous with San Francisco.

So, have to confess, that there have been numerous times I have trekked into Chinatown, fresh on the heels of many tourists (especially the ones from the Midwest who stick out like a sore thumb) in pursuit of my favorite bow buns from a dim sum store on Powell.  

My experience makes me want to learn several important pieces of information in Chinese, those being along the lines of "I'm Next", numbers to specify portions "two bow, three bow" and etc.  There have been countless moments of exasperation because I have been trodden on by people carrying many pink plastic bags filled with dim sum and vegetables, or cut in front of because I can't speak up.  And even though I look Asian, they probably deduce that I am a tourist or not Chinese, so again, I'm last in line.

But I love these moments of just walking around aimlessly, picking up a steamed bun here, walking into shops there, and sitting peacefully in a local teashop listening to the songbirds chirp away.

Its definitely a great escape.
author: Miika M.

description: Chinatown is so awesome. It's fun, intense and super congested the way Hong Kong is so I felt nostalgic visiting as it reminded me of being in HK with my bestie in '07. We had a blast in Chinatown SF this past weekend. Every time I passed a dim sum place or bakery I had a smile. It's really a neat place to visit. Be sure to check out the adorable bakeries and shoppes. Some have a more tourist-centric feel and others are a little more authentic. Either way there is something for everyone there.
author: Trudy H.

description:
The best way to see Chinatown at night is a self guided tour of the historic alleys and streets. Do a little research online and you will be pleasantly surprised by what you find. I had never seen Chinatown this way before and learned so much about the city I live in. The shady alleys are an adventure to find, my favorite is Dumcombe Alley, home of the opium den. 

Duncombe Alley (Jackson and Grant) 

Duncombe Alley is located almost directly across from Ross Alley (famous for gambling and brothels) causing me to believe this little city block was once one hot bed of illegal activity. Duncombe Alley was once the center of the great opium trade and where the poor and middle class went to get high in Chinatown. Opium dens started to pop up in the 1850s and spread to the non-Chinese San Francisco population within 20 years. In 1878 San Francisco passed its 1st anti-opium ordinance and in 1913 opium became illegal. Most opium dens had cover up store fronts with a tightly sealed basement or backroom for smoking. 

The alley is just as shady as ever. The sign is hidden in the shadows and is faintly highlighted by a depressing neon green sign. The lighting and fact that the alley can only be accessed by a metal fence with a deadbolt lined with barbed wire leads me to believe a little opium is still being smoked. 

We stopped at a bunch of other locations on my tour, Ross Alley, Joice Alley, Imperial Palace Restaurant.......
author: Alice S.

description: Best Chinatown in the nation. Ive been to the Chinatown in New York, Oakland, and Philly. I hear the LA chinatown sucks. Dirt cheap groceries and why of course all the OLD CHINESE PEOPLE. How can it be a Chinatown with them?! Pretty good food too but don't expect the restaurants to be clean.
author: Sarah C.

description:
Oh Chinatown. Bush street is a tourist mecca for those people from elsewhere travelling to see the City. It eventually leads into North Beach for most touristy bullcrap.

I go to Chinatown, but not to see the crappy tourist stuff. But to see the real stuff. To taste the DIM SUM, to wander through the strange shops, and be the only white person buying durian.

When I do relocate to the City. This is the place to buy produce. It is so cheap here. You can get a lot of veggies for a little money. You can also get turtle, frog, and any other kind of fowl. Seitan, soy, and other products.
author: Lana P.

description: Since, I am from the beautiful city by the bay AKA San Francisco.... I come to the San Francisco Chinatown many many times about every week to do my grocery shopping.... Not only that this is my favorite hang out area reason why...I love shopping areas that they have here and going to alot of different Chinese Restaurants all over the streets of the San Francisco Chinatown for lunch or dinner... Like on the popular shows like the Travel Channel there were alot famous people like Emeril Lagasse, Rachel Ray, Samantha Brown they all had came here to San Francisco's Chinatown and had once did a t.v. show here on the Travel Channel there is alot of other different shows from other t.v. network shows that was done in San Francisco's Chinatown as well!!!
author: William B.

description: It's way too crowded. I wouldn't recommend coming here on a weekend. There was no room to walk anywhere!! I enjoy coming here, but only on weekdays.
author: A L.

description: Ack!  By Starbuck's on Grant it is Tourist central, with the entry way lions, cheesy stores shelling junk and carved "jade" or "ivory" minatures of little people with big junk engaged in sex acts.  The real Chinatown is down on Broadway.  If an old lady with a pink shopping bag isn't smacking you or pushing you out of the way, you aren't in the real part of Chinatown, which does not cater to tourists.  Good food can be found there, great spices and produce at the markets, but you wont find sex carvings.
author: Rebecca H.

description: It's grimey, it's beautiful, it's crowded, it is what it is. A tourist spot, a place to eat, a place to explore, a place to find cheap goods. It's big, it's small, it's everything in between, but overall, it's awesome.
author: Jay A.

description:
Great place lots of fun shops
CAUTION: THE CHINATOWN RESTURANT PESTERS THE FUCK OUT OF U TO EAT THEIR EVEN INFRONT OF OTHER RESTURANTS
author: Matt N.

description:
As an LA native, this san fran chinatown is quite big compared to the one in LA. And much livelier, I must say.  It seems that Grant street is completely dedicated to tourists, with all the souvenir shops. Oh and a thing about these souvenir shops is that they only look small on the outside, but once you walk in, you'd be surprised out deep in these shops go. 

Grant street is the heart of TOURIST chinatown, but to really get the feel of the asian community you must go one street up to stockton, or any other street aside from Grant, because thats where all the dingy markets, snack shops, bakeries, outdoor grocery stores, and not to mention, rowdy locals shop for their weekly groceries. And as annoying as that may sound, it really is a great, and interesting thing. It almost felt like I was in actual CHINA instead of a Chinatown. I loved it! I can only imagine that it's like there when Chinese new year rolls around every year.
author: Janice W.

description: Chinatown is an amazingly crucible of culture and history in any city, but the one in San Francisco can definitely challenge any of them. I loved walking about, not even going in anywhere (yet!) and getting to view all of the culture that's present in this part of the city. It's absolutely 100% somewhere that you need to visit if you're ever in San Francisco, because it's absolutely huge and there's so much to do and see! (and more importantly eat.)
author: Martyn M.

description: If you never seen an area that's predominately Asian then this is a real treat otherwise it's nothing too spectacular. You can find the cheap junk most vendors sale almost anywhere nowadays. The fact that Asian food is ubiquitously found in California means that you probably will find similar fare to the local hole in the wall Asian place near you. Chinatown does have an energy to it, and it isn't a huge let down, but it just isn't as special as it once was.
author: Andrew D.

description:
Want really cheap produce? Go to Chinatown. Want a cheap, definitely made-in-China knicknack? Go to Chinatown. Crappy day and just want to shove against people? Go to Chinatown. Want yummy, most likely greasy, cheap food? You know where to go. 

Tips: Don't be offended if you get pushed around. While you shouldn't mosh through the crowd, you're allowed to elbow through a bit if needed. When you're in line to pay, guard your position in line like a footballer. I may be a bit extreme, but I stand with my elbows out and feet braced. The grannies may be old, but they are fast! Wear closed-toe shoes. At the least, don't stand next to a guy clearing his throat; spit is probably coming soon. Not for the claustrophobe, germaphobe or xenophobe.

Grant Ave is filled with tourists, touristy stuff and knickknacks. Stockton St is filled with Chinese, produce, and fish with their heads. Both have their uses and good eats. Also wander off the beaten path through the alleys and side streets for a true hole-in-the-wall experience.
author: Yan E.

description:
If you're looking for cheap food and made-in-China stuff, this is the place to be. The people who run the businesses are very rude and unwelcome; some don't even speak English. I guess that's why it is called China town.
We went to visit and had to use the restrooms once, no word to describe; they were extremely dirty and horribly smelled. How can a place like this be located in one of the most beautiful cities in the world.
Not too far away, Japan Town is much nicer and cleaner.
author: The D.

description: If I could rate Chinatown as a zero I would.  Worst place to tour, shop, or eat.  Don't go here!  The streets are dirty, the shops are unclean, the people are unfriendly.  On top of that it is very crowded with many people that looks like gangsters.  Worst place in San Francisco to visit.  After 200 years in America the Chinese community have not improved their living standards.
author: Nus V.

description: Not the cleanest place to be at but there are a few perks about CT.  Some of the yummy restaurants such as R&G Lounge, Great Eastern, and Vip cafe is located in CT. The best egg tarts in town by golden gate bakery.  Also I can get my inexpensive asian snack fixes here. In addition, the cheap and fresh groceries your money can buy.  Parking and getting through this place is troublesome so parking at the garage is recommended.
author: Ann L.

description: Five stars for being a part of San Francisco's rich history.  Not too long ago we traveled to China town for the new year parade.  Which was amazing, but trying to squeeze through all the crowding is actually a little bit like being in the more populated areas of China!
author: Jennifer L.

description:
I've never been to China, however I have been to many Chinatowns. The Chinatown in San Francisco is the largest outside of China. 

Once you enter through the green tiered gateway, you are entering a massive and complete city, within a city. San Francisco's Chinatown has it own schools, churches and banks. The buildings are very colorful and Golden dragons, pagodas and pagoda style roofs adorn many of the buildings. Some of the finest architecture can be seen here. 

The number one tourist attraction is the inexpensive shopping that is available, either walking through a store front or checking out a vendors merchandise. There are many herbal shops offering Chinese medicines. Beautiful silk dresses, Dim Sum, Majong sets and even Chinese checkers can be found. 

I would not be surprised if they have close to as many restaurants and bakeries, as San Francisco has in itself. How do you choose? 

Chinatown is colorful and beautiful with the structures and ornate decorations. You try not to look at the dirt and rubbish laying around, which can be very distracting from this cities beauty.
author: DJ M.

description:
I walk through Chinatown often to get to work - here a few highlights from my commute:

Chinese women hocking loogies on the sidewalk - Not terribly pleasant at 7am
The delightful smell of low tide outside the fish markets
Hundreds of caged live chickens being delivered to "restaurants"
Dead pig carcasses being delivered - no gloves ? no problem
People bumping into at every cross walk  - No sense of "personal space"
Lots of public housing - but also luxury vehicles (BMW, Mercedes etc) parked outside
Interstingly, 99% of these luxury vehicles outside the public housing units also have handicap stickers -- not paying taxes + free parking = fancy new car (i guess)


Call me closed minded but this part of town is really quite disgusting - And what's with the "yelling" at
author: Pan P.

description:
Chinatown is awesome. Where else can you find all kinds of cheap trinkets to remind you of your visit and eat great food also? Here. If you are looking for a great place to eat, I'd venture deep into Chinatown and pick any number of unassuming or even seedy looking entrances. Remember, just don't got a block into Chinatown and pick one. That's where most tourists go. You have to go deep in! It's pretty long walk to the end. 

I remember we even used to buy our illegal firecrackers here in high school. Ahh, the idiocy of teenagers. 

It's a short walk from Union Square. Additionally, you can park at Portsmouth Square Parking lot. When you get out of the elevator from the garage, all the old Chinese guys will be playing cards, chess, or mah jongg. It's a nice community park. This is a must for any visitor.
author: Brian A.

description:
Chinatown's the best. 

People can complain all they want about this place, but so long as the fundamental awesome factors stay the same then I'm still in love: 

- Cheap food & gifts around every turn!

- Amazing feeling of escaping normal life and "getting lost" in what essentially feels like a busy Chinese city! 

- Good size square footage allows the above to happen!

I'm lucky to live 20 mins away from the largest population of Chinese living outside of China in the world's largest CHINATOWN! 

Can't wait to make my way through here again.
author: Kai S.

description:
So after the horrible experience of my first night in San Francisco, I was happy to experience Chinatown. 

I had read and heard only good things about San Fran's Chinatown. We decided to walk here since it was not too far from the hotel. 

DO NOT, I REPEAT DO NOT WALK. 

I quickly learned the hills in San Francisco are no joke. It felt like I was taking a hike but through the city. When we arrived we knew we had arrived because all you saw were locals. The signs were in Chinese, the streets smelled Chinese, the buildings even looked Chinese, and there was TONS AND TONS of GRAFFITI. 

Luckily I was with someone who actually spoke Chinese. We were able to enter shops and order food without any trouble. My only complaint was a lot of the shops had no chairs or tables to sit and eat. But that wasn't a problem since I don't mind just sitting in front of a closed business' steps and just setting up shop. 

The food here was authentic and as my friend said "man this reminds me of china." 

This is the real deal.
author: David N.

description: I like coming here! so many places to go to shop at for a real good price. theres a bakery somewhere down the street that I went too that was good (sorry forgot the name). It does get crowded here on the weekends. Definitely good to bring people here for sight seeing and shopping. Parking wise, SUCK! i would recommend parking some where in the city further than chinatown because it gets real real packed but then again, parking in the city is real hard to find. Walking distance isnt so bad.
author: Kim T.

description:
Chinatown is awesome. I made the mistake of coming in the morning, before many stores were open. It's just so surreal here. You almost forget you're still in SF, and not in some Chinese city somewhere.

I liked SF's Chinatown much better than DC's.

Take a few hours and stroll along the streets. The sights, smells, sounds, and characters you'll see make for an experience. 

Just go.
author: Jay M.

description:
Chinatown is one of my favorite places to go in the city.  

I always cringe when I hear people talking about how much cheap shit they found at Chinatown.  Do tourists come here for the cheap knock off shit, or to experience the culture of the oldest Chinatown in the U.S?  I can't never tell any more. To me, it's saddening to find hords of people along Grant Ave (Or Dupont Street as the old Chinese San Franciscians call it), where they really should be is on Stockton Street, or in the little alleyways .  

While it can stink insanely bad on Kearny and Jackson, or on Stockton Street with all of the supermarkets, it's these little qualities that makes Chinatown to distinct to me.  No other neighborhood is quite like it.  My parents grew up here in Chinatown back in the 50s, and I love hearing stories of where they used to play, hang out, and where their friends used to live.  

Call me crazy, but I really get excited when I have to go to Chinatown.  My grandparents immigrated here to S.F back in the early 40s to late 50s, so I only feel it's right to honor where they lived by surrounding myself with all that Chinatown has to offer.  Look beyond the obscene old Chinese men spitting along the sidewalks, or the one's picking their noses in public, or the rude little old ladies shoving people with their grocery bags as they run to catch the 30 Stockton bus.  Keep in mind that in China thats acceptable.  So in actuality, you are pretty much as close to China as possible, here on this side of the Ocean.  

So my only advice to vistors, is to avoid the the superficiality of the souverior shops of Grant Ave, and venture towards Ross Alley, Waverly Street, and Spotford Alley.
author: Cass J.

description: Cheap fruit and veggie markets, great tiny muffins in a window, insane bus rides on the 30 that are way too overly packed, huge crowds along the street, awesome Chinese food that I haven't tried nearly enough of, bubble tea's, people spitting on the street, animals hanging in windows, inexpensive stores... it has its good and bad so three stars!
author: Meghan P.

description: UGHH NO! NEVER COMING BACK! it says 13.49 for 4 ppl but when i bill comes it turns out that it was 13.49 PER A PERSON! $108 is our total and this place isnt even good!
author: Kimm T.

description: If you want a fun experience walk from the FiDi up Grant or Stockton through Chinatown and into North Beach.  It's amazing to see how the neighborhood suddenly changes from Asian to Italian in one block.
author: Tim R.

description:
San Fransisco's Chinatown is by far my favorite in the entire country! I have been to all of the China towns in the US except for Portland's. http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chinatown
Unfortunately all of the pictures on our computer were wiped out. I have a few reviews pending but we have to reinstall a new application for photos on our computer. We had some beautiful pictures of Chinatown San Fransisco at night! 
It seems to me that you people in Northern California are a bit spoiled at least when it comes to the Chinatown there! You complain that it is dirty but it is clean compared to any of the 4 established China towns in NYC and one that is developing here! My criteria for 5 stars is , it has to be the best of it's kind. I do not know how to judge if it is best but it is the prettiest and my favorite. I have not been to Portland's Chinatown.
 Being from NYC it feels empty so not sure what everyone is complaining about. I think it is wonderful! And I do not feel like I will be bit by a rat eating dinner! like I do here in NYC!  And my Chinese but Brooklyn born husband loved it!
author: Pinky And The B.

description:
Chinatown... lots of chinese restaurants, shops and a lot of asians on one street. 
it can get very crowded with tourists but its a very interesting walk.


 ive heard its the biggest chinatown in the USA!
author: Deezoo

description:
I am half 4th generation Chinese-American from San Francisco.  My family used to own the famous Hang Ah tearoom.  My grandfather owned the first chinese-owned gas station (Shell) in chinatown (it is now demolished) and he also worked at the piers and built submarines. One of my great-great uncles was the first chinese person to own a house in SF.    My great-grandfather was murdered on Grant Street in chinatown in the early 1900's - it was a case of mistaken identity.   Of course it wasn't taken to the police.  Back in those days, chinatown was strictly segregated from the rest of SF, a city within a city.

My dad was born in chinatown and still knows all the streets and alleyways like the back of his hand.  My brother and I are in our thirties and we still get nervous and stay close to his heels as Dad leads us through his crazy shortcuts.  Aside from the cheesy tourist shops laden with some of the most offensive stereotypical souvenirs you can imagine, there are some real bargains and finds here; Affordable and delicious food, intricate gold jewelry with amazing craftmanship, fantastic imported items from asia, Sanrio and Sanrio knockoffs galore.  There is still a real sense of community here.

Although I often detest chinatown with it's fishy smells and the shoving, pushing, and yelling, it is a part of my  heritage and this is where I'm from. For that I can't help but feel a sense of pride as I walk through the streets, making sure the hems of my pants don't touch the filthy sidewalk.
author: Courtney Y.

description:
It happened one year that many of the parents in my class were Chinese.  I mean Old School Chinese.  And they were great.  They all showered me with food, which is always the best way to bribe me into giving your kid "special treatment." 

But it was Christmas when I raked up the schwag, and this year most of my stuff came from Chinatown shops.  Chinese bakery cakes, cookies, fruit, char si bau, platters of those greasy-ass sesame balls, See's candies (crosses all borders) and the occasional gift certificate.  I was stoked!  

In the morning, one of my favorite little girls came up to me as I was taking attendance and handed me a pretty red box with a big pink bow.  I gave her my shocked and surprised face, hugged her and thanked her profusely, swearing I would cherish it forever.  

"Will you wear it?"  She whispered bashfully into my ear. "Mommy let me pick it out in the store..."

She was staring at me with big, Bambi eyes and looking insecure about her present.  It was heartbreaking, so I decided to act like she'd just given me an Elizabeth Taylor sized diamond...or a crate of Yoo-Hoo.   "Wear it?"  I whispered back with great enthusiasm.  "Only EVERY DAY!"

As soon as the kids evacuated the room to go home, I greedily opened all of my loot.  I rejoiced in all of the goodies I was going to be gorging myself on for the next three hours (before hubby came to pick me up...I don't like sharing.)  All that was left was that pretty red box with the big pink bow.  I casually ripped the paper open and stuck my hand in the box.

Something...polyester...and itchy...with an obscene amount of sequins was in there.  Dread suddenly filled me as I finally pulled out the gift the little cutie had tried so hard to find, just for her teacher....the gift I swore to this big Bambi-eyed kid I would wear faithfully...EVERY DAY, and for God knows how long!  

She was in Kindergarten, so that would be...4 more years until she'd be out of Elementary school?!  "Muthafu#%ing, big-mouth, dumbsh%#t, assh!$le, dip-sh%#t, pin-head,  lame-brain, idiot, moron" quickly flowed through my head.

It was a bolero cut, tight as Hell, hoochie mama top made out of some mystery material apparently engineered to cause severe itching.  Size 2.  When I tried it on I looked like a Solid Gold Dancer reject....a deranged Rick James impersonator!  I looked at myself in horror and thought, 

"Holy Christ, I can't wear this in public!"  I was already humiliated at school once that year in a dodgeball/krunking incident...I really would rather not talk about it...

My husband ruptured a blood vessel in his forehead from laughing so hard when he saw me in it.  I, in turn, fractured my hand from beating him repeatedly until he passed out.

I wore the friggin' thing to school the first day back from Winter Break.  The kids were impressed with the sparkly gold material and grabbed my boobs all day long trying to get their hands on the little shiny sequins.  Bambi Eyes looked happiest of all.  She beamed a smile that made me wish I had matching kick-pleat pants to go with it.  After that, I didn't mind the stares of disgust, the insidious laughter, or the nasty rash I contracted from the scratching.

The next weekend, I was walking in Chinatown with my husband, looking for Dim Sum when a shiny glare hit my eyes, blinding me momentarily.  When I regained my sight, I looked up into the store window in front of us.  There, hanging on a satin hanger, was my Solid Gold Dancer uniform.   AND you had your choice of either matching hot pants or lovely leisure slacks to complete your ensemble.

Hubby looked at the pants.  Then looked at me.  Then looked at the pants.  Ran into the store.  And BOUGHT me the rest of that wretched outfit...

...and I look HOT.
author: Kristina R.

description:
After the disappointment of Washington DC's Chinatown, it's nice to see the one in San Francisco. It's hustly and bustly and typically Chinese.

We had a good wander through, got some lunch and bought ginseng. Mum and dad found it a haven in amongst all the hectic travel.
author: Yee Gan O.

description:
Two words, Love It! 

My only pet peeve is that there are many line cutters who think their time is more important than yours.

I damn near punched a little old lady when she cut in line.

TIPS: 
-when waiting in china town lines, have your payment in hand, wave it around like you just don't care. This will prevent most line cutters who "think" you already paid.
author: Keit K.

description:
1848 - The first Chinese immigrants arrive in San Francisco on the American brig, the Eagle. 

1859 - The first Chinese school is created in Chinatown because Chinese children are not allowed in the general public school system in San Francisco.  A growing number of Chinese laborers are settling down in what will become Chinatown.

1882 - The Chinese Exclusion Act bans immigration of Chinese laborers to the United States for 10 years.  In addition, with regards to all Chinese people, laborers or otherwise, already in the country or otherwise, "hereafter no State court or court of the United States shall admit Chinese to citizenship; and all laws in conflict with this act are hereby repealed."  The Act is passed by the Senate and the House of Representatives of the Forty-Seventh Congress of the United States of America.  The Act is subsequently renewed for another 10 years, twice, and is amended to be for an indefinite period of time in 1904.

1900 - The Tung Wah Dispensary opens in Chinatown.  This is the only hospital made available to Chinese people living in Chinatown.  During the bubonic plague outbreak at the turn of the century, the city's health department quarantined Chinatown rather than open health facilities to afflicted Chinese. 

1925 - The Tung Wah Dispensary is moved to its current location on Clay St. between Stockton and Powell and is renamed Chinese Hospital

1943 - Chinese Exclusion Repeal Act by Congress grants Chinese aliens naturalization rights

1975 - My parents get married 

1976 - My parents decide that they want better opportunities for both themselves and their children.  My father applies for internship programs in the United States even though he is already a doctor in Hong Kong.  He receives three acceptances: University of Vermont, University of Saskatchewan, and the University of Hawaii.  They choose Hawaii and they move immediately.  They don't know anyone there.

1978 - My father applies to residency programs on the mainland.  He is accepted into the orthopedics program at the University of Calfiornia, San Francisco and they move immediately.  They don't know anyone there.

1981 - My father begins his private practice.  Having been chief resident of orthopedics for 3 terms at UCSF, he has a number of offers from high-end medical groups around the city.  He chooses to work in Chinatown in order to be able to give back to the community.  Seriously, that's his reason.  His patients: little old chinese ladies who break their hips falling off the bus or crossing the street.  The hospital he works out of: Chinese Hospital on Clay St. between Stockton and Powell, the former Tung Wah Dispensary.  His office is in the medical building next door.

2007 - My father is still practicing medicine in Chinatown.  His patients: little old chinese ladies who break their hips falling off the bus or crossing the street.

A lot of people think this place is dirty or disgusting.  That's fine.  I'm not upset or angry.  They just don't have the background to appreciate how important a place like this is (a place where you can get some good comfort food or speak your own native tongue) to someone who has been completely (and intentially) uprooted from his home and everything he knows. People use words like "dirty", "smelly" and "gross" to describe this place.  Me?  I think this place is beautiful.
author: Sebastian N.

description:
*note-this review is dedicated to the punk asses who think it's funny to throw firecrackers 2 feet away from people waiting for the bus*

Here's a short list of things I hate about Chinatown:
-everybody smokes
-the spitting-'nuff said
-people see the red lights and don't walk signs as suggestions
-ma and pa kettle see nothing wrong with standing in the middle of the street blocking traffic in order to take a picture to send home to the kids on the farm
-the smell-eww.

Ok, maybe I'm being a bit harsh but I feel a hell of a lot better now.  Thanks for letting an old man vent a bit.
author: phil h.

description:
I lived in Chinatown for a few months, and although I was excited by the potential for adventure and immersing myself in a fascinating culture, the thrill wore out quickly.

Maybe it's a cultural norm, but I got tired of being stared at all the time.  

I got tired of little old ladies seeing me come out of my building, asking if I lived there, and then scowling and sneering when I answered yes.  

I got tired of dodging spit.  

I got tired of having to travel across the city (Sunset and Richmond) to get good Chinese food.  

I got tired of walking in the street to pass slow moving herds of tourists.  

I got tired of the fireworks at all hours of the night.  

I got tired of seeing the sketchy "massage parlors" on my block.  

I got tired of my cramped little apartment with a kitchen wall instead of a kitchen. 

And I got tired of knowing that while I felt crowded with one roommate, every other unit in the building was the same size but housed three or four times as many people.

I still love Chinatown for buying fun crap on the cheap, for Mark at the Buddha Lounge and for the produce markets, and I miss standing on my roof at night with the 360 degree city skyline, but I will never move back.
author: Quinn S.

description:
Where else can you get an enormous leather jacket for $90. And have it tailored for your arm length at that. 

Where else can I buy silver and gold coins from all over the world?(For very cheap) No where that I know of. 

The food and culture is great. The trinkets are great. I also recommend getting a Cast Iron Tea Pot or a Jade sculpture of yourself - I am sure if you have some coin - it can be arranged. LOL

Now as to where you can park - I have not found a good legal place to park. - good luck with that.
