The fish is fresh. The Lo Mein is tasty. And the trolley is cheap.
author: Aaron D.

description:
I love Chinatown. I love dim sum. I love Kites. I love tourist attractions. I love walking Grant st. That being said, you should know that....

San Francisco's Chinatown is a POSER. 
That's right. I said it. A POSER.

But Andrew! What?.. Why do you say that?...

I say that because before the Great Quake of 1906, San Francisco's Chinatown was quite different and the current "Chinatown" was planned and placed to be the tourist attraction it is today.

In Victorian times (pre-quake) Chinatown was a little more northwest and was simply an area where Chinese-American Immigrants lived in mass. Land ownership for Chinese men was sparse and limited to the wealthy few. In fact, there was a lot of xenophobia towards the area. Attitudes might be equated to modern popular sentiment towards shanty-towns and hobo villages.

For the white folk, Chinese-American Immigrants were barbaric, exotic and the sight-to-see. It used to be the thing to do to have a guided tour through the streets to watch these 'savages' live, talk, interact, etc. It was considered a great scare for the women folk and a penis contest for the men... Oh, an adventure to visit Chinatown... The initial 'tourist attraction' was more like exploitation. 

After the quake, politicians were eager to recreate (at a larger scale) the tourist attractions of San Francisco to bring people back. One being Chinatown. A location was chosen from the rubble to be redeveloped  (Ever wonder why there's a very Catholic church smack dab in the center of Chinatown?)... From there, architecture from buildings to lamp posts were designed to emulate "oriental/Asiatic" designs. And VOILA! You have San Francisco Chinatown.

What we have now is a neat staple in the city. It continues to thrive as a diaspora for Chinese-Americans, and I love dim sum! But there's a lot of really neat history behind the area that a lot of people don't know! It would be better if there was a way to integrate educational tools into the area. 

I'm also one for closing the street off and turning the area into a pedestrian way! 

The end.
author: Andrew C.

description:
Call me weirdo but I use this part of SF to test a guy Im dating.  I enjoy cooking and love shopping for fresh cheap produce/meat.  If a guy cant handle the smell or is claustrophobic of the fob crowd, then most likely I cant date you.  I want a guy that can get me 1/2 lbs of frog legs when I need it.

Also, I never regret having dimsum here.  Chefs are guaranteed to have the freshest ingredients available.  I had brunch here today with friends after a long night of craziness. There is nothing better than having family/friend gather for dimsum brunch on Sundays.
author: Rovie T.

description:
Here are the reasons why I don't like Chinatown:

1.  The traffic up in this bitch couldn't get any worse.
2.  99% of the pedestrians NEVER follow the laws of the road; i.e. crossing on a red, jaywalking, ect.
3.  People seem to think hawking lugies and blowing snot rockets all over the place is an OK practice in society- and it's absolutely disgusting.
4.  It often smells like rank ass.
5.  Could there BE any more double parkers???
6.  Oh you're looking for a parking spot, are you?  Ha- good luck with that.
7.  Dirty, filthy sidewalks.
8.  Seriously- are this many freaking yellow zones necessary?
9.  All those stores that sell tons of cheap, useless crap that just ends up as clutter and garbage.
10.  All the meters have a one-hour limit.
11.  I often end up having a conniption fit whenever I drive through Chinatown.
12.  Rats and weird mutant horse flies.

The things I like about Chinatown:

1. My favorite Pho place is there.


Thats it- hence the 1 star.
author: Genevieve M.

description:
Let me preface this - I hate crowds.  Hate them.  Especially slow-moving crowds on narrow smelly sidewalks.  So knowing my own limitations, I rarely venture into Chinatown.  However, I took my visiting seven year old niece through Chinatown and learned to see it through a whole new set of eyes.  

Did you know that from a seven year old perspective:

~ A little 'jade' monkey purchased from a wizened lady sitting next to the door of a mysterious shop can turn into a magical charm?

~ It's really cool to not be able to read the signs?

~ Chinese groceries are the most fascinating places on earth because lots of the fruits and vegetables are so strange looking?

~ Listening to all the voices speaking a language you don't understand can make you giggle?

~ Life is only complete if you can convince your auntie to buy you a set of embroidered pink satin pajamas and little flat shoes?

~ It's very tiring to look at absolutely everything, explore the recesses of every shop and try a little dim sum all while having one's eyes open to their widest possible extent?

Thanks to my niece I have rediscovered the fun and joy of exploring a truly - for me - alien environment right in my own back yard.
author: Suzanne B.

description:
Three Words:  Joy Luck Club.
Oh wait, here's another two:  Waverly Place.
Bush Street is pretty cool too.
author: Ivy W.

description:
Perhaps it was my grandparents fleeing Bolshevik Russia and finding safe harbor in Harbin, China, before jumping a tramp steamer out of Shanghai for San Francisco. Or, perhaps, it was nothing more than my family's yen for Chinese food.

Nevertheless, my dad, a true aficionado of spicy Chinese food (and probably the women too, truth be told) took us kids into the bowels of Chinatown often. So often that we were masters of "chopstick-do" long before we could use a fork "European style". We lived off Green Street back then and whenever dad got the hankering (he really liked to hanker a lot and they didn't call him "Terrible Teddy" for nothing), it was off to Chinatown. And as we grew, our love for this seedy section of the City never waned. The sights, the smells, the sounds, the pools of vile street fluid no test could accurately determine the ingredients of...it was all cool to us. 

My twin and I shared almost every adult birthday here trying the hidden, off the main drag holes-in-the-wall. We'd play around the twin temple dogs at the entrance and starting on one side, ate our way right around to the other, fattened like pigs ready for slaughter. It didn't matter a whit that we had to tussle and fight for a seat in some of the joints, or even speak Chinese. We were just happy in our "second Shanghai" search for the best of Chinese chow. It would sometimes take hours and there are so many small shops serving delicious Chinese fare, I can't single one but I can't recall a totally bad one. You just had to remind yourself that what goes on in the backroom kitchen is best an unknown. 

Every major city lays claim to a "Chinatown" but they all pale in comparison to The Chinatown, San Francisco's very own.

P.S., if you're a virgin, watch "Blade Runner" before going and it won't be far-off the mark.
author: Robin Z.

description:
Here are some of my favorite things about Chinatown:

1. Live frogs in tubs of water -- Aww he's so cute. Wait, don't get attached. I think the fat one is calling your name for dinner.

2. Smells like vagina -- Not mine, but you know. 

3. Bok Choy hanging on metal fences to dry -- I think the ones with pieces of rust on them are supposed to taste better.

4. In Chinatown, no kleenex allowed -- Plug one nostril with index finger and blow. Anywhere.


All jokes aside, I really do love Chinatown. It's a completely raw experience and you see nothing but hard-working people trying to make a living. You can get all kinds of yummy sauces and some delicious fruit. Plus, my peepo give good deal fo' cheapskate!
author: Jen Y.

description:
I feel many people are intimidated by chinatown, and few really know it beyond the "tourist" levels. 

Chinatown has so many great shops and restaurants and can be kind of a maze if you are unfamiliar with it, Driving through it can be intimidating for those who truly don't know their vehicle.

Walking can also be tedious to some, many get stuck in the density of the masses of people. you snooze you lose pretty much. 

Once you truly know chinatown though, you love it.
author: Bruce W.

description:
The best place to load up on inexpensive groceries [although not organic] and SF souvenirs. If you want good deals on postcards or t-shirts [any other SF paraphernalia, for that matter], head down to Grant Avenue. 

Generally, it's overcrowded. 

Through the years, I've learned to maneuver the crowds, but for a first-timer or novice, it can be quite the task. I hate wandering the streets when it rains because other people's umbrellas are quite intrusive. No matter how well-covered you are by your own umbrella, there's always someone shorter to shake the rain onto you.

The restaurants, compared to many others in the area, are mediocre [although cheap], and the bakeries are quite good [Golden Gate always has a line out the door.]... Some of the streets smell bad too. Sometimes it's really the essence of Chinatown, other times it's just a stinky tofu restaurant [especially on Jackson].

On weekends, you can park down by the Embarcadero and take a shuttle up. It's around $5 and is better than driving around in circles, looking for spots on Chinatown's hills. I'd do this because driving in Chinatown alone can be horrendous. Traffic signals? What traffic signals?

Despite its faults, I wouldn't trade it for anything else.
author: Tinna H.

description:
Crowded, Smelly and Good Deals!

I've been shopping here many times through out my 2 years of living in San Francisco. Every time I come around Chinatown I find amazing artwork and authentic knickknack's. I enjoy discovering new things that Chinatown has to offer...

However, it is quit stinky on all the horizontal streets and a majority of the parallel ones...

CLEAN IT UP!
author: Dee C.

description:
i was born in s.f. chinatown in the chinese hospital a while ago. though i only lived there a few years before moving to oaktown, i always have fond memories of frisco chitown. the good, bad, and the ugly. it's all part of me. 

i go there less often now. but i always look forward to visting my home again, seeing the old sites, seeing what's new, watching the old folks, and watching the tourists.

i can't hate what is a part of me.

i'm not a salmon so i'm not going back there to spawn and die.

i just like to go home, rejuvenate my roots and move on.
author: Victor G.

description:
At six forty-eight am on a Sunday morning it is silent in Chinatown.

That is about the only time it is as such.
Trust me, I know - I live right smack in the middle of it all... 

I heart living here, though... it is urban culture at it's best.
...And, it's worst.
author: Kate R.

description: Oneof the best Chinatowns in America.  So many shops, restaurants, groceries - and so much to learn. A cultural treasure.
author: Karen F.

description:
Authentic chinese food! 

This place is dirty and smelly but delightfully fun!

You get to experience the culture in a whole different way. 

Its a fun place to just chill and walk around enjoy a beautiful culture..

Also cute stores with merchandise you cant find anywhere else in the city.
author: Jessica M.

description:
I have mixed feelings about Chinatown.  On one hand, it's one of the richest places in America where you can experience Chinese American culture, through food, history, and even grocery shopping.  On the other hand, Chinatown is a ghetto.

On several occasions, I've visited relatives of friends in Chinatown.  What a lot of people don't see are the living conditions in some of these buildings, two or three bathrooms that are meant to serve an entire floor of tenants, the smell of urine in the hallways, rusted pipes, like ivy, climbing the walls between buildings.

Of course, living in an ethnic enclave has its upsides as well as its downsides.  For many this is a place of community where you don't have to speak English to find work but few have the luxury of social mobility.

I'd like to think it's changing.  In New York, for instance, Chinatown is actually one of the hip places to live these days.  But go north of the border into Canada, and you see an entirely different kind of Chinatown with modern buildings, bustling commerce, and spotless facilities more reflective of modern Asian life in cities such as Hong Kong.

Of course, there's nostalgia.  Having dim sum with my family, picking  up fresh fish and vegetables at various markets, are memories that will stay with me forever.  But as Chinatown continues to age, as it already no longer represents what it used to be--home to the largest Chinese population outside of China--I'd love to see a time when Chinatown catches up with the rest of the world.
author: Tony L.

description:
Fun times...

...and good exercise.
Most streets are at a 45 degree angle so you must be in good shape to be walking around all day.
I've never been to China, but this is how I would imagine it.

Good luck finding parking.
Use the cable cars to get here.
author: Realtor Karl B.

description:
I'm going to find and marry the man that manufactures and distributes the pink plastic bags to Chinatown. I will retire a wealthy woman with a limitless supply of unwashed vegetables, small personalized CA license plates, smelly herbs, and Hello Kitty charms. 

If that doesn't happen, I'll form a miniature army and begin the hunt for David Lo Pan. I'll search every alley - high and low! - and won't stop until I've found him. Then I will ask him for a ride in his wheelchair.

And if for whatever reason that doesn't pan out either, I'll join forces with the dirty fortune cookie factory and invent an updated version of the "Adult Finger Trap". 

(Minus 1 star for the little kids pissing down storm drains - now that's just nasty.)
author: Katelin H.

description: This chinatown is cool I think way better than L.A. thats for sure! lol It has  lots of shoppes and of course the chinese restaurants I went to this authentic chinese restaurant where I sat on the floor and me and my friends ate family style! really cool. On the other hand I think china town is dirty and kinda ghetto...
author: Tawny P.

description: I know a lot of people like this Chinatown but I find it a bit kitsch with rows of Chinese shops selling San Francisco T-shirts, cheap imports and other tourist drawcards. The positive is there quite a few little bakeries and food spots to chow down on Chinese but even in those restaurants, the quality was quite variable. Surprisingly not my fave Chinatown spot.
author: JJKay

description: Walked forever to get there! OMG haha it was raining so much that my boots were super soaked by the time I got there that I had to buy rain boots. Other than that I liked it, got me some tea. Black lycee tea so delicious.
author: Team NB F.

description:
Come here if you have nowhere to go in a hurry. Narrow streets are usually blocked by trucks, fake antiques from those gaudy "antique" shops probably owned by the mafia (Who buys this shit???? Gigantic gilded, marble lion with a monkey swinging from it...who buys this shit??? Besides The Donald?), and a billion aimless, slack-jawed tourists. 

Avoid this place if you lead a sheltered, corporate life and your immunity is low, because the exposure to the various viral brews of foreigners, geezers and children might just push your sniffle into a full-blown cold/flu.

Great place to shop for Asian decor, feng shui gear, brocade goods, Bee & Flower soaps, Asian cookware and dinnerware, novelty items. Not the best place for Chinese food.

Note: You know those PopPop things that you throw on the ground to make a loud mini-explosive snap? Be careful where you throw it. My friend got yelled at by a 4-foot tall camphor-scented granny for freaking her out with the PopPop. "AIYAHHHHHH!!!! &$%#&!!"
author: Trixie J.

description:
I work 2 blocks from the entrance and never enter this place. What I see eminating from this foul arena is oh so horrific!

*** Shitloads of pink plastic bags flying through the sky, wrapping themselves on street poles, wrapping themselves across pedestrian's heads and temporarily blinding them as the walk into traffic on Bush Street. 

*** Shitloads of pink plastic bags, packed full of useless shit, trinkets, giant rice bags, and the sort, in shitloads of people's hands swarming the sidewalks that exit the arena of Chinatown. 

*** Shitloads of pink plastic bags flying high into the sky, to land in the Pacific Ocean and add to the 42 square miles of plastic shit garbage floating in a circle around the Pacific Rim.
author: Braden B.

description:
Alright lets get this straight people.

When you are in Chinatown, you are in a whole different world. This isn't a land where people are walking around politely with their eyes looking forward and saying excuse me. 

You are literally living in a fusion of old and new China. I say this because when I was growing up in Hong Kong, part of the city is modern, with bustling skyscrapers and business people and modern day sanitation. 

Then there was the outskirts of the city. Full of old school, traditional buildings and how life use to be.. slow and dirty, but still a way of life back then.

Bringing it back to America, those two cultures clash in what is known as Chinatown. On one hand, you have the old fashion chinese that "do obscene things" on the street. For them, its normal to do that kind of stuff back in their homeland, but since moving to hear, they consider Chinatown like home. Hence they bring their habits here.

Yeah, I know Wilson, its really sick and disgusting to see this in America, but hey, there are other Chinatowns around the bay you can hit. It is a dirty place, but not as bad as it is over back in Mainland China.

/rant
author: Wilson L.

description:
SF has possibly one of the dirtiest Chinatowns, and that's what makes it truly authentic. Despite the jam-packed buses, despite the jaywalkers who make it hell for drivers to get around, and despite the hostile old women pushing their way through the crowds, I love it here.

JONASAPPROVED!
author: Jonas T.

description:
What's that smell? Chinatown! Is that Yoda? Nope just a hunched over man.

There are lots of cheap things here to buy, cheap vegetables that seem like they were altered in some way or are from last week, cheap meat but I don't know how you can make meat so cheap and actually make profit (eek), cheap cheap things that might fall apart, tasty bou (buns), a good variety of tea shops, and lots of milk tea. One star gone because there is spit all over the street, more so compared to any other district (even the mission wow!) Another star taken away because I keep gettin the stink eye. I guess I should get rid of this tattoo on my face that says "give me stink eye now."
author: S D.

description:
Where else do old women blow snot rockets?

Technically, I live here. When asked, however, I usually say I live in North Beach since I am only a block or 2 from the lovely Italian flag striped phone poles. And also, I'm 1/2 Italian, so somehow that makes it feel more right. But I digress...

Chinatown is the only place in the city where I feel tall. Props for that. Also, I can go around the corner and get a full bag of produce for about $1.50  - granted i have to eat it within hours or it will all spontaneously combust...or just rot...but who's counting...

The tourists are annoying, and the crowds piling onto the Dirty 30 I could do without. There is also always an assortment of underwear and fish being dried out my neighbors' windows. Ew. and Ewer.

As for the snot rockets, Fing ew. It's just so rotten.

All said, I feel pretty safe here and have a sweet pad with a garage, laundry and a patio and deck...so I ain't movin'!
author: Diane S.

description:
EW!
Is there any clean China Town? HELL NO!
It won't be China if it's clean.
You don't even feel China if it's clean.
why not?
they have a rat big like a dog, True story.
I do like Chinese food in general but  I try not to go to Grant and Stockton.
I have heard that local "Asians" won't eat in there.
San Francisco's Chinatown is the oldest, largest and the most filthy disgustingly dirty Chinatown outside of China, in North America.

Well, I'll be darned if its clean. But I know it won't happen.
author: Nobu K.

description:
Bought two ducks here. Had heads, no feathers. They was dead. Cooked  'em up niiiiice n easy in the oven. Stuffed 'em with figs even. Walked alllll through C-town to find them, these nice, juicy, dee-liciousy ducks. Had to break off the heads. Those cute lil webbed feet too.  

Next time we hope to get us some live ones and get em ready for the oven on my rooftop.

Ew, does that sound totally gross? Actually, it was pretty cool to be so close to our meal, and to take part in the preparation. The ducks were quite tasty. And they were about 1/3 the price of anything you'd find in Whole Foods. (I love you, WF. I HATE you!!! Wait, I take that back. I love you.)
author: Sahra H.

description:
One of the most ubiquitous items will soon disappear from  Chinatown- those pink plastic bags....I often tell people walking around in Union Sq asking directions to Chinatown- "Just follow the trail of pink bags heading straight up on Stockton and walk through the tunnel - or for a more scenic view- go up on Grant-still watch for that trail of pink bags :-D"
So go ahead and bag one these things- from cheap hoodie shirts and knock off bags to jade and rolex watches.  Make sure to eat at one of the restaurants IN Chinatown, get a drink at the Buddha Bar or get a souvenir of cable car snow globe! Soon you'll be totting your pink bags with both hands :-D
author: Arissa C.

description: First let me uncoil my body from the pretzel position the sinkhole of a bed they put us in. No heat until 6PM guys, but they will give you space heater to warm yourself by, after showing up with icicle nose at the front desk. Don't forget safety pins! You'll need them to keep drapes closed, in case you find the view of barbwire and no screen on your window disconcerting. One more hit, bring your own shampoo as to not offend others. Enjoy!
author: Jerry A.

description: Still my favorite Chinatown in the US!
author: Elena N.

description:
Probably one of the most soul-less places I've been to outside of Tijuana and Walmart.

Everyone everywhere trying to pedal cheap junk.  Really cheap junk.  Maybe I'm just referring to the main tourist strip--who knows, maybe there's more to it than the facade of Grant Ave.

Also I've never been to a restaurant in C-town that I'd really call great.

I did however get some really cheap cable car Christmas ornaments, along with some magnets that were probably hand-painted by homeless orphans for pennies on the dollar.

The one magnet has a sticker on it that says "contains lead".

LOL!
author: Rocco B.

description:
Mee luv you long time!

This is the only place where you walk around and see residents hanging fish on clothing lines to dry...........................classic!
author: Victoria S.

description: A great place to take a walk when you miss the bustling streets of Asia. When you get mowed down by someone's  four foot tall Chinese grandmother, think of it as adding to the authenticity of the experience. And to reward yourself for keeping calm under the pressure of the crowds, pop into Golden Gate Bakery for the best egg custard tart in the whole world.
author: Miriam W.

description:
This is a good place to start your Xmas shopping. There are lots of deals and quirky cute gifts. There is also lots of beautiful jewelry. I have to constantly remind myself that I am shopping for other people dammit

I love china town because it is like treasure hunting. You never know what you will find.
author: Melissa B.

description:
I have to say, this was one of the highlights on my trip to San Francisco.  It was one of the "tourist must see" places on my trip itinerary and it was well worth it!

The atmosphere is great - people everywhere, great decorations, a mix of American and Asian architecture, and $1.88 Tshirts as far as the eye can see.  Though most of the tourist shops on Grant Ave are repeats of one another and pedal cheap San Francisco novelty gifts, I still couldn't help but go in each one just to browse.  And for the picky among you, there are also some great shopping finds there if you're willing to look.

Though I only got to stop in 2 restaurtants along Grant street, I enjoyed  the food and would love to try out some more places if I ever get the chance to make a return trip to the area.  

So to sum up - If you're taking a trip to San Francisco this is a definite place to stop!
author: Angela Z.

description:
I was going to give it 2 stars, but I can't honestly say "Meh. I've experienced better" because, well, I haven't been to another Chinatown yet.

I live very close to C-Town (it could be argued that I live in C-Town, but I say I live in Russian Hill), and I find myself avoiding it as much as possible. It's dirty, it smells, it's crowded, there are dead birds hanging in windows... it's just depressing to me. Back when I had a job (ha, ha) I would catch either the (dirty) 30 or the 45 on Stockton at about 6 am when the shops are getting their deliveries. There was always this one truck that stopped right in front of the bus stop, and I kid you not- this truck would be full of loose, dead animals. Not wrapped up or anything. Just tossed in the back. The driver was really nice, he made small talk with me most mornings while pulling chickens out of his truck. One time I bumped into him with a pig thrown over his shoulder. Pretty unappetizing if you ask me.

I will give Chinatown credit for its cultural appeal, cheap produce, and unique merchandise. If you're visiting from out of town, you must at least take a walk down Grant, just to see it. Although it's not my favorite place in San Francisco, the main reason I love this city is because of it's many different, diverse attractions- including Chinatown.
author: Christine K.

description:
Where else can you find the following?

Live chickens (that can be slaughtered) for your dinner
Old ladies carrying pink plastic bags
Overcrowded 30 & 45 MUNI lines
Old ladies trying to enter the rear door of a bus, while you are trying to exit
Take-out dim sum spots on every other block
Vitasoy milk cheaper than anywhere else in the Bay Area
People crossing streets with utter disregard for the color of the light
Cars double parked on every block

All these things you can experience yourself, first hand in SF's Chinatown!
author: Daniel M.

description:
I love visiting here.  Great food at low prices if you do your homework online before you go.  Lots of very cheap shopping.  Unless you want the tourist experience, stay OFF Grant Ave.  Overpriced junk.  Shop and exlpore Stockton St and its side streets.  Stockton St is where the locals shop. 

If you're an easily offended, stuck-up WASP, don't go here.  The locals spitting and the bad smells are not as bad as many would claim, but if you're looking for a reason to be offended, you'll find plenty.

If you're an adventurous traveler and like authentic ethnic experiences and food, you'll love it.
author: Art C.

description:
The real Chinatown is actually the streets that surround Grant.

There you can find everything from mystic medicine shops to seafood centers to all the lychee nuts and durian you can eat! When I go to Chinatown, that is what I explore. You see so much awesome stuff and you get to truely experience what Chinatown is.
author: Aoecean G.

description: i am here everyday cause i work here at the YMCA. great asian culture to discover!
author: Calvin T.

description:
This isn't my favorite place in the City. It smells, and people push you around a lot, and it smells, and whenever I turn around I see a duck hanging in a window with all of his clothes off and he's TOO tan (there IS such a thing, you know!) and he's all sweaty. Gross!

I do like the cool deals you can find in some of the little ticky tack stores: paper parisols, noisy little firecracker strings, red envelopes, joss paper, and the folding fans.... cool stuff! super cheap! ("For you, only $1... only for YOU.")

I'm a borderline vegetarian, though, and my squeamishness (though I AM half Chinese) is hard to overcome sometimes. Plus, I will go rambo on someone's ass if I see defenseless baby turtles in little sad bug cages, with barely any water and fake palm trees in it. I will go RAMBO on the MOFO.
author: Shari D.

description: i love chinatown. only because it gives me something to do if i have nothing else to do in the city. has plenty of places to eat, random shops to buy touristy things. walking distance from other shopping areas so all in all this place is a must stop. park far and walk there.
author: Rainier V.

description:
Pros:
cheap food (stinky tofu) and items

my bank has a location here

Cons: 
spit/snot all over the sidewalk and streets

smells bad

crowded

rude people who push you out of the way to get on the bus first. Or get a seat on the bus.

they walk SLOW and when you try to go around them, they suddenly walk to the side for no apparent reason

they cross in the middles of the street. 

they cross when it's a red light.

the dried foods hanging up with flies all over them

one store has an item for X amount. The next block down it's cheaper or more expensive. And it can taste better or worse. You really have to know which store to buy it from.

If they know that you're a tourist, or ABC (American Born Chinese) they'll jack up the prices knowing that you'll still pay it.

Speaking from personal experience, and I'll update later when I find out the store name and exact location. But the shop with a bunch of lighters in the store front on Grant St. and ( I think) California St. I wanted to buy 2 cool looking lighters. He quoted me $10 each. I gave him my credit card and he had charged me $15 each. When I asked him about it, he said "no. I told you they were $15 each." I should have torn up the credit card slip (it was done the old fashioned way by "clacker")  but I wanted them too much. After signing it, he then writes "no returns and no exchanges" on it. I got home and calculated the $30 plus tax and  he still overcharged me by a few dollars. GGGGRRRR!!!!!
I called my credit card company to complain but they said "if you signed it, it's your responsibility."

So I seem to have more cons than pros.
Chinatown: San Francisco's "Raison d'Etre"
author: Jennifer P.

description:
Chinatown is always amusing. Unlike the sad attempt of our Japantown, Chinatown actually feels like its own little world with of course a ton of Chinese restaurants and funky shops as well as some fancy antique stores.

I like to walk through Chinatown from North Beach as I make my way downtown. It's always crowded with shoppers, which amazes me. The elderly Chinese men and women seem to shop far more than my friends and I do! I've found a mix of treasures and throw-away trinkets, like gorgeous jade bracelets as well as some funky items that are fun nonetheless.

Once you've been through it a few times, you narrow down your favorite dim sum places and of course, the infamous Buddah Bar. Recently, I randomly took a walking tour of Chinatown and found it fascinating. We visited places I would have never noticed before--such as really traditional temples and a store where you can purchase paper replicas of just about anything you might need in the afterlife. Fascinating. 

It's definitely a must for entertaining out-of-towners, whether you're a local or a tourist, Chinatown is always a fun and interesting trip.
author: Sophie D.

description:
Stopped by for the 18th annual Autumn Moon Festival, although I didn't know it was happening! I was just strolling down the streets, showing my visitor our Chinatown, when I noticed that the streets were blocked and there were many, many booths. I don't think I've ever seen Chinatown this crowded. I mean people weren't only confined to the streets, pushing and elbowing you and side swiping you with their pink grocery bags, but they were out on the road as well...in a huge mass. There were people EVERYWHERE.

The Chinatown in SF is my fave and I've been to Oakland's, New York's, LA's and even abroad such as in Australia. I don't know what it is, but there is definitely a "rawness" (as Jennifer Y. states) to the place. People are not afraid to show their true self here are are non-conformists in any way.

I've grown up going to Chinatown so I'm used to being shoved around without an apology, smelling the fresh fish and the not so fresh sewer smells and seeing snot rockets and loogies shooting from orifices. But by all means, please visit Chinatown and come for the cheap trinkets, fresh produce, bakeries and dim sum items and of course, for the true Chinatown experience.
author: Janel Y.

description: We spent a morning here. There was not much open but, it was kind of cool because the place was busy preparing for the day. We really enjoyed watching everyone. We were starving and stopped in a bakery. I tried a very savory roll with green onion. I could have eaten 50 of them. It was so good. Stopped by the fortune cookie factory. It is very small, located in one of the back alleys which was cool. Loved the free sample. Next time we will take a tour and eat lunch.
author: Ellie S.

description:
Like many locals in SF, I have a love and hate relationship with Chinatown. The people there are rude, it smells (like fish -because old ladies sell fish out of a bag on the sidewalk w/o ice), and there are many gross sights (i.e. dangling ducks, pigs feet, flies everywhere, some guy sitting on the sidewalk with a HUGE tumor on his leg asking for money, etc.). BUT where else can you go (besides in the Mission) to buy 5 days of  groceries for $10???
Today for $10 I bought: 3 nectaries, green onions, shallots, 6 garlic, Chinese broccoli, tofu, noodles, onion, sweet peas, 3 tomatoes, reg. broccoli, 2 bell peppers, 2 lemons, ginger, so much more, etc...
Tips: bring cash, be patient, don't buy any meat or fish, and TRIPLE wash your veggies.
author: Kat F.

description: It's so fun.  Oldest Chinatown in America or some such thing.  Come check it out.  Bring a camera and a appetite.
author: Cynthia B.

description:
I tend to avoid Chinatown at times, but not for any disturbing reason...I avoid it because it is one fucking hilly ass area. Other than that it has some awesome dim sum shops, a great place to get bargains on cell phones and cell related products. I like the Chinese movie shops around there. The always have good selections and are reasonable on their prices (again, bargain). It's not the cleanest part of SF...but I frequent other dirty areas of SF so I can't hate on a place with a long history.

If you ever get parking here, never get rid of it.

5 Big Red Ones
author: James J.

description:
Other than Golden Gate Bakery, Lucky Creation Vegetarian, Washington Bakery, Jai Yun, and maybe one or two places on Stockton that sell Chinese BBQ, plus some shops, there's no other reasons to come to Chinatown. This place is overcrowded, flithy, and full of oddball characters, including the pro communist grandpa always seen standing on a chair wearing a bright red shirt on the corner of grant and washington, chanting down with (insert the latest name of the Taiwanese president) or some anti communist political figure. He fits in right there with the rest of the loonies (and I don't mean Candian coins).

The roof level of Portsmouth Square parking lot is a sad sight...lots of old retired Chinese people who don't have family caring for them, just hanging out either playing Chinese chess or smoking/chatting just to kill time...until their time comes. The nearby public toilets you don't even want to come anywhere near them, and the city does nothing to keep them clean. This is the Hong Kong equivalent of Statue Square on the weekends, except they're not Fillipina maids. And what an excellent location to hold the summertime weekend night market right in this very spot; the moment you take the elevator from parking your car, you are treated to elbow to elbow crowds and the smell of shizzle and pizzle from the nearby public toilets. Add to the fact that stores try to pimp counterfeits made in China on the stalls from stock they can't get rid of, or really mediocre and overpriced product, you have a winning "nostalgic" event that makes Chinatown that much more worthwhile to go to. Sigh.

Grocery shopping might be an experience for some, but you'll be fighting with immigrants from China who only speak the Toyshanese dialect, who treat the streets like their own living room and block foot traffic, and who practically come here everyday or live around here because they don't know any English to venture anywhere else.

Maybe 2nd or 3rd+ gen Chinese Americans need this place to reconnect with their roots (and of their forefathers/mothers), but honestly they should just fly to their home villages or cities in China, Hong Kong, or wherever their ancestors came from to discover the REAL roots.

Then again maybe SF has it luckier, because other states don't have places (or dumps) as big as this. (The Chinatown in Portland is even smaller and almost as sad, but cleaner).
author: Ken K.

description:
Stroll.... I mean stroll.  You cannot breeze through Chinatown in a hurry.  Don't stop at Starbuck's and down your triple tall latte.  You will have too much energy for Chinatown.  The herds of people are NOT in a hurry... unless some bakery just pulled out their steamed pork buns and all of the Chinese knows at what time.

It's fun.. it's exciting.  Yummy food, smoke filled air, and 3,000 year old grandmas spitting all over the place.  

That my friend, is fine living.
author: Emily S.

description:
Chinatown is filthy.

We were walking our dogs through Chinatown on Mason, as we made our way from Huntington Park down to Washington Square (and then to Trieste to complete our Saturday morning ritual).  As we minced along the dirty sidewalks, forcing our dogs to avoid eating the piles and piles of garbage, discarded food items, and worse, one of them cut his pad rather severely on one of the myriad pieces of broken glass that litter the sidewalks.

I like the idea of Chinatown, and frequent it often for restaurants and shops, but a little sanitation would go a long way.
author: Pete G.

description: I would say I am a little biased but I love Chinatown.. the food is amazing and the smell of food everywhere is intoxicating!
author: Lynn C.

description:
I always wanted to be on a game show. In particular I wanted to be on MXC. A visit to Takeshi's Castle was on my list of 42,000 things to do before I die. Sadly, that show isn't around anymore but I can get almost the same experience by visiting Chinatown! And for the record, I do know that MXC is a play on a JAPANESE game show, whatever, let me write this. 

I start at the Grant Street entrance, put on some Pizzicato 5, and then whip myself around in circles until almost unconscious, scream out  "Let's go!", then take off running full throttle down the street. In my mind I hear Kenny Blankenship and Vic Romano giving me my own personal tour. "Stop at the Tea House!" "Watch out for that loogie!" "Grab that $2.99 shirt!" "Take a shot at the Buddha!" 

Chinatown is always a fun visit. Tea houses, dim sum, chotchkes, fortune cookie factory, cheap socks and tee's, pastries, and dollar toys. 

Check it out, I promise Guy LeDouche won't be featuring you in the Most Painful Elimination of the Day.
author: Delta C.

description:
Updating the location from one to two stars. 

I passed by that crazy old man that stands on a bucket and repeats "Happy, happy, happy" to get people to read his sign. He's cool. Why? Because my friend Dingster back at Cal won his student government election campaign with the same slogan. 

=====================

The place reeks of fish. It smells, people spit, and it's an absolute dingy neighborhood. I hold my breath every time I drive by it. Yes, even the car A/C circulates the outside smelly air in.  Every time I read about Chinatown in SFGate.com, besides the festivities, the news lately has been about how a bunch of Chinatown teens beat up on some Hispanics, and it's being viewed as a hate crime, how another bunch of Chinatown teens beat up and harassed this benevolent homeless person, or how these Chinese people are extorting money from Chinatown businesses. It's great for tourists to browse through in the day, but it's got hidden secrets at night. I don't like shady places like this.
author: Cathy H.

description:
I really enjoyed Chinatown. There were so many great looking buildings and so many different things to look at. Very crowded on Grant street with a lot of touristy shops. If you really like something in one shop, you can find it in a bunch of the other shops...so shop around for the best price you can find.

I would love to go back again and have more time to spend exploring the areas other than Grant street.
author: Ericka S.

description: Hit or miss, depending on where you're going and what you're doing. Some food is great, other places not so great. Same with the produce shops. I guess all in all you should just be aware of, and prepared to, stand your ground. I've never been around so many pushy and rude people in all my life. Personally I don't care for it, it's mostly for the historic aspect. But occasionally I find a shop or two that tickles my fancy ;-)
author: Brad Y.

description:
Clement is the Chinese-America town. I'm down with the peoples in the old Chinatown!

SF Chinatown is unique in the Americas because of the proximity to China. It has a flavor and history unlike any other place, Asia or otherwise. In fact, Chinatown has become much smaller than it was. Recent government/private sector scams have displaced a good portion of the population. Chinatown survives!

I wish every borough of SF had a parking garage. Chinatown parks!

Real food from real cooks almost 24/7. It's not as good as a lot of stuff I've had in China or a Chinese home but it kicks PF Changs janky ass. Chinatown eats!

My mom goes to Chinatown to get all of her herbs. Chinatown heals!

There are at least 5 great small bars in the area. Some hole in the wall, some gangster, some yuppie. Chinatown drinks!... a lot

Unlike Clement, the real Chinatown has kept alive a sense of unity, community, and immigrant pride. Banks, schools, and a plethora of community help organizations tell the residents and visitors alike that the people of China are here to thrive in a land that does not always treat them as valued citizens. The Chinatown YMCA is world famous for the involvement it has with the people. A model studied by various organizations to be duplicated. Chinatown lives!

Besides... Big Trouble in Little China was filmed there and Kurt Russel can do no wrong! (no wong jokes allowed)
author: Selino V.

description: Gotta love SF Chinatown!  City View is my favorite for yummy dim sum.
author: Miss P.

description: Where else can you buy a live pheasant for dinner, purchase a collectible Charles Dickens action figure and buy a $120,000 chandelier all within  5 blocks.
author: Meli B.

description:
k... it's not the richmond, and ya gotta deal with tourists who got lost trying to find north beach, but goddamn, it's good in it's own cliche'd niche. 

We had partied on friday, we partied on saturday, and by sunday at the crack of noon, we were ready for some breakfast.

We washed our smeared faces, brushed our pleading teeth, and set out, ostensibly for dim sum. 
First, we found the sushi boats. It counts as dim sum i am sure. We were all rooting for the lonesome $1.75 plate of plain tofu but nobody ever took it in. I am positive that it ran away and joined a gang. So unloved, such a shame.
Then we went a- wandering, on a mission to eventually wind up at the hot tubs on van ness ( the cleanest sleazy place in town). So we went in to the random stuff store. Found the " grabber" - a device like a small apple picker in case you can't reach the top shelf. Right. Some people only hit 5'2... that's just not me. But now i can dust the top of my venetian blinds( if i ever dusted). The store was playing " you've lost that lovin feeling", so we were all singing it when we left. I began to harmonize with " summer lovin" 

the acapella mashup(tm). Born in a moment of genius.

I recently started accessorizing with bugs. From where? 
From discount flashy sale fountain big dinging noises everywhere goodness in chinatown. 

Pardon me, i must retire now and read my entire horoscope for the dragon in the year of the rat. Only $7.99 right beside the dung beetles encased in acrylic attatched to a key ring ( $8.99 i think)
author: Domini A.

description: It's ludicrous  to judge an entire neighborhood in one big generic rating.  Yes, 95% of The restaurants suck.  They are mostly dirty tourist traps.  But like many of reviewers state in this category, Chinatown is an old, venerable, authentic neighborhood filled with families that have lived here since the 1850's.  There are many great Chinese markets with exotic food that you will not find elsewhere.  Black market firecrackers can be purchased if you ask the shady looking guys hanging around the alleyways.  I may be 53 years old, but I'm still a juvenile delinquent.  Great walking neighborhood.  Mostly safe even at night.
author: Tom S.

description: I'd like to say I've been to my fair share of north American Chinatowns (S.F., Chicago, Houston) and then smaller China squares/villages but in honesty, I have yet to find any that tops the one in San Francisco.  Omg, it's awesome here.  Prices are great - the people are wonderful.  And once you immerse yourself in it, you start to feel as though you've been transported to China itself.  So many varieties and so many Asian nationalities.  I actually start to miss home!
author: Jai J.

description: I guess living in LA gave me high expectations for what I think a Chinatown should be.  A place to buy cheap goods (aka knockoffs) at cheap prices that you wheel and deal for.  Not the case at SF's Chinatown.  Sure it's larger than LA's but it's just more of the same shop over and over and over again.  It does have a large market district which was crazy busy with a lot of locals when we went so if we lived locally I could see that as a plus.  We didn't try the restaurants while there but did try a couple boba shops and those were AMAZING!!  The people were friendlier and less pushy to sell than the shops in LA but no one would haggle prices with you and every store on every block had the same prices.  Also, though we found places that would sell you boba/bubble tea/tapioca drinks NO ONE sold the actual tapioca/boba balls.  That was a bit disappointing to me along with the high prices of everything.  I'm thinking this Chinatown knows they are a tourist destination so therefore charges for it but again just wasn't what I was expecting.  The building themselves and the experience make it worth it for any first time travelers to the area but if you've seen it once then you've seen it plenty.  One tip I'll pass along is bring cash and change and know your math as not every shop has a cash register and some of the employee's change giving skills were not up to par.
author: Nicole M.

description:
People have mixed opinions about SF's Chinatown, but mine are largely positive.  Unlike NY's Chinatown, there appears to be more of an open and dominant Chinese community here - schools, centers, churches, hospitals, etc.  It's also quieter, cleaner, etc - at least on the day we went.

On the flip side, a lot of places seemed closed on Sunday and don't open early on Monday morning.  Luckily a few bakeries were open and we were able to stock up on some goods.  Coming from DC and its ever shrinking Chinatown (it's now a block, and more places are closing), I can't be too judgmental when it comes to other urban Chinatowns.
author: Lucy Z.

description: We brought a visitor from Spain to see Chinatown and were told by one of the merchants that the best food in chinatown was the Oriental Pearl Resturant on Clay st. So we tried it.  WOW! honest to goodness Excellent Food. Great Service, clean,. Truly superior authentic chinese quisine.  The Fried rice was great, we had mini egg rolls like I have never tasted before, pot stickers and mouthwatering chow mein. A must stop when you are looking for a decent affordable place to grab a bite to eat. We will be back.
author: Susan A.

description:
Review Haiku:

Has history, yes
Tourists drive up the prices
Stick with the Sunset
author: Random J.

description:
Chinatown is everything you think it should be and more. 

If I lived in the area I would be here all the time!

But... there's always Chinatown in LA! 

I any case... it's pretty touristy, the stores have a lot of cheap, overpriced crap in them, so hunt for deals! (that's part of the fun.)

I want to go back and visit this hidden Chinatown with Mah Jong parlors people keep talking about.
author: danelle g.

description:
People, this is a REAL taste of China. There is none of your uberclean, empty LA Chinatown. This. is. San Francisco.

That being said, what are you expecting? St. Francis Woods? Seacliff? For godssake people, grow a pair or two. Most people complaining about shit haven't even bothered to be in the general vicinity for more than 30 minutes at a time. There's more to CT than just trash and snot. Chinatown is OG.

Granted, the place is a fucking mess. There's no denying it, but so is the Mission on a good day or Clement Street on a bad day. You try squeezing THAT many people into that small of a space and you'll see how clean the streets can be. 

I don't even know why the hell I'm defending Chinatown. I don't live here, I don't shop here regularly (but the fish is fucking good. Fresh fish from chinatown = better than the crap they sell at overpriced fancyass stores.) and I can't stand the constant stream of mucus and phlegm. 



Have a sense of cultural relativism people. Take a fucking sociology course or something! What's disgusting to you might not be for other people. This includes: disregard for the environment, snot shooting at missile speed, shouting, and yes, fish on a clothing line. 


Also, the "me love you long time" line is as fresh as your vagina. Say it again and I'll send a troop of 80 year old grandmothers on your sorry ass.
author: tammy m.

description:
This review might get a little Joy Luck Club.


 Personally, I hate Chinatown. The streets are crowded, the food is greasy, everything smells bad, there is always some strange liquid spewing into the street. My standard response when my friends tell me they're going to Chinatown? Watch out for SARS!


 Perhaps because it's always been there. It was one of the first places in San Francisco I'd ever visited. I didn't know the history, nor did I really even care. It's gross and why don't these people move faster! was my main concern. All kidding aside, I grew up in a hispanic suburb south of San Diego. I've never really felt close to the Chinese community since I never really had one around me. Stories of those Chinese immigrants involving railroads and Angel Island were as foreign to me as my slanted eyes were to everyone else.


 I never knew that my Dad had never been to Chinatown either. He was up here in the Bay Area because of my college graduation, so things were already a little bit emo. We were walking around, and on Stockton and Jackson, he stopped. In Mandarin, he tells me a story.


 When I was young, your grandfather and grandmother would always talk about Old Gold Mountain [San Francisco's name, in Mandarin]. We had many friends who would sneak onto boats in the hopes of arriving here. Many of them never made it to Old Gold Mountain. But when they did, all they could speak of was the strength of the Chinese community and all the hopes and dreams of the Chinese in America.


 The 30 Stockton rumbles by, the street shakes a little, as does my Dad's voice.


 60 years later, I am here for the first time. I am old, my accomplishments in life are limited. But you, you live here now. And for you, it's been so easy. But in these streets, you can feel history. You can feel my story, your grandfather's story, your grandmother's story, your mother's story. To you, it is just some street in San Francisco. To us, it is the reason we are all here, celebrating you and your sister. To us, it is the reason why so many of us came to America, why we always pressure you to succeed. It is so we could give you the opportunity to create hopes and dreams of your own.
author: eddo

description:
From what I could tell there were a lot of overpriced trinket shops and empty, overpriced restaurants. But then a friend told me that we should have walked down Stockton Street (not Grant). 

Oh well!
author: Jen F.

description:
San Francisco Chinatown is one of the largest Chinatowns outside of Asia.  It is worth visiting at least once just for the experience though it can be very touristy.  It offers a wealth of restaurants, "tea rooms", shopping (including unusual herbal shops), and beautiful architecture.  Start by passing throgh Chinatown Gate at Grant and Bush, then head up Grant.  Next hit Stockton Street and the Fortune Cookie Factory (http://www.yelp.com/biz/7CR8EP4gV-oYXyNa2-PTcw).

It is also home to a number of events (http://www.sanfranciscochinatown.com/events/index.html) including the annual Chinese New Year Parade and the annual Chinese New Year Treasure Hunt (http://www.yelp.com/biz/jiPLMKZfe8umEbMrNnIuEA?hrid=cDVGzDTd0Sfwo0OXFks8Nw).
author: Rachel R.

description:
Chinatown is a multi-faceted area. Well, maybe not...But I sure like saying that it is to sound smart!

Welcome to Chinatown. That's basically it. No introduction needed. Just walk in and look around. You'll either love it or hate it. Take your pick. You have a couple of options, as well, as to how dirty you want to get. Stockton St. is, by far, the dirtiest because of all the foot traffic. Grant St. is not as congested but beware of the tourist trap shops that aren't even Chinese owned. You'll know which ones I'm talking about. And Powell St. is like the new kid on the block. Very quiet and light on traffic. Maybe it has something to do with the cable car line...

There's plenty to see and learn in Chinatown. Some will come to you and some you will need help and guidance to learning. Like self defense against the elderly. They may look old but they can kick you ass getting on the bus and getting to and from where they want to go. Best stay out of the way. And taking pictures of the meat products in various states of animation. Fish in a Styrofoam box with enough water to breath versus the live fish in a tank. Poultry in a cage versus poultry in a bag in the cooler. Yeah, that's what's for dinner tonight.

And if you can get over the stench and dirtiness of the place, you can try to venture into a hole in the wall restaurant and try ordering some food. Kinda adventurous that way. Or you can cave in and dine at one of the many brightly lit restaurants that try to suck up to the tourists with their fake smiles. Let me tell you something, when they walk away and talk with their other co-workers, they ain't saying good things about you most of the time. Just letting you know.
author: Anthony L.

description:
SF's Chinatown is great for tourists looking to feel like they actually stepped into a neighborhood in Shanghai, but the quality of food can be sketchy, at best. In my college days of partying, Sam Wo's was always a welcome destination after leaving the clubs, as they were open till the wee hours of the morning. 

Now that I'm a family guy, my wife and I would rather head to what we've dubbed (and we're not alone) "the real Chinatown," a few miles away on Clement Street. You won't find buildings adorned in red silk decor, but you won't find too many of the unappetizing aromas that Tim so mercilessly described as Chinatown. What you will find are an assortment of multi-Asian restaurants that pride themselves on simply darned good food. The service is surprisingly a little better off Clement Street, too; probably because the waitstaff knows you're a local and won't settle for rude service. 

Parking note: Street parking is very limited as you're sharing with the local residents, but be patient, it's worth circling the block a couple times. 

Again, head for Clement Street, closer to Park Presidio's north side...enjoy!
author: Rudy P.

description:
I love Chinatown. Yeah, it's dirty, yeah the people are rude, but it has SO much! 

The restaurants....the jewelry places...everything. You can find excellent bargains. 

Just try to stay away from the obvious touristy SF cheap looking souvenirs and stuff...the smaller, dirty-looking hole in the wall restaurants are the BEST. =D
author: Alison N.

description: I work in Chinatown, and though it's touristy I still love walking through it each day. Go on Commercial St. to find a rare Banksy piece!!
author: Chloe C.

description:
Chinese-Americans and other folks of Asian origin (such as myself) may be jaded to what "little" SF Chinatown has to offer, or how "mediocre" and "done" the culture and bustle of this neighborhood has grown.  But, really, the place is a timeless treasure that allows all peoples of SF and the Bay Area to get lost in a completely different world that's just around the bend.

A recent stroll on a busy Saturday afternoon with my visiting family taught me to appreciate the neighborhood like a child or newcomer all over again.

Explore the alleys!!
author: Alfonso E.

description:
Well we go to china town with any of our guests. 

We also go to Mark's Hair Salon on Jackson Street, where my husband gets a hair cut. All he has to do is sit on the seat, and the guy (I think the owner) knows what to do! And it is an acceptable price.

They also have great pastry at AA bakery on Sacramento Street. Napoleons, fruit tarts and more.

I am amazed though at the prices of some of the restaurants. We went there yesterday and we ate at the restaurant that has the ducks and pigs hanging in its window (the one close to the parking garage). We ordered two entrees, rice, and chow main (? Spelling), and 2 sodas and we paid $50. Excuse me? And honestly the food was not even all that good. There are a lot of other restaurants in china town that serve way superior food and for half the price.

As for buying Asian groceries or sweets, we go to Ranch 99 or 99 Ranch, where I buy as much as I want and never pay more than $90. Sweets, fruits, vegetables, meats, and all sorts of fun things included!
author: Mona O.

description: I visited SF's Chinatown several weeks ago during my summer vacation. And I must say, the diversity and culture of this lively town has made my first visit to San Francisco, unforgettable! I went to SF with a group of friends with no schedule or plan of where we were planning on going. However, yelpers recommended Chinatown for me, where they have lots of retail shops, restaurants, and souvenir shops, which was exactly the place we were aiming for. So people who are planning to visit San Francisco any time soon must visit Chinatown! Other than the "run-down" areas of this city to peculiar odors of fishes you never knew existed, you will definitely find restaurants, shops (like Forever 21, H&M, etc), souvenir shops (postcards, t-shirts, etc) near the outskirts of Chinatown. If you're a person who loves to shop, there were stores such as American Apparel, Forever 21, H&M, etc which I found interesting. You will always find a big crowd surrounding a street act or hot dog stands selling hot dogs that may be your favorite of all time! All in all, SF's Chinatown is definitely a place to visit when you come to the bay!
author: Lisa K.

description:
Even though I live on the eastbay, I love coming to SF's Chinatown. There is so much going on here. Just to experience daily life for some that live in this "inner-city". Some of residence of chinatown hardly ever leave. I remember visiting an elderly aunt that rented a room...more like the size of my bathroom. She would only leave if there was an event at a relatives house. She probably lived there for more than 40 years. She would go out daily to buy her fresh veggies for the day. Amazing how much culture that we don't see. 

Ohhh great inexpensive fresh produce. Yummy places to eat. I come here to shop sometimes because some of the things are so different from what is available in eastbay. 

Parking is the worse!
author: Winane L.

description:
I love Chinatown, but what makes Chinatown cool for me, isn't the touristy strip of Grant, but it is the inner bowels, the gizzards and grates of its hidden shops, stores and oh yes, Mahjong parlors.

In a perfect world, I could find a Mahjong parlor serving Absynth... oh yeah.
author: Storm W.

description:
Forty years ago, I came to San Francisco for the first
time - and was thrilled to visit Chinatown.  I remembered
Nancy Kwan singing "Flower Drum Song", looked in 
wonder at all the delicacies in the restaurant windows,
and bought myself a small jade ring.  Now that I've lived
here thirty years, and have traveled to Hong Kong and 
Singapore and other parts of Asia, I am not so 
mesmerized with Chinatown - but I can still overlook the
crowded streets, the poverty, the annoying traffic, and
feel the hum of life, the hope and sorrow of many who
live there, the aspirations.  I still enjoy going to the 
apothecaries, eating dim sum at Chinatown restaurants,
and looking for an occasional bargain.  Chinatown is as
much a part of San Francisco as the Golden Gate Bridge
and I can't imagine the city without it.  It is part of our
culture and our heritage!
author: Carmen H.

description:
Have nothing to do and want to get out of the apartment and just experience something different? Take a stroll down Stockton Street, especially on a nice weekend afternoon.

This side of Chinatown is more for the actual Asian families that buy food (rather than other parts which are filled more with restaurants, bodegas, sundry stores, etc.).

Stockton Street, though, is yet another in the never-ending list of reasons why I love big cities, including good ol' SF. You turn on a corner (like I did coming out of North Beach one day) and you're in a whole 'nother world. 

It's such a nice break from my own moronic reality to stumble down this street where it's packed with mostly Asian shoppers, buying what appears to be very authentic (and incredibly affordable) meats, seafood, fruits, and vegetables.

As busy and crowded as it can get, there is a kind of NYC-style vibe of organized chaos that you just float through. It's something to experience, for sure.
author: Derek R.

description: So many complaints about Chinatown! I got I Love SF tshirts for $1.88! I am from Kansas so everything about SFO is foreign to me. I didn't find Chinatown to be dirtier than downtown. I didn't get harassed by any "bums" in Chinatown so that was a plus for me. I purchased tons of souvenirs for super cheap. I visited Good Mong Kok Bakery and had the best Chinese food in my life ($4 stuffed 2 people with enough left over for another meal). We walked from our hotel about a mile away. I see a lot of complaints about the hills and they are leg burners, I agree, but no reason not to visit (we do not have hills like that in Kansas, at least not ones that are paved over and built on). It was an awesome experience!
author: Phylicia B.

description: I haven't seen this much useless crap for sale since i went up for bid in that fat, unemployed ,mexican bachelor auction.............update- I sound like Peter Griffin from televisions Family guy.
author: Gabe F.

description:
Yeah, I am a fan. I love the uniqueness, I love gettin dim sums passing by, I love to window shop at those gift touristy shops. Love Chineeze New Year show!
Some of CT parts might be a lil dirty, but it's sure very safe area.
author: Cat of a Donut J.

description:
I get my haircut in Chinatown. I pay $9 as I like to splurge. 

Used to work in Chinatown so I know it quite well.
author: Marcus R.

description: Chinatown is such an interesting place to stroll through. Check out all the dried foods shops. Visit a tea shop. Nosh a yummy egg tart or cha siu bao (or better yet, stop at a dim sum restaurant...Great Eastern is my favorite). Then watch the old timers play mah jong or practice tai chi in Portsmouth Square or St. Mary's Square. Hen hao.
author: Denise N.

description: You can buy cheap goods here.  It cleaner then before.  Always crowded.  Cheap SRO.
author: John F.

description: I've been to chinatown, pretty much everytime I am in town...... searching for great deals, something unique that I cannot find anywhere else. But time and time again I seem to be disappointed. Honestly ladies, you will find better prices with the street vendors on Union square and with less bargaining. The streets are filthy and crowded. I guess it's an experience everyone needs to do once and if you are buying souvenirs for alot of friends this is probably a good spot to buy knick knacks for cheap, but I still will argue, you will gt better deals with the street vendors. For example, I went into atleast 10 jewelry stores looking for turquoise earrings and necklace, every place wanted atleast $10 for earrings and $20-25 for a necklace, with the street vendors earrings are $5 and necklace $10-15. So you decide. But if you are good at wheeling and dealing negoiating prices, than this will be you cup of tea!
author: Jennifer D.

description: If you are in the area looking for San Fran cheap souvenirs -- this is the place to go.  Tourist HEAVEN.  Cheap crap everywhere.  Every other store is either a gift shop or restaurant.  Some gift shops are better than others...and you can tell just by walking in 4 feet into each store.  Anyway, white tourists way out numbered any other ethnic groups -- including all the transients -- who were all scary white people -- asking for cigarettes, money -- you name it...they want it!  The buildings are all really cool and colorful.  Even the Bank of America was pretty spiffy.  The weather was great when we went...but boy was it packed on Memorial Day...TONS OF PEOPLE.
author: Kyle R.

description: interesting place, with nice Chinese music playing on the street and in the stores..the people are friendly , and the street decorations are beautiful.
author: Derick A.

description: Walking through once, I witnessed about thirty ethnic stereotypes that I'll have to learn to undo...
author: Keane L.

description: If you see everyone carrying pink plastic grocery bags, you know you're in Chinatown. We Chinese love the color red and all shades of it.
author: Connie C.

description:
whats with the chinatown hate? i gots love for my chinese folks. 

duy lai lo mo hai. mo cho. da sae lai. 

ha, i still remember my cantonese. 

look into chinatowns past, our collective sf past.... how quickly the yellow man was turned from the, friendly, hard working foreigner, to dogs with no rights in this country, right in this chinatown. 

now when was it they took down that NO DOGS AND CHINAMENS BEYOND THIS POINT sign on stockon? 

*vincent chin mutha fuckas, vincent chin*

*angry asian man*

chinatowns a thriving community with many layers. the complexity of the place astounds me. the public layer, the tourists, the tongs, the street gangs, the underworld.... THE FOOD!!!!one!!l33t. 

ehhh, chinatown dirty? sure thing boss, but who gives a fuck, gots love for yous chinatown.

vincent chin
http://www.asianweek.com/061397/feature.html

quick overview 
http://www.sanfranciscochinatown.com/history/
author: Euge L.

description: If you can get passed getting hit and kicked by people the age of your grandparents, the smells, the crowds, spittng, getting staired at all the time, tourists, etc...there are some good things.  I haven't had the food there yet because I'm not real keen on eating where I've seen cat's roam around looking for mice (or mice in general), but the few places I've been have been ok.  Watch your stuff there! I had a guy try to pick-pocket me in chinatown.  He wasn't Chinese, but I'm sure it's a hotbed for people who do that since everyone is so close anyway.  If you are a tourist then skip Stockton...go to Grant and you will have a friendlier time.  If you are looking for a cleaner area with a better atmosphere...try Clement st.
author: Robin L.

description: Jesus Christ, MOVE PEOPLE. Walking in Chinatown is not a pleasant experience for the high-strung. It seems like Chinese women live to be 120, and they're still out there walking, albeit very, very slowly. And I really don't understand who buys those fruits and vegetables on the sidewalk. It is a certainty that at least 1,000 people touched them and sneezed on them. And they just add to the impossibility of walking, because everyone stops to feel them. Add in the cigarette smoke, the chickens being slaughtered, the honking cars, and the guy screaming HAPPY HAPPY HAPPY and it's sensory overload. Get me away from here I'm dying.
author: Anonymous P.

description: Its smells like pee, poo, spit, farts, post nasal drip, mildew, tea, egg tarts, tofu, rotted fish, herbs, and tuna.  Poor manatee...  I recommend wearing shoes around here.
author: Fatty A.

description: why does everyone keep referring SF as the "home to the largest Chinese population outside of China"?   SF is not the largest place for chinese dispora, but it is probably the largest in the United States.  In Indonesia, the minority are the chinese-- 7.5 mil pop.  For the entire US, only 3.3 mil pop.  Go figure and do your homework.
author: Hana ..

description: AHHHHHHHHHHHHHHH!!!!  How can this place have a four star rating?!?  Chinatown is even worse than Fisherman's Wharf as far as I'm concerned.  Nobody, not even the locals know how to walk down the street in this neighborhood.  Too many lookie-loo's, too many people, and too much STUFF!  I HATE STUFF!  Who needs a five dollar rabbit pelt any way?  Heed my advice, steer clear of this area.
author: Max M.

description: You'll experience sights and smells, (both good and bad. Mostly bad.) from a far away land, hear exotic tongues, see laundry hanging on lines as it was generations ago, roasted ducks dripping with fat and most likely get body checked by an 80 year old woman carrying 15 pink plastic bags...and that's just on the ride on the 30 Stockton.
author: Josua P.

description:
chinatown never gets old for me.

it's one of the places i visited the first time i came to san francisco to visit, long before i moved here. it was one of the first places i visited when i moved here. it is one of the first places i always take everyone who visits me here. it's loud, chaotic, people spit and stare and sometimes, the animals hanging in groceries are a little disconcerting. to me. but it's also full of magic and cheap treasures and character.

not to mention, poppers. everywhere you turn, POPPERS!

i just love poppers.
author: Irene S.

description:
When I walk down Grant Street, I can't help but think about my grandmother, who at all of her 4'10" stature threatened to chop down & burn the sign over the front of the local family Association in Chicago's Chinatown. They had made the mistake of thinking that they could ship this recently widowed woman and her six kids back to China. 
It is this kind of tough as nails tenacity that reminds me of any Chinatown community, one that is a whole community of it's own, where for many is their only world.  Barely surviving after the freeway closures from the Loma-Prieta earthquake, and the plague of gentrification that affects so many communities in urban cities, it continues in it's metamorphosis.  
Hang Ah tea room is where my family would gather when we came in from 'Yee Fow'.  Amazing that it's been here for so long and is still getting decent reviews.  After that, we would get a duck to bring back home and go to Eastern Bakery for a slice of Coffee Crunch Cake, or pick up a Chinese Apple Pie at Ping Yuen Bakery. Yang Sing only had one restaurant on Broadway and the prices were actually reasonable.  Some people preferred the Orange or Custard pie at Sun Wah Que or Uncle's Cafe.  Sadly Edsel Ford Fong is no longer around to insult you and stick his thumbs in your jook at Sam Wo, but his name lives on at AT&T Park.  
Joe Fong, of the 'Joe Boys' Chinatown gang infamy, is now a professor in the Ethnic Studies department at College of San Mateo.  The Holiday Inn is now a Hilton.  The new International Hotel was finally completed in 2005, replacing the hole in the ground that was left after the original was demolished after the elderly tenants were evicted, beginning  what would become a nearly 40 year battle to provide affordable housing.
Much has changed. So if one of those little old ladies almost knocks you over to board the #30 Stockton, think of my Grandmother and offer her your seat.  She has had a long struggle.
author: Arlene C.

description:
I didn't go to the part of Chinatown the tourists know about. I had just bought my ticket for Alcatraz at Alcatraz cruises and asked the person at the ticket booth what's the fastest way to get to Chinatown from there. Zie told me what bus to take, and I hopped on that bus without a second thought.
When I got off at the stop for Chinatown, it looked nothing like what I've seen on TV or the movies, I felt as though I had just set foot in Beijing. I barely saw any tourists. 
It was scary while I was experiencing it, but now I see it as an adventure in retrospect. I feel happy with the fact that I can say I wandered around those parts.
I even ate in these parts. Now I was unfortunately strapped for cash so I settled for this small buffet spot. It was.....different from what I'm used to. It did hit the spot, but it wasn't amazing. It did "feel" a little more authentic though, what with the grimy cafeteria style dining area, atrocious bathroom and pigeon walking around the floor. Ick. 
I never even came back to see the gate to be honest. Definitely trying the spots where the really good food is and seeing the tourist area next time I come around SF's way, but I can say I'm satisfied with my out of the ordinary experience in Chinatown.
author: Philippe C.

description: i love it here.because i grew up watching my dad play mah jong in the associations.  even if i didnt this place is just amazing if you want athentic chinese food
author: Steven K.

description: Its China Town man,  i can get discount oriental items and candy for super cheap.  i went looking around all over and enjoyed the nice breezy day up and down the streets.. if you've never been then you should at least check it out once!
author: Lety M.

description: When I first moved to the Bay Area I lived in Walnut Creek.  So when I made to move to SF and Chinatown I was in for an awakening.  But I learned to love the area and the people.  It's true not all the locals love outsiders but it's like any other neighborhood,  the more you see people the more friends you make.  Chinatown holds a special place in my heart.  I love the novelty stores and produce and meat markets.  Although sometimes my butcher would wince when I would ask for only one pork chop.  I respect the locals here.  It's no wonder some have mixed feelings about outsiders the way they were treated during the first of the century.  I could move back to Chinatown and be very content and happy.
author: Kevin G.

description: It's so easy to get lost in Chinatown...in a good way. Every time I go there I find something crazy. The last time we were there my boyfriend found a store selling fresh eggs. I mean fresh, as in, in the back of the store you ordered the type of egg you wanted (duck, chicken, etc..) and the guy turned around and retrieved the egg from the coup behind him where live birds are laying their eggs. This kind of crazy stuff only happens in Chinatown.
author: Kelly S.

description:
for the tourist who gets sucked into the kitsch of chinatown--grant street then you're a n00b. the real chinatown is on stockton. hollar.

good luck avoiding lead poison. and the crzy eye from a glass eyed china man.
author: curi k.

description: I love chinatown!! alot of stuff to see and buy.. fo cheap.
author: Roger A.

description: Who doesn't love a good dirty, filthy and smelly Chinatown?  Good Chinese dim sum and cheap souvenir stores.  One suggestion is to keep your wallet and purse close to you at all times.  Don't waste your time and money on Muni, you can walk to Chinatown from downtown SF.  After Chinatown, you can hit the stores on Boadway and afterwards go to North Beach then maybe you can end your day at Wharf.
author: Chris R.

description:
there's this crazy, homeless dude that walks around in his suit pretending to talk on his cell phone.  he doesn't even bother opening up the phone.  he pretends to talk on it, closed-style (his minutes must be low).  i really like this guy.

cool stuff to buy in chinatown:

1) $1 paper handfans
2) ninja shoes
3) kites

also, the dude that plays the chinese one string instrument.  that guy rules.  there's two that i have seen.  i like the one who plays the thing solo-style.  no tape/cd player with him.
author: Claudia B.

description: You guys need to remember this: SF Chinatown is the second highest density  in population behind Manhattan.   It has been around from the time of the Gold Rush and the founding of San Francisco.  It has seen many historical significances to San Francisco.  Sure it might be dirty and old, full of  old cranky people, and cheesy tourist traps. But it has the freshest groceries around, the cheap food and most important I think it has heart and lots of people who want to make Chinatown a better place to live  and perserving it for the next generation.  There are people out there who wants to improve the lives of these people who live here.
author: Chris C.

description: Good dim sum at most of the little dim sum places.  very touristy, and you can bargain for prices with just about everything.
author: Matt N.

description: We had a blast in Chinatown.  Stockton Street is a great place to start with poultry & ducks hanging in the windows, the exotic herbs, teas, sweet & savory treats, fun candy stores, just so much to do & see.  We enjoyed the Kite Shop, Waverly Place for the painted balconies, visiting the authentic Tin How Temple, & the Ten Ren Tea Company.
author: Amy B.

description:
gotta love the san francisco chinatown. if you know the story and history of the main gate and the actual meaning of san francisco chinatown you would know what i'm talking about. 

this is the only chinatown in the united states that is located smack in the middle of all these hills. it's also one of the biggest chinatown other then NYC.

definitely a place to visit if your a tourist. also a good place to show off when you have relatives or friends over. you know, everyone needs to go to chinatown.


expect: 
-dirtyy, smells, and cramped
-lots of hills, don't bother walking if you can't handle walkin
-heavy traffic, both foot and by vehicle.
-lots of grandmas and grandpas who are mean and hard to deal with.


tips:
-get someone to drive you here if you can't parallel park on steeps hills
-main street gives you enough idea of how chinatown is like, no need to go on side streets unless u want food.
author: Eric Y.
