description: I sometimes enjoy the hustle and bustle of Chinatown on the weekends, hence I'll prep myself for the jostle with the old ladies at the grocery stores or bakeries! It's interesting to watch some dramas at the cash register when ladies fight over short change issues, someone cutting in line of another, how much the vege weighed, etc. It's enough drama for a weekend afternoon so I'll settle for my egg tart or baked goods from the bakeries.
author: Yan M.

description: What a fun place to walk around on a gorgeous Friday afternoon. Just wandering around, people watching, and laughing at the ridiculous things on sale in some of these shops...I think it's definitely an under-rated (and free!) opportunity to experience a unique part of San Francisco!
author: Purvi R.

description:
the first time i visited san francisco it was for a job interview.  i was with friends who were also up here for that reason (company was bought, yada yada) and we came in early to do a little sight seeing.  you know, check out what could potentially be our new home.  we were staying in union square, so naturally one of the first places we hit was chinatown.  it was amazing- all the shops filled with treasures and junk- a tourist wonderland.

the next night, after the interviews were over, we hit a few bars up in north beach (as required by the narrative).  the night was cool and clear so we decided to walk back to our hotel- through chinatown.  this time it was a whole different world.  damp, empty streets reflecting the neon lights.  trucks being unloaded in the steam rising up from street grates.  i fell in love with the city that night (and no, it was not the alcohol talking).  

chinatown is one of the reasons i moved here.  despite the crowds and the tourists and the annoyances, i love it.  and i am grateful to it for convincing me to come.
author: Samantha W.

description:
chinatoon...hahaha what a funny looking word.
i just mistyped it and had to put it somewhere so i can remember it.

besides all the usual resturants and souvenirs and food stores...
take a peek in a tea shop...
lots to taste and learn about tea.
author: Cee G.

description: Five stars because this is the exact polar opposite of Washington, DC's "Chinatown."
author: Kenny L.

description: we love this place.  if you want some super cheap touristy stuff come here.  if you want to spend mucho dinero on crazy mushrooms and ginseng, this is also the place for you.  i would say this is one of the cooler chinatowns i have been to. check it out!
author: Nick S.

description: Originally an enclave for male inexpensive labor force until prostitutes escaped to Cameron House's christian nunnery. Aging demographic. Live chickens sometimes clucking in storefronts. Tuberculosisoutbreaksandtransmissions.Some unusual golden, glistening duck hanging in the window. aflac. Pedestrian style lights for crossing. Denizen of gambling fetish/addiction. Inexpensive bakeries, suspicious electronic shops, chinese halloween dress fantasy. Open on Christmas. Lots of spitting on the sidewalk. Like China. Pink plastic bags. Hate love.
author: miriam b.

description: Chinatown is one of the most interesting and enjoyable neighborhoods to walk around in the City.  It's also the most affordable place in San Francisco for everything from food to haircuts to medical care.  Why go to a chain supermarket when you can get all of your produce from a family market for half the price?  Why pay a fortune for dim sum outside of Chinatown when there are so many delightful dim sum restaurants here?   And, if you get tired, just stop at a bakery for a cup of tea or relax in one of the three parks.  Avoid the seedy camera shops that exist only to rip off tourists.
author: Emma Q.

description: I love going to Chinatown and not just Grant. There are some great little stores and restaurants thru out  Chinatown. My girlfriends and I from work love to get fresh shrimp wontons from the Dick Lee market. (its definitely a hole in the wall but great won tons!) Bring them home and lightly fry them up...! Amazing! Or make soup with them. Or stop by the fortune cookie factory on Ross St. (?) so fresh, the place looks like a total fire hazard but the cookies are worth a trip. Once you've had one  you realize all those others you've had at restaurants are stale. There are great places to find gifts, and the markets for fresh veggies and fruits. There is a parking lot on Vallejo across from the police station I can always find a parking space and its not too far to walk. And its also on the edge of North Beach so you get the best of both worlds. So yeah it can be a bit dirty  and sometimes the locals aren't always so friendly to "outsiders", but hey if I'm spending my money there...whatever...and I've been to NYC's Chinatown and San Francisco's is way better. Our Chinatown Rocks compared to theirs!
author: Susan D.

description:
dirty
crowd,
traffic jams.

valuable prices,
traditional dimsum,
Chinese Chinese
author: Sue S.

description: I usually do grocery shopping here because of the variety and the price.  Seafood, meats, vegetables, knives, contacts, tea, swords and just about anyting else you can imagine can be found here for cheap.
author: Corey V.

description: I enjoy walking through San Francisco's Chinatown. Some parts of it are extremely touristy and the little shops are full of cheap souvenirs aimed at the tourism dollar. However, I enjoy buying some of the cheap fruits and vegetables as well as Asian sauces and condiments that can be found in the tiny grocery stores. Every time I go is a new experience because there are a lot of little side streets and alleys that I encounter on subsequent visits. It can be a bit crowded and hard to find parking, but there are also parking garages within parking distance if you don't take public transportation.
author: Cynthia D.

description:
lot's has already been said, but... i don't write enough reviews.

everyone should go here at least once, just for the spectacle.  go on a saturday afternoon in the summer.  walk down grant.  this is the worst that chinatown has to offer.

walk down stockton early on a sunday, before things get too crazy, and you'll get to see the grocers getting their fresh produce for the day.  it's still a bit of a madhouse, but it's like being in a chinese city, minus the $1000 airfare to go see it.

i never go there to eat or shop.  just to see the sights and to see a little city within the city.  that's just me; i'm a sinophile i guess.  there's worse things you can be.
author: MaFan D.

description: The real Chinatown is on Stockton Street but don't tell the tourists - as long as they stay down on Grant Street we'll have the place to ourselves (And the pushy little Chinese grannies with sharp elbows who will knock you down as they push their way onto the bus)
author: Quartknee K.

description:
i hate walking around in chinatown! super narrow and overcrowded sidewalks with people who can't walk straight in a consistent pace.  and then there's all that junk for sale in front of the cheesy gift shops sharing the sidewalk so that if you want to pass the crowd in front of you, you have to get out on the street and risk your life from the crazy drivers driving around.  
but sometimes i have to walk in chinatown because guests come and visit and want to see chinatown.  argh... there's really nothing to see there either.  well maybe going to look at all the laundry hanging to dry from all the windows above is kinda entertaining - i'd imagine those clothes just get dirty right away if they're hanging between the buildings or from the windows in that area...
author: charlotte s.

description:
I have a love/hate relationship with Chinatown. I walk through it often to get around, since I live in the neighborhood next to it, North Beach.
Here are my pros and cons of Chinatown.

Pro:
Lots of funky shops. Most sell the same or similar items, but you can find some cheap stuff--random things--but cheap!

Con:
It is always crowded. It boggles my mind how much shopping the Chinatown residents do just in their neighborhood! Everyday, they're out there with their plastic shopping bags, pushing through the crowds...mind boggling.

Pro: 
Good dim sum restaurants...you have to find the good ones though

Con:
Public urination before 7 AM. Most mornings I'm just not ready for this sight.

Pro:
Cultural flavor. It's fun walking through here, it's a change of scenery.

Con:
The crowds. Navigating the sidewalk should be the next Olympic sport.
author: Nicole R.

description: A fun place to find tons of little shops full of junk - very entertaining for my kids.   But that's it.  Problem is that it fricking stinks and I wanted to puke the whole day.  How in the world am I supposed to eat there when breathing is a challenge.  I know I'm a hick from Illinois, but I don't get it.  Walking in overcrowded streets with zillions of old people shuffling around doing lord knows what.  Tons of small grocery stores with some of the nastiest stuff I've ever seen - and I thought Californians virtually stopped smoking?   I like going to the city for a fun day, but I'll be skipping Chinatown.
author: Rob C.

description: I actually really love SF's Chinatown.  It's got so much history.  Sure, it gets crowded with the natives shopping and the tourists gawking, but if you can fit yourself into the little gaps in the crowd, you're good to go.  It's gotten a bit rundown, but Chinatown holds so many memories for me.  I still go grocery shopping with my mom in Chinatown every once in a while.  I frequent the Chinatown library to grab a book to read for my bus rides to and from work.  I even did my student teaching at a Chinatown school.  The living conditions in Chinatown aren't the best - that I'll admit and I've witnessed them firsthand.  But I give it four stars for the memories...
author: Kris L.

description: My favourite place is that fortune cookie factory in the alley... but I love the whole damn town.  SF has the largest Chinese population outside of China (I believe this is correct)... and it adds so much to the city!!!  Fantastic place to just walk around, to get errands done, or just stop and get a bite with a friend.  YAY!
author: Uncle Fishbits Aeneas X.

description: I don't go here to pretend I'm in Shanghai, but this is my neighborhood when I visit.  It doesn't make me think of many films.  It doesn't smell like pee and poo.  My boyfriend loved the dirty fortune cookies I bought him one year.  The food is generally okay.
author: Ai M.

description:
house of nan king.. 

ps. clement is better... yeah i said it!
author: Angelo M.

description:
ok, i have very mixed feelings about chinatown.  
i do all my grocery shopping here, mostly in the stockton markets.  fruit and vegtibles are extremely cheap, think 1/4 the price of safeway.  they also have live fish, which is cool, and live frogs and turtles which is not so cool.  there are also many cheap wonderful places to eat, as long as you stay from grant (where the tourists are).
on the bad side, chinatown is way overcrowded.  people push and shove, and bump into you like its nothing.  shopowners also often try to overchangre me, because i am obviously not chinese.  there is also a lot of yelling which bothers some people.
finally, i am sorry but the stores all smell really, really bad.
so a great place for fresh cheap produce, but a slightly unpleasent social experience.
author: charlene l.

description: FUN PLACE...despite the crowds, the place is pretty awesome. LOTS of hole in the wall food places and shopping to do. This is a MUST when you go up to San Francisco.
author: Ann T.

description: Damn, after being in LA for a bit and experiencing the Chinatown over here (which ain't much, sadly), you truly do realize what a treasure The City's Chinatown is. I do realize its getting little bit more national pub right now due to its central role in "The Pursuit of Happyness", but in spite of that, you possibly can't be human if you can't love an area where you can get cheap dimsum, DVD's you can't understand, and easy access to the Financial D., North Beach and Union Square all in one compact geographical package. I gotta admit though, the amount of cheesy, made-for-tourist cheapo t-shirts on sale here does bother me, especially on the very wide Grant Ave.
author: Ramon T.

description: One star in the daytime when it's crowded, four stars in the evening when you go on a bender in those dark cubbies of bars they offer. No, not the ones where 25 ladies greet you when you walk in..the 3 that are there to get you nice & toasty on a chilly SF night. The shops are pretty shitty and most of the food isn't anything to write home about, but there is a charm about Chinatown. I can safely say it's hands down better than the ones in Philly and LA.
author: Colleen B.

description:
perfect place, to see asian people. SIKE. ahha.
Hands down, the truth is we don't like tourist. maybe just around 4th of july. any other time, naaaaaaaah. It's weird, I was waiting for the 30.. and some asian guy came up to me and my boyfriend and started talking to us and then the bus came and decided to ask him for a cig. nice one nice one. I like to go get star paper because it's cheaper then japantown and other places. They always have good food, but I have germphobia. I'm gay. ._________. I'm always scared to touch things, so that doesn't work for me. And everytime I go it's always like a fair going on, a fair here a fair there. or just like "lemonade" stands that sells jade and etc. Cool right? lolol.I like banh uot NOT FROM THERE. I like boba, from chinatown, and egg custards. ^_______^V I shall go to yelp the egg custard place now. ahhaa. enjoy chinatown. :] btw, people are pushy becareful.
Oh last thing, if you decide you need to get to the other side of the street and you are being pushed DON'T DON'T DON'T DON'T DON'T run in the middle of the street if you see a bus, THEY DON'T CARE AND WILL JUST SPEED UP. T_______T
author: Carolyn Y.

description:
as a SF native, i used to loathe chinatown.  it was the backdrop for my weekly torture, aka saturday morning chinese school.  now, since i've happily moved out to the burbs, chinatown has become a place that i look forward to going every once in awhile.  here's a rundown of my favorite things/places in chi-town:

Golden Gate Bakery (on Grant) - they can usually get away with the (relatively) murderous prices because they are damn good.  love their fluffy spongy cakes more than their famous egg tarts.

Napoleon Bakery (on Stockton) - dirt cheap, large portions.  beware of the lack of order and etiquette when trying to buy something.  i've bitched out an old lady or two who cut in front of me in "line" only to realize that there IS no line.  just barge to the front and shout out what you want.

most of the take-out dimsum places, particularly You's (on Stockton).  

also load up on snacks, spices, sauces, etc at the supermarkets.

everything closes down around 6-7pm.
author: Jolene T.

description: Im not sure what the deal is with all of the hate for Chinatown. Yeah, the crowds are really bad at times, but I don't find hanging ducks, etc... to be so appauling that I can't wander through once in awhile. This is the one place you can get some of the freshest, cheapest produce in the entire city. Sure, Chinatown has it's drawbacks, but I just don't think it is THAT bad. I guess perhaps maybe I've just learned to ignore quite a bit...
author: Anita B.

description: San Fransisco has the best China Town ever.  Comparing to Boston's CT which is pretty small..  this place is rad.  Manymany more restaurant, shopping, & grocery options - go to SF CT and have a blast!
author: Mina I.

description: I love just walking down Grant and stopping at all the shops along the way.  I was able to get some great stocking stuffers and also some cute stuff for myself.  If I don't get a sake set for Christmas, I am definitely going to find one here.
author: Jenna M.

description: China Town is cool when you first enter on Grant. It's  touristy and the souvenir  is pretty extra cheap, but once you take a left on to Pacific get ready for the crowd. It's better to walk there of course, I feel like I'm in China every time I'm there. You're see people carrying the pink plastic bags, so that's where all of the cheap veggies & food come from. It's so funny I saw two fights the last time I was in China Town.
author: V N.

description: This Chinatown is how many blocks long?? Its pretty big but I've only been to Seattle and Honolulu's Chinatown so I don't know how it is in bigger places.  Its a lot more decorative and it has one main strip.  There are also lots of dim sum restaurants and souvenir shops.  I actually looked for the cheapest bargains available and while the souvenir shops were selling the same items, some are more expensive than others so watch out.  The quality isn't that great though.  I bought a mug and the ink started fading.  There were also pillow covers that started falling apart.  So lesson one is don't buy cheap crap in chinatown cause they fall apart easily.   I found there are Americanized dim sum restaurants so if you want the authentic ones avoid the financial district.
author: Leo M.

description:
i really liked the busy and lively chinatown but i do agree with the reviews about the cleanliness off the place and people shouting at each other.
when we went to chinatown we found a lovely little restaurant with very reasonable prices and overall we were impressed. there wasn't a great deal of variety on the menu but maybe thats a good thing because sometimes you dont really know what your gonna get!


 all in all a nice place to eat but quite loud, dirty and very VERY busy.
author: blondi1

description: When you get into the heart of this place, you really feel like you have left SF.  Fish hanging, everything written in Chinese, and best of all, even I felt tall!  It is such a fun place to walk through and go into all the little shops.  It is a mini-vacation for me.
author: Pele N.

description: If you think SF Chinatown is dirty you should go to LA's Chinatown. I don't think it's sanitary to even walk there. ( But I still enjoyed my visit). I love my Chinatown! Where else in the City can you get Breakfast Lunch and Dinner for less than $10. Breakfast- 2 Law Mai Bao + Box Drink $1.50. Lunch-Sandwich @ LIttle Paris + Drink $3.00 Dinner-Plate Stir Fired Noodles- $5.00 ( If your paying more than $5 you've overpaid). Total= $9.50. With the 50 cent you can go buy another box drink. VITASOY LEMON TEA is my favorite,
author: Katrina C.

description:
I was so impressed - you actually half forget you are in San Francisco and not China!


 Lots of nice buildings and it has a real comfortable, safe vibe.


 Some cracking little shops for presents - and strangely, very cheap!


 Ooooh - good restaurants/ food stalls too!!
author: Pinklizard

description: Great place to take visitors to SF. Used to buy fireworks down there back in the day. My girlfriends mom likes to shop there when she comes to town. Restaurants can be hit or miss in that area. Look for the ones that are packed with chinese people. That will be your best bet for good and inexpensive food.
author: David P.

description:
From what I heard, San Francisco's China Town is the largest collection of Chinese in the US.  Driving down Stockton would make that even more obvious.

I love walking through this area on a nice Saturday afternoon.  Finding a cozy restaurant, sipping a cup of tea - or maybe just finding a special bargain.  

This is a great place.  Make it yours today!
author: James B.

description:
note-this review is dedicated to the punk asses who think it's funny to throw firecrackers 2 feet away from people waiting for the bus


 Here's a short list of things I hate about Chinatown:
-everybody smokes
-the spitting-'nuff said
-people see the red lights and don't walk signs as suggestions
-ma and pa kettle see nothing wrong with standing in the middle of the street blocking traffic in order to take a picture to send home to the kids on the farm
-the smell-eww.


 Ok, maybe I'm being a bit harsh but I feel a hell of a lot better now. Thanks for letting an old man vent a bit.
author: tvham

description: Chinatown is commercial, but it is teeming with people and activity. Some restaurtants are touristy, so avoid those--go to some of the little hole in the wall spots for a real Chinatown experience. Another good idea is to take a free San Francisco Guides walk thru Chinatown, sponsored by the Library. This gives you a real close up view of the area
author: Nathanw88

description: I LOVE Chinatown . It has like everything you need ! I grew up going to Chinatown at least once every week . There's a wide variety of cheap groceries .. anything from fish to canned foods to meat to veggies to frozen foods . There's a few shops that sell Asian tea which comes in loose tea leaf .. good for you tea lovers out there ;) . They also sell soda , Asian beverages , and Asian snacks . There's some boutiques as well that sell some pretty unique stuff . I only shop at one boutique in Chinatown and it's my favorite boutique . Lots of cute and trendy clothing =] . Sorry , I'm just more of a boutique person . I hate mainstream clothing . I barely ever shop at corporate stores . And no , I'm not going to tell you guys which boutique it is is .. don't want all you going there or else there would be no more cute sexy clothes left for me hehe ;) .  There's also a cosmetic store that sells interesting decent Asian skincare and makeup products . There's some spas too .. my favorite spa in Chinatown . I've been a good amount of spas but they give the best quality facial massages and facials at the best prices . There's 3 Bank of Americas , 1 Wells Fargo , and 1 Washington Mutual in Chinatown . There's LOTS AND LOTS of hair salons that will give cheap haircuts . There's 4 parks and a recreation center . There's LOTS AND LOTS of Chinese restaurants .. well duh - it's Chinatown !! Lastly , the reason why I LOVE Chinatown is because it's the only ghetto left in SF . Don't drive to Chinatown unless you're willing to pay for garage parking because there is NO PARKING in Chinatown .. there's just no room for it - the streets are too narrow . Don't take the bus through Chinatown .. it's just so packed that it's not even funny . You will get so frustrated taking the bus through Chinatown . Your best option would be to get off at North Beach and walk though Chinatown or get off at Downtown and walk through Chinatown . C'mon people .. stop being so lazy !! It's only a few blocks ! Another thing I don't like is Grant St - it's way too touristy . Don't even argue with me .. you all know it's true !!
author: Eileen L.

description:
when i was younger my mom worked for Saks  5th Avenue as a manager of their alterations department. anyone who has been in Saks knows that their prices, attitude, and overall demeanor is like hot air, uncomfortable and always rising.
 one sunny day my friend Shari and I went to SF to do what all 8th graders do, take the muni all over town looking for adventures. on this specific day  we found ourselves on a mission to free a toad from the cruelty of china town grocery stores. the mission was limited to one toad because we needed money to get home and still eat something. So, we bought the toad. It was sold to us in a plastic bag which we filled up with water. Hero Helen and Sidekick Shari got back on muni and went back to Union Square to share the saved creature with my very important mother. 
 It is clear that the next part of the story takes place inside of Saks 5th Avenue with a steaming mother an innocent group of superheroes and a very happy, slimy, living toad. I was banned from visiting my mother at work for a year.

back to china town for a second. 
  the place looks like something out of  movie. people still dry their sheets out on clothes lines outside their windows, the crowds are monstrous, and the smell, OH THE SMELL....
  great food, a must for tourists too see, and incredible back scratchers for $1
:)
author: Helen N.

description: Chinatown used to be a wonderful place with several good restaurants with the question being the avenues or Chinatown? Well, that is no longer the case with Oriental Pearl, Bow Hun, Sam Wo, and Great Oriental being the only excellent contenders left in the neighborhood. Lee Po and the rest of the watering holes are excellent, as are all of the shops, Golden Gate Bakery, and markets for nicknack's and groceries. Otherwise, Chinatown is more of a tourist trap that needs revitalization bad.! Chinatown for shopping, groceries, and cocktails and the avenues and suburbs for food okay.!
author: Brian S.

description: dim sum = the only reason you will ever catch me dead in china town.
author: Alyssa W.

description: i love it! this china town is like a thousand times better than the one in LA... don't get hustled! look for your deals! werd...
author: A. M.

description: i love chinatown. even though waiting in line is apparently illegal there. i love how it's still a vibrant, living, breathing ethnic community and not just some tourist trap. i love its rich history (and present) of community activism. i love the chinese donuts filled with red bean. and i love the grampas at portsmouth square.
author: sarah i.

description: I am Chinese and I used to hate this place with a passion.  Maybe b/c I felt as if I was too good for it.  But after being exposed to it more and more, it felt comfortable going there.  I've been there as a kid every year and first couple of times was fun but afterwards, it got boring b/c it's all the same.  When I moved back to the Bay area, I rarely went there b/c it smelled, the people were rude, and quite frankly, I didn't think the food was any good.  Now, after some time and knowing where to go and what to buy, I started liking it because turns out that there are some things that you can get in Chinatown that you can't get elsewhere.  For example, you can't get any better egg tarts than Golden Gate Bakery, you can't get any better produce than at Chinatown, and you don't have old ladies cutting in front of you while you are waiting for a cashier anywhere else but in Chinatown.  If you like to cook and eat like me, I think the best place to buy asian fruits and vegetables is in Chinatown.  Just yesterday, fresh (not frozen) Longan's were only $1.09 a pound.  The only problem with Chinatown is the parking.  Either park in a garage or have patience when looking for a spot.  Don't forget to overfill your parking meter b/c the meter maids are out in full force over there.  Also, if you go after 3pm, expect not the best and sometimes dried vegetables b/c 1) the old ladies have already picked out the best ones or 2) they stores won't restock b/c it's late in the afternoon and they are about to close.  However, on the flip side, during the late afternoon they keep lowering their prices so they don't have to repack it and bring it back inside.  I think that's the same case with the chinese deli's too but I'm not too sure about that.
author: Benny M.

description:
pros...you can find most anything here.  can we say "tourist trap"?  and you guessed it everything they sell is actually made in "china".  cool huh?  fun place to visit, the streets are just like in china, they are old and not that clean.  some places smell, and it's crowded everywhere and all the time as well.  be prepared to bargain with the people,  it is just fun to haggle with the shop owners.  most of them will do it, i guess it reminds them of home.  it also helps to speak or bring someone who speaks cantonese, (just kidding), but really it can only help.  i love the wok shop, it of course sells all sort s of woks, knives, and other cooking equipment.  i love the eastern bakery too, it has gone a bit downhill but still good stuff.  and just wander around to any restaurant where the people are mostly chinese, and you will find authentic or at least good food.  don't be afraid to explore the little shops, one of my favorites is the fung ng kee gallery.  it has paintings and scrolls and they will even make a chop for you, chinese stone seal.  

cons...this place is a mad house of confusion, chaos congestion and commerce.  you will be hard pressed to find any parking...so just give in and park in one of the garages.  it is always crowded, be prepared to walk a lot, and up hills most of the time.  do some bargaining, it's so fun.
author: Joel G.

description: its kool little shops & cheap produce & other stuff as well dim sum places /cafes reminds me of hong kong! =]
author: Kevin L.

description: arg, chinatown, one word that sums it up is i think is just plain dirty. sorry but there are wet water, people shouting everywhere, vegetable, meat on the ground especially in the main market place. sorry if i am too harsh, but people push you around, and give me no respect everytime i go there. but there are good things too, there are a lot of paid parking that usually has space, so parking is not too hard to find if you are willing to pay, and there are murals on the walls that look really nice, and things there are quite cheap, but the quality is not guaranteed.
author: moonight

description:
The Chinatown in San Francisco is the oldest chinatown in USA. I believe it is also one of the largest chinatowns outside Asia, if not the largest. So if you dont have the opportunity to go all the way to china, this would be a funny place to visit if you happen to be visiting the city. 
I used to live near the Chinatown gate for a little while. So for me its nostalgic. Is a hastle,always crowded, full of angry little chinese grandmas shouting , lots of tourists, but has some places with good chinese food. just better avoid going to the bathroom if not absolutely nessesary ;) you might find some little friends there 
Many little shops full of items you will never need. but I think its funny to hang around and just look.
What is great though is that there is oriental supermarkets, where you can get very good ingredients. Also some herbal stores, if you are into chinese medicine. I have no experience on that. Also in china town is the Golden Gate Fortune Cookie Factory, where you can get freshly made Fortune cookies of all sizes and shapes.
author: nostylebutgoodsense

description: so much history (first house in san francisco anyone) so much culture so many shops so much good food so many beautiful people.
author: cesar z.
